translated_text:
A Ukrainian woman in Simferopol, the second largest city in Crimea, when there were still protests against Russia's takeover of the Ukrainian peninsula PHOTO Spencer Platt/Getty Images
International
From the human cordon for independence to the fear of total invasion. A chronology of relations between Ukraine and Russia
Sovereign for more than three decades, Ukraine continues to be a country forced to fight every day for its democracy ‚Äì the current President has not escaped the temptations of centralizing power. From 1991 to 2022, Russia and Ukraine went through periods of rapprochement, but the biggest demonstrations in the country were in favor of a preferential relationship with the West
Facebook
Twitter
Linkedin
email
18:31 February 22, 2022
18:42 February 22, 2022
|
Ana Fran√ßa
In January 1990, more than 400,000 Ukrainians joined hands in a chain that linked the city of Lviv, in the far west of the country, to the capital, Kiev, waving the blue and yellow flag, a symbol that should not be seen in public, as Moscow's rules dictated. The Soviet bloc was collapsing and a year after this day Ukraine had already become independent.
#OTD
in 1990, >400k Ukrainiansüá∫üá¶ joined hands from Kyiv to Lviv to demand independence. It was our first
#UkrainianWave
. Today we face more than 100k üá∑üá∫ troops at our border. Join us for a new
#UkrainianWave
to support our right to choose our own path!
RT
#StandWithUkraine
+ üëã
pic.twitter.com/4eeEsAJ73M
‚Äî MFA of Ukraine üá∫üá¶ (@MFA_Ukraine)
January 22, 2022
In 1992 there was the first approach to NATO, when the Ukrainian President, Leonid Kravchuk, visited the headquarters of the Atlantic Alliance, in Brussels.
In 1994, Ukraine handed over its nuclear arsenal, at the time the third largest in the world, in exchange for protection from the United Kingdom and the United States.
. It was in the 2000s that the contours of the conflict that now engulfs Europe began to emerge.
2004 ‚Äì Yushchenko, pro-NATO candidate for President, is poisoned
Presidential elections. Viktor Yanukovych, a man close to Russian President Vladimir Putin, is running against another candidate, closer to the West, Viktor Yushchenko. In the final months of the campaign, Yushchenko falls ill and doctors confirm that he was poisoned,
having been operated on more than 20 times
, according to Reuters. Unsurprisingly, but under accusations of a fraudulent election, Yanukovych wins. But the Ukrainian people do not accept it and after huge protests, which became known as the Orange Revolution, and three votes, Yushchenko manages to become president.
Former Ukrainian President Viktor Yushchenko at the ‚ÄúSolidarity in the 21st Century‚Äù conference in Poland. PHOTO: Michal Fludra/NurPhoto via Getty Images
2008 ‚Äì first ‚Äúpromise‚Äù of joining NATO
Neither Yushchenko nor Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko are able to effect Ukraine's entry into NATO. Both France and Germany are opposed, after Russia expressed concern about this potential inclusion. The United States supports the entry of Ukrainians into the military alliance, the result is
a no-strings-attached commitment
: NATO promises that Ukraine will become a member one day, but there is no written date, not even a list of essential changes that Ukraine would need to guarantee in order to gain entry.
A survey carried out by the Ukrainian company Rating Group, published last Friday, shows that 62% of citizens support joining NATO
.
2010 ‚Äì President close to Russia returns
Yanukovych is elected in February, and calls for a more ‚Äúneutral‚Äù Ukraine, which negotiates with the West but also with Russia.
Donbass and Kosovo: discover the differences
2011 ‚Äì Prime Minister tried for ‚Äúabuse of power‚Äù
Ukrainian prosecutors are opening an investigation into the prime minister for ‚Äúabuse of power‚Äù during the 2009 energy crisis, during which Russia disrupted the supply of much of Europe, not just Ukraine. After lengthy negotiations, the situation returned to normal but the court ended up sentencing Yulia Tymoshenko to seven years in prison. Some members of the pro-Western opposition are beginning to raise doubts about President Yanukovych's plans to remove critical voices.
2014 ‚Äì The second wave of pro-Western protests
After the ‚ÄúOrange Revolution‚Äù, comes the ‚ÄúRevolution of Dignity‚Äù, the second time in the History of post-Soviet Ukraine in which a large number of citizens took to the streets to demonstrate against the country's departure from a line closer to the capitals to the West. Citing pressure from the Kremlin, Yanukovych announces that he will not sign a collaboration and commercial integration treaty with the European Union ‚Äì and Kiev becomes a campsite for protesters. Some government buildings are occupied, including the Ministry of Justice. By the end of February, the authorities' rather violent response had left 100 people dead.
Yanukovych, who began his career precisely as governor of Donetsk, flees to Russia and, in his absence, the Ukrainian parliament unanimously calls for his removal. An interim government is installed, the agreement is signed and Tymoshenko is released. The new government decides to accuse the former President of the ‚Äúmass murder‚Äù of Maidan protesters and issues a warrant for his arrest.
Russia declares these protests and the government changes they provoked as a ‚Äúcoup d‚Äô√©tat‚Äù and shortly after the new government took office, armed men appear on the Crimean peninsula
a, Putin himself admits, after denying, that they are Russian forces.
2014 ‚Äì Hot March
Russia controls the peninsula and officially annexes it after a referendum showed 97% of inhabitants in favor of the territory's entry into the Russian Federation. Kiev and a large part of the international community criticize this vote, carried out under the presence of Russian weapons and without an option, on the ballot paper, that would allow people to choose the status quo ‚Äì which at the time would be maintaining the autonomous status of Crimea, with the high level of independence in relation to Kiev that it already had.
2014 ‚Äì Parts of the east also fall
Shortly afterwards, in April, with around 40 thousand Russian troops already stationed on the eastern border with Ukraine, violence broke out in parts of the provinces of Donetsk and Luhansk.¬† Pro-Russian separatists and Russian militias conquered part of the provinces and not all of them.
The ceasefire line between the official Ukrainian army and the occupying militias determines only a small enclave of the entire province of Donbass
‚Äì the collective name of the Donetsk and Luhansk regions. Going beyond that line, in 2015 as today, is invading yet another part of Ukraine, it is not ‚Äújust‚Äù occupying parts that were already separated from Ukrainian territory.
What is a ‚Äúfalse flag‚Äù? How do you create a pretext for war? Interview with Olga Lautman, propaganda maneuvers researcher
May 2014 ‚Äì another pro-Western President and referendums in Donbas
Petro Poroshenko, director of the Board of the Ukrainian National Bank is elected President of the country. He tries, like others before him, to promote some anti-corruption measures and also reduce Ukraine's dependence on Russian energy.
The ‚Äúpeople's republics‚Äù of Donetsk and Luhansk were born through two referenda ‚Äì not even Russia recognizes these electoral acts
which resulted in 96% support for independence in Luhansk and 89% in Donetsk. Russia, Germany, France and Ukraine meet in the Belarusian capital, Minsk, and agree to a ceasefire, which quickly fails ‚Äì and the war continues until 2015
2015 ‚Äì Minsk version 2.0
The same representatives meet again in Minsk and the Minsk II Agreements are born, which, despite not being able to completely stop the violence, mark the beginning of a relatively less violent phase. Still, 14 thousand people have died in this war since 2014, at least one million have had to leave their homes.
Soldier on guard duty in a trench in Ukraine near the border with RUSSIA Photo: Gaelle Girbes/Getty Images
The agreements contain several points open to different interpretations and therefore many analysts also consider them difficult to implement. The document provided that, in a new Ukrainian Constitution, the decentralization of the Donetsk and Luhansk regions would be enshrined, guaranteeing, among other things, the right to linguistic self-determination; the appointment, by the new autonomous authorities, of prosecutors and judges; ‚Äútransnational cooperation‚Äù between the occupied regions and Russian regions, among other things that Ukraine‚Äôs current leaders do not accept.
Countries clash in the order of solutions established in the document
. Ukraine wants to reestablish control in the east before a political agreement is signed, with Russia withdrawing and only after that allowing elections to be held and the cession of some powers to the regions. For the Russians, Minsk II implies a political agreement finalized before Kiev regains control of Donbass: elections would first be held and Ukraine would agree to give these ‚Äúrepublics‚Äù a series of powers, including the ability to veto decisions such as joining NATO. That's what
It became known in geopolitical jargon as ‚Äúthe Minsk charade‚Äù because these agreements present mutually exclusive notions of sovereignty.
2016 and 2017 ‚Äì computer attacks and destabilization
As Ukrainian forces and separatists close to the Kremlin continue the war on the border, they also multiply
computer attacks
, which Ukraine attributes to Russia. In 2016, an attack on Ukraine's electricity grid causes a general blackout. In 2017, another attack: disruptions in the banking system, and again a blackout, provoked fear in the population. As early as 2022, Ukraine reported a ‚Äúmajor attack‚Äù on several government websites. Also in 2017, the European Union ended the visa requirement for the entry of Ukrainian citizens and another commercial collaboration protocol was signed.
2019 ‚Äì Current president is elected but the war continues
Well-known comedian and actor Volodymyr Zelensky wins the presidential election and promises to end the war in Donbass, a goal he failed. But it didn't just fail there. Despite its popularity being at 20%, which is quite good in Ukraine, some analysts began to notice
an unhealthy concentration of various areas of civil and political life under the purview of the President
, for example, the attorney general and other institutions linked to criminal investigation and direct influence in parliament.
Volodymyr Zelensky, President of Ukraine, in Donbass, the region in eastern Ukraine that is the front line between Russian and Ukrainian troops PHOTO: Getty Images
2021 ‚Äì The beginning of this crisis
In April, Russia sends around 100,000 soldiers to Ukraine's borders, allegedly to participate in military exercises
. Zelensky urges the NATO leadership to put Ukraine on a serious plan to join the Atlantic Alliance, but nothing happens. At the end of April, Russia says it will withdraw troops, but tens of thousands of troops remain. In August, Zelensky visits the White House, with Joe Biden now president (Trump had asked for an investigation of the Bidens in exchange for financial aid to Ukraine).
New satellite images. Diplomacy on one side, more barracks for troops on the other: Russia continues to prepare
The President of the United States emphasizes that his country is committed ‚Äúto the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine in the face of Russian aggression‚Äù, but repeats that Ukraine has not yet met the necessary conditions to join NATO
, something that was said again a week ago by the German Chancellor, Olaf Scholz. In November 2021, Russian troops return, and Western intelligence agencies record a permanent accumulation of more and more soldiers, tents, and heavy weapons, which leads some leaders to once again speak of the imminent threat of an attack.
December 2021 ‚Äì Kremlin issues demands
Joe Biden and Vladimir Putin talk on the phone. Biden asks Putin not to invade any more parts of Ukraine and warns that there will be ‚Äúa very heavy cost‚Äù if that is the path chosen. Following this conversation, Russia writes a list of demands, including that NATO withdraw all its military forces from countries that joined the Alliance after 1997, when no Warsaw Pact country had yet joined.
The requirement is not met by the United States, nor is there any reason to believe that this will ever happen.
. Russia also asks that neither Ukraine nor Georgia (whose regions of Abkhazia and South Ossetia have also already been annexed by Russia) join NATO but, once again, representatives of the military alliance do not accept closing the doors. This does not mean that there is a short or medium term intention to accept any of these countries as members. NATO regulations do not allow membership for countries involved in any conflict.
2022 ‚Äì On the verge of an invasion beyond the ‚Äúrepublics‚Äù
January
The year begins with diplomatic activity between East and West that has not been seen since the end of the Cold War ‚Äì and the secretary general of NATO,
I said it myself
that there has not been, since those years, a military concentration as threatening as the one that Russia placed on the Ukrainian borders at the beginning of this year. Political and diplomatic leaders from Russia, the United States, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, among others, speak several times on the phone, having also held some face-to-face meetings. On January 23, the US State Department asked the families of diplomatic staff to leave Ukraine and, since that day, many EU countries, almost all in the west and north, have advised their citizens to leave Ukraine as soon as possible.
Ukraine. How important is Donbass? Where does the border of the ‚Äúrepublics‚Äù recognized by Russia run? What remains of the Minsk Agreements?
February
Satellite images show a concentration of more than 150,000 troops on Ukraine's eastern border, but also military ships to the south, in the Black Sea, troops and war arsenal in Crimea and also in southern Belarus (less than 200 kilometers from Kiev), where Russia had military exercises scheduled until February 20. Despite having said that he would return the troops to their original bases, this did not happen. NATO members agreed to send military aid to Ukraine and the United States reinforced the presence of troops in countries close to Ukraine, such as Romania and Poland.
February 21
Vladimir Putin gives a speech in which he denies that Ukraine has ‚Äúany tradition as a sovereign state‚Äù, says that the country is just ‚Äúa Russian creation‚Äù, post-Bolshevik revolution, and ends up recognizing the independence of the self-proclaimed republics of Donetsk and Luhansk ‚Äì which puts an end to the Minsk Agreements, as he himself confirmed. The Western world assumes the collective shock of Putin's words and several sanctions packages begin to be drafted, in Washington, London, Brussels and, surprisingly, in Berlin, with Chancellor Olaf Scholz putting
a brake
in the certification of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline. Putin authorizes a ‚Äúpeacekeeping mission‚Äù in the occupied territories and sends tanks and troops.
February 22
Putin asks for ‚Äì and gets ‚Äì authorization from the lower house of the Russian parliament to use Russian troops abroad. NATO allies consider it possible for Russian troops to cross the line of separation between the territory controlled by Russian separatists and the rest of the provinces, which would be a new invasion of new Ukrainian territory that is currently not controlled by Russian armed militias.

translated_text:
"The
"As the assets of the five Russian banks involved in financing the Russian occupation are frozen, the decision comes into force immediately," said British Foreign Secretary Liz Truss.
The banks covered are IS Bank, General Bank, Black Sea Bank, which operate in Crimea, and Promsvyazbank (Moscow) and Rossiya Bank (St. Petersburg).
Promsvyazbank is state-owned through the Federal Property Management Agency, being the main creditor of Russia's defense industry sector and serving 70% of the state defense order.
The amount of financing provided to defense industry companies is 1.5 billion rubles, Promsvyazbank leader Pyotr Fradkov said at a meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin last December.
Rossiya Bank has been on the United States sanctions list since 2014, which implies the strictest possible restrictions, including the blocking of properties and accounts, as well as a ban on maintaining business relationships.
The current shareholders of the banking institution are unknown, as the Kremlin allowed sanctioned banks not to disclose information about their beneficiaries. The bank occupies 12th place in the Interfax-100 ranking.
General Bank, which operates in Crimea, is owned by Rossiya Bank and has also been under sanctions for eight years.
The new sanctions, according to the chairman of the board of directors, Elena Blinova, will not affect the bank's financial position and operations.
Also in Crimea, the Black Sea Bank, which belongs to the local government, has been under US sanctions for several years.
Despite being registered in Moscow, IS Bank carries out operations in Crimea, from Simferopol, and has been included on the US sanctions list since 2017.
The United Kingdom today announced sanctions against three oligarchs known to be close to Russian President Vladimir Putin and against five Russian banks, in retaliation for Moscow's recognition of the separatist regions of Luhansk and Donetsk, in eastern Ukraine.
The targeted billionaires are Gennady Timchenko, Boris Rotenberg and the latter's nephew, Igor Rotenberg, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson revealed in Parliament.
Johnson warned he has other sanctions "ready" to be introduced alongside the United States and the European Union (EU) if the conflict continues to escalate.
"This is the first installment, the first load of what we are prepared to do and we have more sanctions ready to be imposed," he said.
The sanctions package was announced after an emergency meeting of ministers and senior officials, held this morning, at the so-called Cobra security committee.
Foreign Minister Liz Truss also said that Russia's ambassador to the United Kingdom, Andrei Kelin, was called "to explain Russia's violation of international law and disrespect for Ukraine's sovereignty."
The head of the British Government told deputies to anticipate a "long crisis" in Ukraine, taking into account that Putin ordered the deployment of troops for alleged "peacekeeping" operations in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions.
"I can't say what will happen in the next few days, but we must expect a long crisis," said Boris Johnson.
In 2014, Russia annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea, after the fall of the pro-Russian government in Kiev, and held a referendum on the return of the territory to the Russian Federation. Since then, Kiev has been in conflict with pro-Russian separatists in the east of the country.
The war in eastern Ukraine between Kiev forces and pro-Russian separatists has so far killed more than 14,000 people, according to the United Nations.
Russian President Vladimir Putin signed, on Monday night, a decree recognizing the separatist regions of Lugansk and Donetsk, in the Donbass (east), and ordered the entry of Russian armed forces into those Ukrainian territories in a "peacekeeping" mission.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, which have already announced or are preparing economic sanctions against Russia.

translated_text:
O
Russian President Vladimir Putin said this Wednesday that Russia is "open to dialogue" and "diplomatic solutions" in relation to the conflict with Ukraine, but stressed that the country's interests are "non-negotiable".
‚ÄúOur country is always open to direct and honest dialogue, looking for diplomatic solutions to the most complex problems‚Äù
, said Putin in a speech broadcast on television to mark Defender of the Fatherland Day, a public holiday in Russia.
But he stressed:
‚ÄúRussia‚Äôs interests, the security of our citizens, are non-negotiable‚Äù
.
The conflict between Ukraine and Russia has escalated in recent days after, on Monday,
Putin recognizes the separatist regions of Donetsk and Luhansk as People's Republics
, in Ukraine. On the same day, the Russian president ordered
mobilization of your country‚Äôs Army for ‚Äúpeacekeeping‚Äù in those territories
from eastern Ukraine.
In his speech today, Putin stated that he is certain of the ‚Äúprofessionalism‚Äù of the Russian military and that they will defend the country's national interests, at a time when the country continues to develop modern weapons, leaving its specifications open - which could range from computer attacks to nuclear attacks.
‚ÄúWe will continue to develop advanced weapons systems, including hypersonic and based on new physical principles, and expand the use of advanced digital technologies and elements of artificial intelligence‚Äù
, he stated. ‚ÄúThese are truly the weapons of the future, which significantly increase the combat potential of our armed forces.‚Äù
Meanwhile, this Wednesday, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Ukraine appealed to national citizens to
leave Russia as quickly as possible in the face of the worsening military situation
. "The ministry recommends Ukrainian citizens to refrain from all travel to Russia and those already there should leave (Russian) territory immediately,"
indicates Kiev's diplomacy, in a statement released today
.
This morning, the Ukrainian army confirmed that
one soldier died and others were injured
following attacks in separatist regions in the last 24 hours. Since the beginning of this year,
eight soldiers of the Ukrainian Armed Forces and one civilian died
in confrontations.
EU, UK sanctions and German punishment in Nord Stream 2
Given Putin's recognition of the separatist regions as independent, the
The European Union approved, on Tuesday, ‚Äúa package of sanctions‚Äù against Russia ‚Äúunanimously‚Äù
. The United Kingdom also announced sanctions against three oligarchs close to the Russian president and against five banks. As for Germany, Chancellor Olaf Scholz revealed that
Berlin took steps to stop the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline certification process
, for the distribution of Russian natural gas to Germany.
Outside Europe, the president of the United States of America, Joe Biden,
advanced a series of economic sanctions on Russian individuals, entities and banks
. Secretary of State Anthony Blinken, on the other hand,
canceled the meeting he had with the Russian Foreign Minister
, Sergey Lavrov, stressing
"Russia has made clear its total rejection of diplomacy"
and, therefore,
"it makes no sense to move forward with this meeting at this time"
.
Today, a source from the North American Department of Defense announced that the country is preparing to
send 800 more military personnel to the Baltic countries
- Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania - by the end of this week, to reinforce NATO in the face of the threat of a Russian invasion of Ukraine.
Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced that his
citizens are prevented "from carrying out any foreign transactions" with the pro-Russian separatist territories
and "participating in the purchase of Russian debt." The country will still
deploy up to 460 Armed Forces personnel to Latvia.
In Japan, they were
issuance and distribution of Russian sovereign debt securities prohibited in Japan
, in response to "Russia's actions in Ukraine." Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida also said that the government will
ban trade with Luhansk and Donetsk
, suspend the issuance of visas for people linked to the two eastern areas of Ukraine and freeze the assets of these individuals in Japan.
Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison also announced
sanctions against banking institutions and industries from different sectors
, such as energy, mining and hydrocarbons. Entry will also be banned and sanctions will be applied¬†to eight members of Russia's security council.
"United Nations Charter is not an '√† la carte menu'"
The secretary-general of the United Nations (UN), Ant√≥nio Guterres, also
condemned the Kremlin's position
and stressed that
the principles of the "United Nations Charter are not an '√† la carte menu'"
and Russia must "apply them all" in relation to Ukraine.
"The decision of the Russian Federation to recognize the so-called 'independence' of certain areas of the Donetsk and Lugansk regions is a violation of the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine," he stressed, adding that the
Recognition of separatist territories "is a fatal blow to the Minsk Agreements approved by the Security Council"
of the United Nations.
On the social network Twitter, Ant√≥nio Guterres also said he was
‚Äúconcerned about the perversion of the concept of peacekeeping‚Äù
, in a reference to Putin's justification for mobilizing the Russian Army in the separatist regions.
"When troops from one country enter the territory of another country without its consent, then they are not impartial peacekeeping forces. They are not peacekeeping forces at all"
, he stressed.
I am concerned about the perversion of the concept of peacekeeping.
When troops of one country enter the territory of another country without its consent, they are not impartial peacekeepers.
They are not peacekeepers at all.
‚Äî Ant√≥nio Guterres (@antonioguterres)
February 23, 2022
In turn, the British Minister for Foreign Affairs, Liz Truss, considered
"highly likely" that Russian president wants to invade Ukraine
and take Kiev.
"We think it is highly likely that he [Vladimir Putin] will carry out the plan for a total invasion of Ukraine"
, said Liz Truss on the Sky News television channel.
It should be noted that Russia is considered the instigator of the conflict in eastern Ukrainian territory and the sponsor of the separatists. A
war broke out about eight years ago
, following the Russian annexation of the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea, after the rise to power of pro-Westerners in Kiev in early 2014.

translated_text:
O
Putin's spokesman Dmitry Peskov said today that the separatist 'rebels' of Donetsk and Luhansk have asked Russia for military support to "repel aggression" by the Ukrainian army.
The statement was broadcast by Russian state news agencies, but this request for 'help' was already expected since the leader of the self-proclaimed separatist republic of Donetsk, in eastern Ukraine, had already admitted this afternoon to asking Russia for military help in the event of Ukrainian aggression.
Remember that Putin had already mentioned that the
sending Russian troops to Ukrainian territory would depend on the situation on the ground
having assumed yesterday that the clashes "continue" and tend to worsen.
At the press conference he also called for international recognition of Russia's sovereignty over Crimea, the Ukrainian peninsula that Moscow annexed in 2014, and said that everything will depend on the development of events and the "situation on the ground".
The Russian president signed two decrees on Monday that ask the Russian Ministry of Defense that "the Russian Armed Forces assume peacekeeping functions on the territory" of the "people's republics" of Donetsk and Luhansk, leading to strong criticism from the US, the UK and even Europe.
Separatists denounce intensification of attacks
The leaders of the two self-proclaimed separatist provinces, Donetsk and Lugansk, today denounced the intensification of attacks by Ukrainian forces against the cities they control.
According to Pushilin, for the first time in a long time, the city of Donetsk was hit by rocket fire, and pro-Russian separatists in Lugansk accused the Ukrainian army of attacking 12 locations with artillery.
The authorities in Kiev, in turn, hold the separatists responsible for violations of the ceasefire, which have increased considerably in recent days, at a time when Moscow ordered the withdrawal of all diplomatic personnel from Ukrainian territory and Ukraine ordered the mobilization of military reserves to reinforce the army.
Moscow-backed pro-Russian separatists from Donetsk and Luhansk went to war with Ukrainian authorities in 2014 following Russia's annexation of the Crimean peninsula.
Since then, the conflict has caused more than 14,000 deaths and displaced 1.5 million people, according to the United Nations.

translated_text:
World
Moscow announces request for help from separatists to fight against Kiev
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
22:03
0
Comments
Photo:¬†EPA/THIBAULT CAMUS
The Kremlin announced today that the leaders of the self-proclaimed pro-Russian separatist republics in eastern Ukraine have asked Russian President Vladimir Putin for help to "repel aggression" by the Ukrainian military.
According to Russian presidential spokesman Dmitry Peskov, quoted by Russian state media, the two separatist regions of Donetsk and Luhansk, whose independence Moscow recognized this week, "requested help from the President of Russia to repel the aggression of the Ukrainian armed forces".
This appeal, if accepted, could mean Russia's direct military involvement in eastern Ukraine, confirming Western countries' fears that Moscow is preparing an invasion of the neighboring country.
The Kremlin spokesman added that the leaders of the two separatist territories wrote to Vladimir Putin denouncing bombings by the Ukrainian military that caused civilian deaths and forced many people to flee.
"The actions of the Kiev regime testify to its refusal to end the war [in the region of] Donbass", said the separatist leaders, cited by the Kremlin.
The Kremlin's narrative is contradicted by the Ukrainian government and Western countries, which claim that it was pro-Russian separatists who bombed areas controlled by Kiev.
A Ukrainian soldier was killed today, and another was injured, in a bombing carried out by pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine, the Ukrainian army said.
The Ukrainian Armed Forces did not clarify the exact location of the attack, saying only, in a statement, that one soldier "died from injuries" and another survived, also with injuries during the bombing.
In Moscow, Dmitry Peskov added that this request for help was requested "on the basis" of the treaties of friendship and mutual support concluded this week with Moscow.
The West accuses Vladimir Putin of breaking the Minsk Agreements, signed by Kiev and the pro-Russian separatists of Donetsk and Luhansk, under the aegis of Germany, France and Russia.
These aimed to find a solution to the war between Kiev and Moscow-backed separatists that began in 2014, shortly after Russia annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea.
In 2014, separatists declared the independence of the Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Lugansk, which Russia recognized on Monday, in a decision seen by the West as a sign of a new invasion of Ukraine.
After the reconnaissance, Putin authorized the Russian army to send a "peacekeeping" force to Donetsk and Luhansk, raising fears of a Russian offensive in eastern Ukraine.
The war in Donbass has caused more than 14,000 deaths and displaced 1.5 million people since 2014, according to the United Nations.

Refusal to attend this recruitment without a plausible reason may be subject to "administrative and criminal sanctions", the armed forces also say.

translated_text:
And
Rdogan also told Putin that "a military conflict will not help anyone" and that he intends to continue exploring diplomatic channels on the Ukrainian issue, the Turkish Presidency reported, cited by the French agency AFP.
"Turkey will not recognize any measure that affects the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine," Erdogan told Putin during the phone call, the duration of which was not mentioned by the Turkish Presidency.
The President of Turkey appealed to Putin to "find a solution based on the Minsk Agreements" of 2014 and 2015 on the war in the Donbass region, in eastern Ukraine.
Erdogan reaffirmed his "commitment to continuing diplomatic contacts and talks" and assured that "Turkey is ready to do its part to reduce tension".
The Minsk Agreements were signed by Kiev and the pro-Russian separatists of Donetsk and Luhansk, located in the Donbass region, under the aegis of Germany, France and Russia.
They aimed to find a solution to the war between Kiev and Moscow-backed separatists that began in 2014, shortly after Russia annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea.
The war in Donbass has caused more than 14,000 deaths and displaced 1.5 million people since 2014, according to the United Nations.
In 2014, separatists declared the independence of the Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Lugansk, which Russia recognized on Monday, in a decision seen by the West as a sign of a new invasion of Ukraine.
After the reconnaissance, Putin authorized the Russian army to send a "peacekeeping" force to Donetsk and Luhansk, raising fears of a Russian offensive in eastern Ukraine.
Erdogan had already considered Moscow's recognition of the independence of Donetsk and Luhansk unacceptable, in a first reaction on Tuesday.
However, in statements made on the plane that transported him from Senegal on Tuesday night, he made it clear that he did not intend to break with Russia and Ukraine.
"It's not possible. We have political and military relations with Russia. We also have political, military and economic relations with Ukraine", explained Erdogan to the journalists who accompanied him.
"We want the issue to be resolved without having to choose between the two," he insisted.
Turkey, a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), is close to Kiev, to which it has sold military drones (unmanned aircraft).
It is also very dependent on Moscow for its energy and grain supplies, among other goods, and has acquired a Russian S-400 missile defense system.
Erdogan offered his mediation to avoid a conflict between Ukraine and Russia, countries that, like Turkey, are located on the shores of the Black Sea.

translated_text:
World
Kiev orders mobilization of reservists between 18 and 60 years old
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
10:08
0
Comments
Photo EPA
The Ukrainian Armed Forces announced today the mobilization of reservists aged 18 to 60, in light of the worsening military situation caused by Russia.
"The mobilization concerns reservists aged between 18 and 60", says a message from the Ukrainian land forces published today on the social network Facebook.
"The mobilization starts today (Wednesday). The maximum period of service is one year", he adds.
Ukraine has more than 200,000 reservists, in addition to around 250,000 members of the regular armed forces.
Refusal to attend this recruitment without a plausible reason may be subject to "administrative and criminal sanctions", the armed forces also say.
On Tuesday, the President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky had already determined the partial mobilization of military personnel in reserve to reinforce the Army, but ruled out the total mobilization of the armed forces.
Zelensky explained, in a communication to the country on Tuesday,¬†that the decree applied only to Ukrainians in the operational reserve, mobilized to reinforce the Army fighting pro-Russian militias in the Donbass region¬†and facing the Russian military threat on the border.
Ukraine's National Police also announced today that it will deploy additional forces to the conflict zone in the east of the country to ensure public order.
The "number two" of the National Police, Oleksandr Fatsevich, also told the press that the additional agents will be sent before the end of the week.
Meanwhile, the Ukrainian Ministry of Foreign Affairs today called on national citizens to leave Russia as quickly as possible in the face of the worsening military situation.
"The ministry recommends Ukrainian citizens to refrain from¬†all trips to Russia and those already there should leave (Russian) territory immediately," Kiev diplomacy said in a statement.
Russia, which invaded¬†Ukraine in 2014 and annexed the Crimean peninsula, recognized on Monday as independent the two separatist Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Luhansk, in the Donbas region, worsening the military situation in the region.
Moscow also approved the sending of Russian military personnel to the area.

translated_text:
Home
International
Kiev calls for more sanctions against Russia and weapons to contain attack threat
"More sanctions must be imposed, we must receive more weapons and diplomatic actions must be multiplied", asked the Ukrainian Foreign Minister to the international community.
Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmitro Kuleba speaking at the UN General Assembly
¬©¬†EPA/JASON SZENES
DN/Lusa
23¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†21:59
Facebook
Twitter
Comment
Share
Topics
Ukraine
Russia
UN
International
Related
tension
Putin says rebels in eastern Ukraine have asked for military help. France orders evacuation of citizens
ukraine
UN Security Council meets emergency tonight at Ukraine's request
ukraine
Zelensky says Russia approved military offensive against Ukraine
Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmitro Kuleba called on the international community this Wednesday to strengthen sanctions on Russia and make weapons available for Ukraine to defend itself against Russian aggression.
"More sanctions must be imposed, we must receive more weapons and diplomatic actions must be multiplied", said Dmitro Kuleba, speaking to journalists, after speaking before the UN General Assembly, which held a session specifically dedicated to the crisis in Ukraine today.
The head of Ukrainian diplomacy repeated several times that the sanctions announced on Tuesday by the United States, the European Union (EU), the United Kingdom and other countries "are appreciated, but are not sufficient."
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
Dmitro Kuleba
warned that one should not wait for Russian missiles to fall on Ukrainian soil to impose new sanctions,
arguing that these "must have a deterrent effect".
For the ruler, Ukraine has the right to equip itself with "defensive weapons" that he hopes will not have to be used.
And he recalled that the President of the United States, Joe Biden, and the Secretaries of State, Antony Blinken, and Defense, Lloyd Austin, have committed to continuing to supply weapons and impose sanctions if Russia does not change its attitude.
Kuleba also criticized countries that limit themselves to generic appeals for peace, considering that in this way "a message is sent that this type of behavior is tolerated", giving Japan as an example.
"Russia must be put under pressure"
The situation in eastern Ukraine "is not just a threat against Europe, but against the world order", he warned.
"Russia must be put under pressure. It must be made to feel that the sanctions are not bearable," he said.
Kuleba also revealed that he has repeatedly asked to talk or meet with his Russian counterpart, Sergei Lavrov, but to no avail because until now there has always been "some pretext".
Russia has been criticized for breaking the Minsk Agreements, which aimed to find a solution to the war between Kiev and Moscow-backed separatists that began in 2014, shortly after Russia annexed Ukraine's Crimean peninsula.
In 2014, separatists declared the independence of the Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Lugansk, which Russia recognized on Monday, in a decision seen by the West as a sign of a new invasion of Ukraine.
After the reconnaissance, Putin authorized the Russian army to send a "peacekeeping" force to Donetsk and Luhansk, raising fears of a Russian offensive in eastern Ukraine.
The war in Donbass has caused more than 14,000 deaths and displaced 1.5 million people since 2014, according to the United Nations.

translated_text:
World
Erdogan tells Putin he will never recognize loss of Ukrainian sovereignty
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
17:12
0
Comments
Photo:¬†EPA/ALISA YAKUBOVYCH
Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan warned his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin by telephone today that Turkey will never recognize "any measure that affects the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine", announced the Turkish Presidency.
Erdogan also told Putin that "a military conflict will not help anyone" and that he intends to continue exploring diplomatic channels on the Ukrainian issue, the Turkish Presidency reported, cited by the French agency AFP.
"Turkey will not recognize any measure that affects the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine," Erdogan told Putin during the phone call, the duration of which was not mentioned by the Turkish Presidency.
The President of Turkey appealed to Putin to "find a solution based on the Minsk Agreements" of 2014 and 2015 on the war in the Donbass region, in eastern Ukraine.
Erdogan reaffirmed his "commitment to continuing diplomatic contacts and talks" and assured that "Turkey is ready to do its part to reduce tension".
The Minsk Agreements were signed by Kiev and the pro-Russian separatists of Donetsk and Luhansk, located in the Donbass region, under the aegis of Germany, France and Russia.
They aimed to find a solution to the war between Kiev and Moscow-backed separatists that began in 2014, shortly after Russia annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea.
The war in Donbass has caused more than 14,000 deaths and displaced 1.5 million people since 2014, according to the United Nations.
In 2014, separatists declared the independence of the Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Lugansk, which Russia recognized on Monday, in a decision seen by the West as a sign of a new invasion of Ukraine.
After the reconnaissance, Putin authorized the Russian army to send a "peacekeeping" force to Donetsk and Luhansk, raising fears of a Russian offensive in eastern Ukraine.
Erdogan had already considered Moscow's recognition of the independence of Donetsk and Luhansk unacceptable, in a first reaction on Tuesday.
However, in statements made on the plane that transported him from Senegal on Tuesday night, he made it clear that he did not intend to break with Russia and Ukraine.
"It's not possible. We have political and military relations with Russia. We also have political, military and economic relations with Ukraine", explained Erdogan to the journalists who accompanied him.
"We want the issue to be resolved without having to choose between the two," he insisted.
Turkey, a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), is close to Kiev, to which it has sold military drones (unmanned aircraft).
It is also very dependent on Moscow for its energy and grain supplies, among other goods, and has acquired a Russian S-400 missile defense system.
Erdogan offered his mediation to avoid a conflict between Ukraine and Russia, countries that, like Turkey, are located on the shores of the Black Sea.

translated_text:
World
G7 expresses "unwavering" support for Ukrainian territorial integrity
Lusa Agency
Feb 22, 2022
21:45
0
Comments
Photo EPA
The heads of diplomacy of the G7 great powers today expressed their "unwavering support" for the territorial integrity of Ukraine, after Moscow recognized the independence of Ukrainian separatist regions, the British Foreign Minister announced.
"G7 Foreign Ministers strongly condemn Russia's violation of international commitments," Liz Truss wrote on Twitter, after a phone call with her colleagues from the United States, France, Germany, Italy, Canada and Japan.
"Our support for Ukraine's territorial integrity is unwavering," Truss said.
On Monday, Vladimir Putin ordered the mobilization of the Russian Army for "peacekeeping" in the separatist territories in eastern Ukraine, which he recognized as independent.
Putin signed two decrees ordering the Russian Ministry of Defense that "the Russian Armed Forces assume peacekeeping functions on the territory" of the "people's republics" of Donetsk and Luhansk.
In 2014, Russia invaded eastern Ukraine and annexed the Crimean Peninsula, Ukrainian territory.
The war in eastern Ukraine between Kiev forces and separatist militias has so far killed more than 14,000 people, according to the United Nations.
At the same time, the constitutional referendum on the prohibition of the production or presence of nuclear weapons will take place in Belarus on Sunday, and it is also expected that Russian troops will remain in the country.

Lusa Agency
Feb 22, 2022
22:36
0
Comments
Prime Minister of Finland, Sanna Marin, Photo Pool
Finland will carry out a new "risk analysis" of the project for a new nuclear power plant with Russian participation in the north of the Nordic country, the country's Prime Minister, Sanna Marin, announced today.
The evaluation procedure for the Russian group Rosatom's project, carried out several years ago by the Finnish-Russian company Fennovoima, "was proposed by the Finnish Ministry of Defense", said Sanna Marin, at a press conference dedicated to the crisis in Ukraine and European sanctions against Russia.
On Monday night, Russian President Vladimir Putin signed a decree recognizing the self-proclaimed republics of Luhansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and ordered the mobilization of the Russian army to "maintain peace" in these pro-Russian separatist territories.
Since 2014, when Russia annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea, after the fall of the pro-Russian government in Kiev, and held a referendum on the return of the territory to the Russian Federation, there have been conflicts with pro-Russian separatists in the east of the country.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries.

The president of the European Commission reiterated this Wednesday the EU's strong determination to "free itself from dependence on Russian gas", especially taking into account that Moscow "instrumentalizes energy" to put pressure not only on Ukraine but on the European bloc.
In a statement to the press upon receiving the Norwegian Prime Minister, Jonas Gahr Store, and the President of the Commission at the headquarters of the community executive,
Ursula von der Leyen
, highlighted the importance of a very close and strong partnership between
EU
and
Norway
, commenting that, in current times, when "autocracies are challenging democracies, it is great to have partners who think the same way", share the same values and keep their word.
Von der Leyen said that one of the issues to be discussed is, of course, energy, highlighting once again the imperative need for
EU
diversify its supply sources, so as not to be dependent on
Russia
.
"The
Russia
has been instrumentalizing energy in recent months, not to say years, to put pressure not only on
Ukraine
, but also the
European Union
. And now we are really determined to move away from dependence on Russian gas," he said.
Addressing the Gahr Store, the president of the community executive said it was a pleasure to discuss these issues with the head of Government of a country that has always been "a reliable supplier", with whom the
EU
"he could always count on it", and that he was "always honest, fulfilling his promises".
"And we also share the understanding that yes, gas is important and we need to diversify and modernize systems. But, over time, it is a transitional energy source and we want to move towards renewable energy. For us, the motto is very simple for
European Union
: get rid of dependence on Russian gas and invest more in renewable energy. This is our future, this is the strategic investment in our independence, and I know that here too we share the same perspective", concluded Von der Leyen.
PUB
The Norwegian Prime Minister corroborated the Commission President's words, commenting that sharing common values is effectively "the cornerstone" of cooperation between
EU
and
Norway
, something even more evident when looking at developments in
Ukraine
.
Jonas Gahr Store reiterated that the
EU
You can always count on
Norway
, who aligned his reaction "to what the
Russia
did this week" on
Ukraine
with European partners, as the positions are similar.
On Tuesday, when reacting to the announcement of the adoption of a package of sanctions against
Russia
by the 27 - in view of the recognition of the "Ukrainian regions of
Donetsk
and
Lugansk
" and the decision of the Russian President,
Vladimir Putin
, to mobilize military forces for these self-proclaimed republics, Von der Leyen also welcomed the German Government's decision to interrupt the certification process for the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, for the distribution of Russian natural gas to Germany.
"Nord Stream 2 must be evaluated in light of the security of energy supply for all of Europe. Because this crisis shows that Europe is still too dependent on Russian gas. We must diversify our suppliers and invest heavily in renewable energy. This is a strategic investment in our energy independence", he declared then.
The sanctions package adopted by
EU
appears after
Vladimir Putin
having signed, on Monday night, a decree recognizing the self-proclaimed republics of
Lugansk
and of
Donetsk
, in
Donbass
(eastern Ukraine), and having ordered the mobilization of the Russian army for "peacekeeping" in these pro-Russian separatist territories.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that the
Russia
invaded Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.
In 2014, the
Russia
annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea after the fall of the pro-Russian government in
Kiev
, and prepared a referendum on the return of the territory to the Russian Federation. Since then, Kiev has been in conflict with pro-Russian separatists in the east of the country.

translated_text:
N
In a statement to the press upon receiving the Norwegian Prime Minister, Jonas Gahr Store, at the headquarters of the community executive, the President of the Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, highlighted the importance of the very close and strong partnership between the EU and Norway, commenting that, in current times, when "autocracies are challenging democracies, it is great to have partners who think the same way", share the same values and keep their word.
Von der Leyen said that one of the issues to be discussed is, of course, energy, highlighting once again the imperative need for the EU to diversify its sources of supply, so as not to be dependent on Russia.
"Russia has been instrumentalizing energy in recent months, not to say years, to put pressure not only on Ukraine, but also on the European Union. And now we are really determined to stop being dependent on Russian gas," he declared.
Addressing Gahr Store, the president of the community executive said it was a pleasure to discuss these issues with the head of Government of a country that has always been "a reliable supplier", on which the EU "could always count", and who was "always honest, delivering on what was promised".
"And we also share the understanding that yes, gas is important and we need to diversify and modernize systems. But, over time, it is a transitional energy source and we want to move towards renewable energies. For us, the motto is very simple for the European Union: get rid of dependence on Russian gas and invest more in renewable energies. This is our future, this is the strategic investment in our independence, and I know that here too we share the same perspective", concluded Von der Leyen.
The Norwegian Prime Minister corroborated the Commission President's words, commenting that sharing common values ‚Äã‚Äãis effectively "the cornerstone" of cooperation between the EU and Norway, something even more evident when witnessing developments in Ukraine.
Jonas Gahr Store reiterated that the EU can always count on Norway, which aligned its reaction "to what Russia did this week" in Ukraine with European partners, as the positions are similar.
On Tuesday, when reacting to the announcement of the adoption of a package of sanctions against Russia by the 27 - in view of the recognition of the "Ukrainian regions of Donetsk and Luhansk" and the decision of Russian President Vladimir Putin to mobilize military forces to these self-proclaimed republics, Von der Leyen also welcomed the decision of the German Government to interrupt the certification process of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, for the distribution of Russian natural gas to Germany.
"Nord Stream 2 must be evaluated in light of the security of energy supply for all of Europe. Because this crisis shows that Europe is still too dependent on Russian gas. We must diversify our suppliers and invest heavily in renewable energy. This is a strategic investment in our energy independence", he declared then.
The package of sanctions adopted by the EU comes after Vladimir Putin signed, on Monday night, a decree that recognizes the self-proclaimed republics of Lugansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and ordered the mobilization of the Russian army to "maintain peace" in these pro-Russian separatist territories.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.
In 2014, Russia annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea, after the fall of the pro-Russian government in Kiev, and held a referendum on the return of the territory to the Russian Federation. Since then, Kiev has been in conflict with pro-Russian separatists in the east of the country.

The president of the European Commission reiterated this Wednesday the EU's strong determination to "free itself from dependence on Russian gas", especially taking into account that Moscow "instrumentalizes energy" to put pressure not only on Ukraine but on the European bloc.
In a statement to the press upon receiving the Norwegian Prime Minister, Jonas Gahr Store, at the headquarters of the community executive, the President of the Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, highlighted the importance of the very close and strong partnership between the EU and Norway, commenting that, in current times, when "autocracies are challenging democracies, it is great to have partners who think the same way", share the same values ‚Äã‚Äãand keep their word.
Von der Leyen said that one of the issues to be discussed is, of course, energy, highlighting once again the imperative need for the EU to diversify its sources of supply, so as not to be dependent on Russia.
"Russia has been instrumentalizing energy in recent months, not to say years, to put pressure not only on Ukraine, but also on the European Union. And now we are really determined to stop being dependent on Russian gas," he declared.

Addressing Gahr Store, the president of the community executive said it was a pleasure to discuss these issues with the head of Government of a country that has always been "a reliable supplier", on which the EU "could always count", and who was "always honest, delivering on what was promised".
"And we also share the understanding that yes, gas is important and we need to diversify and modernize systems. But, over time, it is a transitional energy source and we want to move towards renewable energies. For us, the motto is very simple for the European Union: get rid of dependence on Russian gas and invest more in renewable energies. This is our future, this is the strategic investment in our independence, and I know that here too we share the same perspective", concluded Von der Leyen.
The Norwegian Prime Minister corroborated the Commission President's words, commenting that sharing common values ‚Äã‚Äãis effectively "the cornerstone" of cooperation between the EU and Norway, something even more evident when witnessing developments in Ukraine.
Jonas Gahr Store reiterated that the EU can always count on Norway, which aligned its reaction "to what Russia did this week" in Ukraine with European partners, as the positions are similar.
On Tuesday, when reacting to the announcement of the adoption of a package of sanctions against Russia by the 27 - in view of the recognition of the "Ukrainian regions of Donetsk and Luhansk" and the decision of Russian President Vladimir Putin to mobilize military forces to these self-proclaimed republics, Von der Leyen also welcomed the decision of the German Government to interrupt the certification process of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, for the distribution of Russian natural gas to Germany.
"Nord Stream 2 must be evaluated in light of the security of energy supply for all of Europe. Because this crisis shows that Europe is still too dependent on Russian gas. We must diversify our suppliers and invest heavily in renewable energy. This is a strategic investment in our energy independence", he declared then.
The package of sanctions adopted by the EU comes after Vladimir Putin signed, on Monday night, a decree that recognizes the self-proclaimed republics of Lugansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and ordered the mobilization of the Russian army to "maintain peace" in these pro-Russian separatist territories.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.
In 2014, Russia annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea, after the fall of the pro-Russian government in Kiev, and held a referendum on the return of the territory to the Russian Federation. Since then, Kiev has been in conflict with pro-Russian separatists in the east of the country.

translated_text:
"The
The Minsk Agreements were destroyed unilaterally", highlighted the German Minister for Foreign Affairs, Annalena Baerbock, at a press conference in Berlin with her French counterpart, Yves Le Drian.
Baerbock stressed that Russian President Vladimir Putin signed these agreements, but that now "those papers have no value".
The German minister also denounced that the Russian head of state did not tell the truth during diplomatic contacts about Ukraine.
"In Germany we consider this to be lying," he said.
The person responsible for French diplomacy also said that Putin did not comply with his "public and private" statements, the last made in conversations with French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz.
Yves Le Drian assured, however, that "the hand [of diplomacy] is still extended" and that there is nothing worse than a "military confrontation".
"There is a forum for talks and it must continue to exist to continue working towards a peaceful solution", he stressed, referring to the Normandy Format, which brings together Germany, Ukraine, France and Russia around the implementation of the Minsk Agreements.
The Minsk Agreements were signed by Ukraine and pro-Russian separatists from Donetsk and Luhansk, in the Donbass region, and aimed to find a solution to the war between Kiev and Moscow-backed separatists, which began in 2014, shortly after Russia annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea.
Those responsible for German and French diplomacy warned of the need to be prepared for "the worst-case scenario", threatening a tougher sanctions package than the one announced yesterday by the European Union (EU).
"For a free and sovereign Ukraine, we are willing to suffer economic costs", assured Baerbock, recalling that Germany interrupted the certification process for the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline on Tuesday because peace in Europe is "priceless".
Both Foreign Ministers also declared themselves in favor of maintaining the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) observation mission in the Donbass region.
"They are the eyes and ears of the international community on the ground" in monitoring compliance with the ceasefire along the contact line, said the German minister.
Vladimir Putin signed, on Monday night, a decree recognizing the self-proclaimed republics of Lugansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and mobilizing the Russian army to "maintain peace" in these pro-Russian separatist territories.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.

"Putin will go as far as he is allowed to reconstitute the borders of the empire"
He went to study in the Soviet Union in 1977 and was still living there at the time when the communist regime collapsed and the 15 republics decided to follow their path, including Russia. Journalist and historian, Jos√© Milhazes follows current affairs in the ex-Soviet space but also studies its past and has just published
The Shortest History of Russia: from the Slavs to Putin.
¬©¬†MIKHAIL KLIMENTYEV / RIA-NOVOSTI / AFP
Leon√≠dio Paulo Ferreira
23¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†00:22

His most recent book is titled The Shortest History of Russia: from the Slavs to Putin. How much he says about the Slavs to Putin is because the mark of the current president, in power for more than two decades, is already certain in Russian history?
Of course, Putin, for better or for worse, will go down in Russian history. This is inevitable. His actions will mark not only Russian history, but also European and universal history.
And are you saying on a horizon that could be many decades, even post-Putin?
Even post-Putin. Because we talk about Putin, but we also talk about Putinism. And the man who succeeds Putin in the Kremlin can continue this type of policy if everything continues to go as well as it has done so far.
When you say continue to run well, what does it mean? That despite moderate resources, compared to the resources of the Soviet Union, in geopolitical terms, Putin has gained position?
Putin, for now, has won. There is no doubt about that. Now the problem here is to see what bets he will make for today, tomorrow, the day after tomorrow, etc. For example, at this moment, it is already becoming, let's say, very likely that Russian troops will not stop in the area occupied by pro-Russian separatists in Ukraine, because the leaders of the separatist regions of Donetsk and Luhansk already say that Ukraine must abandon the entire territory of these two regions. This means that the war could increase in intensity.

Putin gave a very history-centered speech. He spoke of Catherine the Great, he spoke of Lenin. Do these arguments that Putin has that Ukraine, in essence, is a part of Russia, an artificial state, have any validity for him?
No. This is really a very dangerous revisionism of Russian history. It is very normal in the history of Russia, when a leader of this type comes to power, to begin to completely review the past in order to adapt it to his actions. In this sense we can, for example, look at Stalin, who did exactly the same. Rewrite history. Hence the Russians say that Russia has an unpredictable past.
But, for example, when it is said that Ukraine does not have a true linguistic unity, that the western half speaks Ukrainian and the east, Russian, and that even in elections there have always been differences in regional votes, is it true or not?
Those are facts. Now what Putin says is not true. Ukraine and Russia are different countries and different people. This is a distinction that is already clear and became especially clear after the annexation of Crimea. Unfortunately, the national character of Ukrainians is asserting itself in an anti-Russian, anti-Putin policy.
¬©¬†Pedro Rocha / Global Imagens
Do you say unfortunately because traditionally Ukrainians should be the true brothers of Russia, due to cultural proximity?
Ukraine and Russia could have excellent relations if it weren't for Putin's policy. Putin does not recognize Ukraine as a state. Furthermore, Putin, in his speech, said something very serious. He called into question all the states of the Soviet Union. With regard to borders and even the right to existence.
But you don't see Putin as nostalgic for communism, do you? See him as nostalgic for the great space controlled by Moscow.
Putin is a nationalist, he is nothing like a communist. This is more than evident. Putin is a nationalist defender of the Russian Empire and will go as far as he is allowed to reconstitute the borders of that empire.
Going to the more historical aspect that you address in your latest book, when talking about Kievan Rus as the first Russian State, still in the Middle Ages, is this really the birthplace of Russia?
To speak of the first Russian state, of Kievan Rus as such, is incorrect. Kievan Rus is the birthplace of three peoples. It's different.
Are you talking about Russians, Ukrainians and Belarusians?
Exactly.
It's the birthplace of the Slavic countries in that region, is that it?
Exactly. Kievan Rus is not Kievan Rus. It is the cradle of three peoples, who later, due to historical circumstances, were sometimes moving apart and sometimes getting closer, until we reached this situation.
Did today's Russia end up being born with the Grand Duchy of Muscovy as a response to the Mongols, the Golden Horde? In other words, what can Russia truly go back to? To the 14th century?
Yes. It's from there. And from there, for example, Ukraine also starts to appear. The latter is constantly fragmented between several countries and empires such as Poland, the Austro-Hungarian Empire and the Russian Empire. The same happens with Belarus, often divided between Poland and Russia. In other words, the three countries took different paths. Of course it can be said that the Soviet republics, many of them, were created and created artificially.
Especially in Stalin's time?
Yes yes. Because many of these republics did not exist as states. I'm not just talking about Ukraine. Ukraine still had some time as an independent state during the Civil War in Russia, between 1917 and 1922. Now, for example, in Central Asia there was no state, let's say, formed. There were people who lived there, but they were within the Russian Empire. For example, Kazakhstan is also made up of land that was ceded by Russia. Here we need to understand something. The borders within the Soviet Union were not borders, say, between states. They were administrative borders. And these borders, as I said, were created artificially. However, when the Soviet Union disintegrated, the various protagonists decided not to change the borders because when that was done it ended in wars. And very violent wars.
Let me just ask, in the case of Kazakhstan, all of northern Kazakhstan has Russian populations. But for Putin it is much more important to have all of Kazakhstan as an ally than to annex parcels of territory.
Yes, and exactly the same could be said about Ukraine.
"I always remember that joke that Russians tell. They ask Putin: how far do Russia's borders go? And Putin says: as far as I want."
Deep down, Putin doesn't want to accumulate Russophone confetti, does he want to have influence over countries?
Exactly. And for Putin, being friends is not enough. He wants Ukraine to depend entirely on Moscow.
In other words, when you talk about Finnishization, you think it's an analogy that doesn't make sense today because this Ukraine would be much more dependent than Finland was.
No. Of course not. Finnishization would be an intermediate step for Russia to move on to other things. I'm not saying that Russia is going to invade Ukraine right now. That's not what I'm saying yet. Although there is this fear, and it is a fear that I think is well-founded, that Russia will at least advance on the ground a few more kilometers in eastern Ukraine.
Using the boundaries of provinces with the name of republics?
For example. And then, if possible, go further.
Let me go back a little bit to the story you tell in the book. When we talk about Russia we talk a lot about the tsars, we talk a lot about the Bolsheviks. But Russia is also a great cultural colossus in Europe. And Europe sometimes forgets this facet of Russia. Do you agree?
Undoubtedly. It is one of the great problems of Europe and the United States, in this case, that they cannot find a formula, or rather, they have not managed to find a worthy formula for both parties, for coexistence after the fall of the Soviet Union. That was a huge mistake on the part of both the European Union and the United States.
That is, not to pull Russia into the western camp?
They pulled it off, but in their own way. They pulled, humiliating her.
And then Putin appears, then...
Of course. He appears as the savior. In the midst of all those humiliations that were taking place. In this sense, Boris Yeltsin was a catastrophe in Russian history.
When you talk about humiliations, do you include NATO's expansion to the east after the end of the Cold War?
I believe so, because there was no sense in this enlargement. It made no sense until the proclamation of independence of the two territories that belonged to Georgia, Abkhazia and South Ossetia, recognized by Russia
In 2008, after the Georgian War. Until now, Russia had never given any arguments for this?
Until then, normal relationships were established, and even good relationships. These relations continued despite everything until the annexation of Crimea in 2014. What caused this huge crisis was the occupation of Crimea and these areas of Ukraine.
But can't the overthrow of the pro-Russian president in Ukraine, which precedes the annexation of Crimea, also be seen by Moscow as a hostile act?
It can be seen. But this is not an argument for invading a neighboring country. That's where I think Putin made a big mistake. Of course, the European Union also made a blunder during the events on Maidan Square in 2014 when it served as an intermediary between the rebels and President Yanukovych to establish an agreement establishing early elections. And the European Union was not able to maintain this agreement. This agreement was violated by the rebels the following day and Yanukovych had to leave Moscow. That's a fact. Now we cannot conclude from this that Russia has the right to occupy parts of a country for these types of reasons. If not, I mean, we were in absolute hell. We have already seen, through other experiences, and I am talking, for example, about the experiences of the United States trying to change the political orientation of countries with armed interventions and which ended badly. Afghanistan and, for example, Iraq. This should prompt Putin to be careful and draw the appropriate conclusions.
Should Putin learn from the Americans' own mistakes?
Exactly. And don't make, don't repeat, the mistakes of the Americans themselves just because if the Americans can do it, we can too.
"Of course I don't want to imagine a war between NATO and Russia. That would be, let's say, the worst and darkest scenario."
Why - and I admit that my perception may be wrong - did Russia and Putin give up on the Baltics so easily? In other words, the Baltic countries joined NATO, despite significant Russian-speaking populations, especially in Estonia and Latvia and less so in Lithuania, and never truly tried to use them as a fifth column. Is it an awareness that these three were actually from another orbit, that joining NATO and the EU in 2004 had become irreversible?
At that time it was, now I don't know. After Putin's speech on Monday I no longer know what will happen.
Do you think the Baltics may no longer be an exception?
They can. It depends on how far Putin can go. Of course I don't want to imagine a war between NATO and Russia. That would be, let's say, the worst and darkest scenario.
There would be three NATO countries being threatened and NATO would already have to come to their defense.
Not anymore. And as we know, both sides have nuclear weapons. Hence this is a very complicated problem.
But in the speech there was no explicit reference to the Baltics. Are you interpreting?
Putin spoke about the republics of the former Soviet Union. Now he considers, as is true, that the three Baltic republics were part of the Soviet Union.
So you think it was explicit?
Of course. There is no doubt there. He has in view the Soviet Union that existed in 1991. Because the Baltic republics themselves were part of the Russian Empire. He talks about this empire with so much love and affection.
But, despite everything, they had that period of independence between the two world wars. Isn't it enough to make a difference?
Exactly. But I always remember that joke the Russians tell. They ask Putin: how far do Russia's borders go? And Putin responds: as far as I want.

translated_text:
World
Germany and France accuse Putin of "destroying" Minsk Agreements
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
19:48
0
Comments
Photo:¬†EPA/ALEXEI NIKOLSKY
The Foreign Ministers of Germany and France today accused Russia of having "destroyed" the Minsk Agreements by recognizing the two separatist territories in eastern Ukraine as independent, although they kept the window for dialogue open.
"The Minsk Agreements were destroyed unilaterally", highlighted the German Minister for Foreign Affairs, Annalena Baerbock, at a press conference in Berlin with her French counterpart, Yves Le Drian.
Baerbock stressed that Russian President Vladimir Putin signed these agreements, but that now "those papers have no value".
The German minister also denounced that the Russian head of state did not tell the truth during diplomatic contacts about Ukraine.
"In Germany we consider this to be lying," he said.
The person responsible for French diplomacy also said that Putin did not comply with his "public and private" statements, the last made in conversations with French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz.
Yves Le Drian assured, however, that "the hand [of diplomacy] is still extended" and that there is nothing worse than a "military confrontation".
"There is a forum for talks and it must continue to exist to continue working towards a peaceful solution", he stressed, referring to the Normandy Format, which brings together Germany, Ukraine, France and Russia around the implementation of the Minsk Agreements.
The Minsk Agreements were signed by Ukraine and pro-Russian separatists from Donetsk and Luhansk, in the Donbass region, and aimed to find a solution to the war between Kiev and Moscow-backed separatists, which began in 2014, shortly after Russia annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea.
Those responsible for German and French diplomacy warned of the need to be prepared for "the worst-case scenario", threatening a tougher sanctions package than the one announced yesterday by the European Union (EU).
"For a free and sovereign Ukraine, we are willing to suffer economic costs", assured Baerbock, recalling that Germany interrupted the certification process for the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline on Tuesday because peace in Europe is "priceless".
Both Foreign Ministers also declared themselves in favor of maintaining the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) observation mission in the Donbass region.
"They are the eyes and ears of the international community on the ground" in monitoring compliance with the ceasefire along the contact line, said the German minister.
Vladimir Putin signed, on Monday night, a decree recognizing the self-proclaimed republics of Lugansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and mobilizing the Russian army to "maintain peace" in these pro-Russian separatist territories.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.

translated_text:
"N
There are currently no Russian troops here. But in the event of Ukrainian aggression, this is possible. The documents we signed allow us to request this help," Denis Pushilin, leader of the separatist Donetsk region, said today during a press conference, quoted by the Russian agency Interfax.
On Tuesday, Russia's Federation Council (Senate) gave Russian President Vladimir Putin 'carte blanche' to openly intervene in the conflict in eastern Ukraine, authorizing him to use armed forces outside Russia's borders.
Putin has already clarified that the recognition of the self-proclaimed separatist republics of Donetsk and Luhansk, in eastern Ukraine, announced on Monday, includes the admission of territory in these two provinces that still remains under Kiev's control.
"The situation is such that the enlargement of the Donetsk and Luhansk people's republics to their historical borders can be resolved by itself, but we prefer it to be by peaceful means," Pushilin said.
The pro-Russian separatist leader assured that, at the moment, the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic is not considering that objective.
"We are not at that stage yet. We are at a stage where rival troops are on the line of contact and at any moment they can go on the offensive. We haven't resolved that yet," explained Pushilin.
The leaders of the two self-proclaimed separatist provinces, Donetsk and Lugansk, today denounced the intensification of attacks by Ukrainian forces against the cities they control.
According to Pushilin, for the first time in a long time, the city of Donetsk was hit by rocket fire, and pro-Russian separatists in Lugansk accused the Ukrainian army of attacking 12 locations with artillery.
The authorities in Kiev, in turn, hold the separatists responsible for violations of the ceasefire, which have increased considerably in recent days, at a time when Moscow ordered the withdrawal of all diplomatic personnel from Ukrainian territory and Ukraine ordered the mobilization of military reserves to reinforce the army.
Moscow-backed pro-Russian separatists from Donetsk and Luhansk went to war with Ukrainian authorities in 2014 following Russia's annexation of the Crimean peninsula.
Since then, the conflict has caused more than 14,000 deaths and displaced 1.5 million people, according to the United Nations.
