translated_text:
World
Donetsk separatist leader admits asking Russia for military help
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
19:44
0
Comments
Photo:¬†EPA/ZURAB KURTSIKIDZE
The leader of the self-proclaimed separatist republic of Donetsk, in eastern Ukraine, admitted today to asking Russia for military help in the event of Ukrainian aggression, taking advantage of Moscow's recognition of his territorial claims.
"At the moment there are no Russian troops here. But, in the event of a Ukrainian aggression, this is possible. The documents we signed allow us to request this help", said Denis Pushilin, leader of the separatist region of Donetsk, today during a press conference, quoted by the Russian agency Interfax.
On Tuesday, Russia's Federation Council (Senate) gave Russian President Vladimir Putin 'carte blanche' to openly intervene in the conflict in eastern Ukraine, authorizing him to use armed forces outside Russia's borders.
Putin has already clarified that the recognition of the self-proclaimed separatist republics of Donetsk and Luhansk, in eastern Ukraine, announced on Monday, includes the admission of territory in these two provinces that still remains under Kiev's control.
"The situation is such that the enlargement of the Donetsk and Luhansk people's republics to their historical borders can be resolved by itself, but we prefer it to be by peaceful means," Pushilin said.
The pro-Russian separatist leader assured that, at the moment, the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic is not considering that objective.
"We are not at that stage yet. We are at a stage where rival troops are on the line of contact and at any moment they can go on the offensive. We haven't resolved that yet," explained Pushilin.
The leaders of the two self-proclaimed separatist provinces, Donetsk and Lugansk, today denounced the intensification of attacks by Ukrainian forces against the cities they control.
According to Pushilin, for the first time in a long time, the city of Donetsk was hit by rocket fire, and pro-Russian separatists in Lugansk accused the Ukrainian army of attacking 12 locations with artillery.
The authorities in Kiev, in turn, hold the separatists responsible for violations of the ceasefire, which have increased considerably in recent days, at a time when Moscow ordered the withdrawal of all diplomatic personnel from Ukrainian territory and Ukraine ordered the mobilization of military reserves to reinforce the army.
Moscow-backed pro-Russian separatists from Donetsk and Luhansk went to war with Ukrainian authorities in 2014 following Russia's annexation of the Crimean peninsula.
Since then, the conflict has caused more than 14,000 deaths and displaced 1.5 million people, according to the United Nations.

translated_text:
O
Minister of Foreign Affairs admitted today that sanctions on Russia could go
"as far as necessary"
, ensuring that the
European Union and Allies are prepared to "place economic sanctions on Russia on a scale never seen before"
.
Speaking to Primeiro Jornal, on SIC, Augusto Santos Silva explained that this means "cutting off the means of international financing to the Russian State and seriously damaging Russia's position in matters of international trade".
"We hope not to get there but we are prepared to get there if necessary"
, he admitted.
According to the minister, the
sanctions approved yesterday
they are "the first response to a concrete act by Russia", the recognition of separatist territories in eastern Ukraine, which it classified as "illegal recognition".
Santos Silva highlighted that "the most important" of these sanctions "is the fact that we prohibit financing, from the European space, of the Russian State, including the Russian Central Bank", further highlighting that these sanctions were agreed between the European Union, the United States and the United Kingdom.
Regarding the possible application of penalties to Russian citizens in Portugal, the official emphasizes that "we do not have a national sanctions policy", but only a "European" one, but remembers, when asked about the case of
Roman Abramovich
, that, "if you have financial assets in Portugal, they are frozen" and that "the ban on travel within the European space applies".
Santos Silva also agreed with Joe Biden, who yesterday stated that
the "beginning of an invasion of Ukraine" is at stake
.
"We are at the beginning. Let's hope it doesn't continue", highlighted the Minister of Foreign Affairs at the Pa√ßo de Arcos station.
"We have to be prepared for all scenarios"
, he also stated, remembering that Vladimir Putin has not always fulfilled what he committed to.
Can the response be military?
"Russia knows, as we all know, that a military aggression against NATO territory represents a military aggression against all NATO states", recalled Augusto Santos Silva, explaining why it "depends" on whether the Allies' response to Russia can be military or not.
The minister justifies that NATO countries have put forces on alert and sent ships and combat planes to reinforce defense in Eastern Europe in a "defensive" way.
"NATO is a defensive alliance, not an offensive one", he explains. "To have its defense structure prepared, it practices what we call its policy of deterrence."
Regarding how Portugal participates in these efforts, Santos Silva reiterates that the "military plan is the one that is foreseen and approved by the Superior Council for National Defense".
"Our Air Force is involved in so-called reassurance measures in the northeast. It is currently engaged in Iceland," he began by saying, adding that this year "we are part of the highest-readiness segment of NATO's rapid response force. Thirdly, exercises are also planned on the eastern flank, in countries on the Black Sea."
On Monday, Vladimir Putin ordered the mobilization of the Russian Army for "peacekeeping" in the separatist territories in eastern Ukraine, which he recognized as independent.
Putin signed two decrees that ask the Russian Ministry of Defense that "the Russian Armed Forces assume peacekeeping functions on the territory" of the "people's republics" of Donetsk and Lugansk.
In 2014, Russia invaded eastern Ukraine and annexed the Crimean Peninsula, Ukrainian territory.
The war in eastern Ukraine between Kiev forces and separatist militias has so far killed more than 14,000 people, according to the United Nations.

The leader of the self-proclaimed separatist republic of Donetsk, in eastern Ukraine, admitted this Wednesday to asking Russia for military help in the event of Ukrainian aggression, taking advantage of Moscow's recognition of his territorial claims.
"At the moment there are no Russian troops here. But in the event of a Ukrainian aggression, this is possible. The documents we signed allow us to request this help," said Denis Pushilin, leader of the breakaway region of
Donetsk
, during a press conference, cited by the Russian agency Interfax.
On Tuesday, the Federation Council (Senate) of Russia gave 'carte blanche' to the Russian President,
Vladimir Putin
, to openly intervene in the conflict in eastern Ukraine, authorizing it to use armed forces outside Russia's borders.
Putin has already clarified that the recognition of the self-proclaimed separatist republics of
Donetsk
and of
Lugansk
, in eastern Ukraine, announced on Monday, includes the admission of territory in these two provinces that still remains under Kiev's control.
"The situation is such that the enlargement of the Donetsk and Luhansk people's republics to their historical borders can be resolved by itself, but we prefer it to be by peaceful means," Pushilin said.
The pro-Russian separatist leader assured that, at the moment, the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic is not considering that objective.
"We are not at that stage yet. We are at a stage where rival troops are on the line of contact and at any moment they can go on the offensive. We haven't resolved that yet," explained Pushilin.
PUB
The leaders of the two self-proclaimed separatist provinces, of
Donetsk
and of
Lugansk
, today denounced the intensification of attacks by Ukrainian forces against the cities they control.
According to Pushilin, for the first time in a long time, the city of
Donetsk
was hit by rocket fire, and pro-Russian separatists in
Lugansk
accused the Ukrainian army of attacking 12 locations with artillery.
The Kiev authorities, in turn, hold the separatists responsible for violations of the ceasefire, which have increased considerably in recent days, at a time when
Moscow
ordered the withdrawal of all diplomatic personnel from Ukrainian territory and that Ukraine ordered the mobilization of military reserves to reinforce the army.
Germany
and
France
accuse Putin of "destroying" Minsk Agreements
The German Foreign Ministers and
France
accused the
Russia
of having "destroyed" the Minsk Agreements by recognizing the two separatist territories in eastern Ukraine as independent, although keeping the window of dialogue open. "The Minsk Agreements were destroyed unilaterally", highlighted German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock at a press conference in
Berlin
alongside his French counterpart, Yves Le Drian.
Baerbock stressed that the Russian President,
Vladimir Putin
, signed these agreements, but now "those papers have no value".
The German minister also denounced that the Russian head of state did not tell the truth during diplomatic contacts about Ukraine. "In Germany we consider this to be lying," he said.
The person responsible for French diplomacy also said that Putin did not comply with his "public and private" statements, the last made in conversations with the French President
Emmanuel Macron
and the German Chancellor
Olaf Scholz
. Yves Le Drian assured, however, that "the hand [of diplomacy] is still extended" and that there is nothing worse than a "military confrontation". "There is a forum for conversations and it must continue to exist to continue working towards a peaceful solution", he highlighted, referring to the Normandy Format, which brings together
Germany
,
Ukraine
,
France
and
Russia
around the implementation of the Minsk Agreements.
The Minsk Agreements were signed by
Ukraine
and by the pro-Russian separatists of
Donetsk
and
Lugansk
, from the Donbass region, and aimed to find a solution to the war between Kiev and Moscow-backed separatists, which began in 2014, shortly after the
Russia
having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea.

The Kremlin said on Wednesday that rebels in eastern Ukraine asked Russian President Vladimir Putin for "help" to "repel aggression" by the Ukrainian army. The Pentagon indicates that additional Russian troops are on their way to Donetsk and Luhansk and France orders the immediate withdrawal of its citizens from Ukraine.

The West has warned that Russia could launch an attack on Ukraine at any time, with tens of thousands of troops stationed in the border regions.
Peskov said Putin received a letter from the leaders of the self-proclaimed Donetsk and Lugansk people's republics, which the Russian head of state recognized as independent earlier this week.

France also does not recommend traveling to Ukraine until further notice, with any travel to the border regions in the north and east of the country being discouraged.

The President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, had already determined the partial mobilization of military personnel in reserve.
The Ukrainian Armed Forces announced this Wednesday the mobilization of soldiers aged between 18 and 60 in reserve, to face the worsening of the military situation caused by Russia.
"The mobilization concerns reservists aged between 18 and 60", says a message from the Ukrainian land forces published this Wednesday on the social network Facebook. "The mobilization starts today (Wednesday). The maximum period of service is one year", he adds.
Ukraine has more than 200,000 reservists, in addition to around 250,000 members of the regular armed forces.
Refusal to attend this recruitment without a plausible reason may be subject to "administrative and criminal sanctions", the armed forces also say.
On Tuesday, the President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky had already determined the partial mobilization of military personnel in reserve to reinforce the Army, but ruled out the total mobilization of the armed forces.
PUB
Zelensky explained, in a communication to the country on Tuesday, that the decree applied only to Ukrainians in the operational reserve, mobilized to reinforce the Army that fights pro-Russian militias in the Donbass region and faces the Russian military threat on the border.
The National Police of Ukraine also announced this Wednesday that it will send additional forces to the conflict zone in the east of the country to ensure public order. The "number two" of the National Police, Oleksandr Fatsevich, also told the press that the additional agents will be sent before the end of the week.
Meanwhile, the Ukrainian Ministry of Foreign Affairs called on national citizens this Wednesday to leave Russia as quickly as possible in the face of the worsening military situation.
"The ministry recommends Ukrainian citizens to refrain from all trips to Russia and those already there should leave (Russian) territory immediately," Kiev diplomacy said in a statement.
Russia, which invaded Ukraine in 2014 and annexed the Crimean peninsula, recognized on Monday as independent the two separatist Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Luhansk, in the Donbass region, worsening the military situation in the region.
Moscow also approved the sending of Russian military personnel to the area.

President of Poland, Andrzej Duda, and President of Lithuania, Gitanas Nauseda, considered this Wednesday that Ukraine deserves the ‚Äústatus‚Äù of a candidate country for the European Union due to the country's ‚Äúcurrent security challenges‚Äù.

, he added.

, he stressed.

translated_text:
World
China accuses the United States of "throwing gasoline on the fire"
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
11:19
0
Comments
AFP Photo
China today accused the United States of "pouring gasoline on the fire" in the Ukraine crisis, for selling weapons to Kiev and "increasing tensions", a day after calling for restraint from everyone involved.
"The United States is selling weapons to Ukraine, increasing tensions, creating panic and even exaggerating the timetable for a war," said Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Hua Chunying.
"The key question is, what is the role of the United States in the current tensions in Ukraine", he asked, adding: "Someone who throws gasoline on the fire, while accusing others, is someone immoral and irresponsible".
On Monday, after Moscow recognized the two self-proclaimed pro-Russian separatist republics in eastern Ukraine, prompting Washington, the European Union (EU) and several other countries to impose sanctions against Russia, Hua called on actors in the Ukrainian crisis to "show restraint."
Fears of a military escalation at the door of the EU have reached a peak since Vladimir Putin recognized the independence of the territories of Donetsk and Lugansk.
Regarding Western sanctions, one of the most dramatic measures was announced by Berlin, which froze the gigantic Nord Stream II gas pipeline project, which was supposed to bring more Russian natural gas to Germany.
US President Joe Biden announced a "first tranche" of sanctions aimed at preventing Moscow from accessing Western funds to pay its sovereign debt.
Asked about the possibility of China imposing sanctions on Russia, Hua said "this has never been an effective way to solve problems."
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.
That year, the war began in Donbass between pro-Russian separatists supported by Moscow and the Ukrainian army, which has since caused more than 14,000 deaths and 1.5 million people displaced, according to the UN.

more sanctions must be imposed, we must receive more weapons and diplomatic actions must be multiplied", said Dmitro Kuleba, speaking to journalists, after speaking before the UN General Assembly, which today held a session specifically dedicated to the crisis in Ukraine.
The head of Ukrainian diplomacy repeated several times that the sanctions announced on Tuesday by the United States, the European Union (EU), the United Kingdom and other countries "are appreciated, but are not sufficient."
Dmitro Kuleba warned that one should not wait for Russian missiles to fall on Ukrainian soil to impose new sanctions, arguing that they "should have a dissuasive effect".
For the ruler, Ukraine has the right to equip itself with "defensive weapons" that he hopes will not have to be used.
And he recalled that the President of the United States, Joe Biden, and the Secretaries of State, Antony Blinken, and Defense, Lloyd Austin, have committed to continuing to supply weapons and impose sanctions if Russia does not change its attitude.
Kuleba also criticized countries that limit themselves to generic appeals for peace, considering that in this way "a message is sent that this type of behavior is tolerated", giving Japan as an example.
The situation in eastern Ukraine "is not just a threat against Europe, but against the world order", he warned.
"Russia must be put under pressure. It must be made to feel that the sanctions are not bearable," he said.
Kuleba also revealed that he has repeatedly asked to talk or meet with his Russian counterpart, Sergei Lavrov, but to no avail because until now there has always been "some pretext".
Russia has been criticized for breaking the Minsk Agreements, which aimed to find a solution to the war between Kiev and Moscow-backed separatists that began in 2014, shortly after Russia annexed Ukraine's Crimean peninsula.
In 2014, separatists declared the independence of the Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Lugansk, which Russia recognized on Monday, in a decision seen by the West as a sign of a new invasion of Ukraine.
After the reconnaissance, Putin authorized the Russian army to send a "peacekeeping" force to Donetsk and Luhansk, raising fears of a Russian offensive in eastern Ukraine.
The war in Donbass has caused more than 14,000 deaths and displaced 1.5 million people since 2014, according to the United Nations.

Os parlamentos dos autoproclamados estados de Donetsk e Lugansk ratificam os tratados do seu reconhecimento pela R√∫ssia.

translated_text:
Chronology
Confrontation between Russia and the West since Ukraine's independence
JN/Agencies
Today¬†at¬†4pm
Facebook
Twitter
Share
Comment
Topics
World
Russia-Ukraine crisis
Confrontation between Russia and the West since Ukraine's independence
Comment
Facebook
Twitter
WhatsApp
Share
Related
Russia promises "strong response" to US sanctions
Ukraine target of large-scale cyberattack: affected banks and ministries
Kiev demands "security guarantees" from the West and Moscow
Ukraine will enter a state of emergency
"Greatest security threat since World War II". US cancels meeting with Russian minister
JN/Agencies
Today¬†at¬†4pm
Facebook
Twitter
Share
Comment
Ukraine has been at the center of disagreements between Russia and the West practically since it declared independence from Moscow in 1991, after joining the Soviet Union.
Amputated from part of its territory in 2014, when Russia annexed the Crimean peninsula, Ukraine once again faces the possibility of an invasion in the Donbass region, where the war it is waging with pro-Russian separatists has already caused more than 14,000 deaths in eight years.
Russian President Vladimir Putin recognized, on Monday, the self-proclaimed people's republics of Donetsk and Luhansk, in Donbass, and authorized the Russian army to send a "peacekeeping" force to those territories in eastern Ukraine.
The decision was taken after months of high tension between Russia and the West, after Moscow concentrated tens of thousands of troops on the borders with neighboring Ukraine, but is part of a dispute that began three decades ago.
Chronology of the crisis over Ukraine, based on various sources:
1991
Leonid Kravchuk, leader of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic, declares independence from Moscow.
PUB
2004
Pro-Russian candidate Viktor Yanukovich is declared President, but allegations of electoral fraud spark a protest movement, known as the Orange Revolution, and force a new vote, which results in the election of pro-Western Viktor Yushchenko.
2005
Yushchenko promises to take Ukraine out of Moscow's orbit, towards the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and the European Union (EU).
2008
At the Bucharest summit, NATO agrees to the accession of Ukraine and Georgia.
"NATO welcomes the Euro-Atlantic aspirations of Ukraine and Georgia to join NATO. We agreed today that these countries will become members of NATO", reads the summit declaration.
With Jos√© Manuel Dur√£o Barroso as president of the European Commission (2004-2014), the EU and Ukraine begin talks on an association agreement and declare that "Ukraine's future is in Europe".
2010
- Viktor Yanukovych defeats Yulia Tymoshenko in the presidential election and becomes head of state.
2013
- A week before the signing of the agreement with the EU, in November, Yanukovich suspends the process and announces that Ukraine prefers to join Russia in the Eurasian Customs Union.
The decision generates a wave of protests from supporters of European integration.
2014
The protests, known as the "Euromaidan" movement, as they are centered on Maidan Square in Kiev, turn violent. Dozens of protesters are killed.
In February, Yanukovych fled the country when he was facing impeachment proceedings and ended up taking refuge in Russia.
In March, Russia annexes the Crimean peninsula in southeastern Ukraine.
In April, separatists with support from Moscow declare the independence of the republics of Luhansk and Donetsk, in the eastern Ukrainian region of Donbass, starting a war that causes 14,000 deaths in eight years.
On May 25, businessman Petro Poroshenko wins the presidential elections with a pro-Western agenda.
On June 6, the leaders of Ukraine, Russia, France and Germany create a dialogue platform to try to resolve the war in Donbass, known as the Normandy Format.
On July 17, a Russian missile destroyed a Malaysian civilian plane while it was flying over the Donetsk region. Three high-ranking members of the pro-Russian separatist forces in Donbass are accused of the deaths of 298 people on flight MH17.
2017
The association agreement between Ukraine and the EU comes into force.
2019
The Orthodox Church of Ukraine formally separates from the Russian Orthodox Church after 332 years.
2019
Volodymyr Zelenskyy, President of Ukraine
Photo:¬†Matt Dunham / POOL / AFP
Former actor and comedian Volodymyr Zelenskyy is elected President of the Republic on April 21, and promises to put an end to the conflict in eastern Ukraine.
2021
Zelenskyy appeals to the new President of the United States of America (USA), Joe Biden, so that Ukraine can join NATO.
Spring 2021
Russia gathers troops near the borders of Ukraine, which it justifies with training exercises.
November 2021
Ukraine accuses Russia of having concentrated 100,000 troops and heavy weapons on its borders, prompting a request for an explanation from the US to Moscow. Putin accuses the West of exacerbating tensions by "delivering modern weapons to Kiev and conducting provocative military exercises" in the Black Sea.
December 7, 2021
During a virtual summit, Biden warns that Russia will be subject to harsh economic sanctions if it invades Ukraine and Putin demands that the neighboring country not become a member of NATO.
December 17, 2021
Moscow discloses its demands to the West: treaties prohibiting Ukraine and Georgia from joining NATO and the establishment of military bases in the east, and the withdrawal of allied troops from Romania and Bulgaria, in a return to the situation before 1997.
January 3, 2022
Biden assures Zelensky that the US will respond ‚Äúdecisively‚Äù if Russia invades Ukraine.
January 10, 2022
The heads of US diplomacy, Antony Blinken, and Russia, Sergei Lavrov, meet in Geneva (Switzerland), but to no avail.
January 24, 2022
NATO puts forces on alert and reinforces military presence in eastern Europe. The US puts 8,500 military personnel on alert.
Some Western countries begin to withdraw non-essential personnel from embassies in Kiev.
January 26, 2022
The USA and NATO announce that they responded to Russian demands without revealing details. They reaffirm, however, that NATO maintains an "open door" policy, which means the rejection of Russia's claim to prevent Ukraine from joining.
Washington offers a "principled and pragmatic assessment" of Russian security concerns through diplomatic channels.
January 27, 2022
Biden warns that Russia could invade Ukraine in February.
China tells the US that Moscow's "legitimate security concerns" must be "taken seriously".
January 28, 2022
Vladimir Putin
Photo:¬†EPA/ALEKSEY NIKOLSKYI/SPUTNIK/KREMLIN POOL / POOL
Putin says Russia's main security demands have not been met, but says he is willing to continue talks with the West.
February 4, 2022
China and Russia denounce US influence and the role of Western military alliances in Europe and Asia, following talks between the leaders of the two countries in Beijing.
February 8, 2022
French President Emmanuel Macron, whose country presides over the EU Council, meets with Putin in Moscow and announces that Russia has agreed not to worsen the situation.
The Kremlin denies any agreement to ease the crisis.
February 10, 2022
Russian and Belarusian troops begin 10 days of combat exercises near the Belarusian border with Ukraine.
February 11, 2022
US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan warns that the invasion of Ukraine could occur "at any time".
The US orders an additional 3,000 troops to be sent to Poland, while several countries, including Portugal, call on their citizens to leave Ukraine.
February 12, 2022
Macron and Biden speak to Putin by phone, but the parties limit themselves to reaffirming their positions.
Dutch airline KLM suspends flights to Ukraine and the use of Ukrainian airspace.
February 13, 2022
Kiev approves funding to help airlines maintain operations in Ukraine, after insurance companies withdraw coverage.
February 14, 2022
Zelensky receives German Chancellor Olaf Scholz and argues that Ukraine's inclusion in NATO would guarantee the country's security.
In a conversation broadcast on Russian television, Lavrov admits to Putin the possibility of an agreement with the West, which raises some optimism among some Western leaders.
UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres expresses "deep concern" about the situation in contacts with Lavrov and the head of Ukrainian diplomacy, Dmytro Kuleba.
The USA announces the transfer of its embassy in Kiev to the city of Lviv, in western Ukraine, close to the border with Poland.
The finance ministers of the G7 (Germany, United Kingdom, USA, France, Canada, Italy and Japan) announce that they are ready to impose sanctions with "massive and immediate consequences for the Russian economy".
February 15, 2022
A few hours before a Putin-Scholz meeting, Russia announced the withdrawal of some of its troops as they had finished the exercises in which they were participating, but without indicating numbers.
The Russian Parliament (Duma) asks Putin to recognize the independence of Donetsk and Lugansk, which Moscow has supported in the war against Kiev since 2014.
NATO says such recognition would be a "flagrant violation" of Ukraine's sovereignty and integrity, and the US threatens economic sanctions.
Putin receives Scholz and announces his readiness for talks with the US and NATO on missile limits and military transparency.
Scholz argues that lasting security in Europe "is only possible with Russia" and cannot be achieved against Moscow.
Ukrainian institutions, including the Ministry of Defense and the armed forces, suffer a cyber attack, with suspicions pointing to Moscow, which denies any involvement.
Biden says the US presented Russia with "concrete ideas" about security in Europe, namely new arms control and stability maintenance measures.
February 16, 2022
The day begins with Ukrainian authorities saying that nothing unexpected happened in the country, after information released in the USA that the Russian attack would begin that morning.
NATO denounces that Russia continues to reinforce its military presence on its borders with Ukraine.
The Kremlin welcomes Biden's availability for "serious talks" about security in Europe and announces that Putin will refuse the Duma's request for recognition of Donetsk and Lugansk so as not to violate the Minsk Agreements.
February 17, 2022
The US accuses Russia of having sent an additional 7,000 troops to the Ukrainian border and warns that a Russian provocation in the Donbass could justify an attack against Ukraine.
The EU demands from Moscow "visible and concrete evidence" of the reduction of military force on the Ukrainian border and expresses concern about the intensification of fighting in the Donbass.
February 18, 2022
Ukrainian forces and Donbass separatists accuse each other of new attacks. Kiev says it has no intention of attacking Donetsk and Lugansk.
Portuguese Prime Minister, Ant√≥nio Costa, argues that the EU must "explore diplomatic channels to the limit" and that sanctions against Moscow must be considered in a "limit situation".
Separatists in eastern Ukraine announce an operation to evacuate civilians to Russia, which has issued passports to 720,000 local residents in recent months. The US says the operation aims to prepare a military attack from Moscow.
Macron calls for an end to clashes in eastern Ukraine and a return to dialogue.
Blinken says the intensification of fighting in Donbass is a Russian act to justify an attack on Ukraine.
Washington accuses Moscow of having positioned up to 190,000 troops on Ukraine's borders, both on the Russian and Belarusian sides.
NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg says that Moscow has promoted the "largest concentration of military forces" in Europe since the Cold War.
Scholz says that Ukraine's integration into NATO is not on the agenda "in the coming days, months or years", so Russia has no reason to increase tension.
The EU threatens to impose sanctions on Belarus if it supports Moscow in an invasion of Ukraine.
Biden says Putin has decided to move forward with the invasion "in the coming days."
February 19, 2022
Putin, accompanied by Belarusian leader Alexander Lukashenko, oversees strategic military exercises with ballistic and cruise missiles.
China calls for Russia's concerns about Ukraine to be respected.
Zelensky calls for a clear timetable for Ukraine's membership of NATO and a UN Security Council meeting.
Kiev announces the death of two Ukrainian soldiers in clashes with separatists in Donbass.
Portugal advises its citizens to leave Ukraine "while they can do so through normal means".
The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) announces a record of more than 1,500 ceasefire violations in Donbas in 24 hours.
Zelensky assures Macron that Ukraine will not respond to Russian provocations and that he remains available for dialogue with Moscow.
January 20, 2022
Boris Johnson says Russia is planning "the biggest war in Europe since 1945".
The Portuguese embassy in Kiev appeals to all Portuguese in Ukraine who have not yet been contacted to urgently report their whereabouts.
The Minister of Foreign Affairs, Augusto Santos Silva, announces that 40 Portuguese have already left Ukraine and that around two hundred remain in the country.
The French Presidency says that Putin promised Macron to work towards a ceasefire in the Donbass and assured that he will withdraw troops from Belarus.
Moscow and Minsk decide, however, that the Russian military remains in Belarus, despite having completed joint exercises. NATO considers the decision as an indicator of action against Ukraine.
Paris announces that Putin and Biden have agreed "in principle" to hold a summit on security in Europe that was proposed to them by Macron.
February 21, 2022
The Kremlin says it is premature to talk about a Putin-Biden summit.
The EU formally adopts emergency aid for Ukraine of 1,200 million euros.
Poland admits to welcoming up to a million people if there is war in neighboring Ukraine and Hungary says it fears a wave of refugees. Germany and Austria announce preparations to provide humanitarian aid to those fleeing the war.
The Russian army says it has killed five "saboteurs" from Ukraine on its territory, but Kiev denies any action in Russia.
Putin says that Russia faces "a very serious threat" and that the West uses Ukraine as an "instrument of confrontation" with Moscow.
The leaders of the self-proclaimed people's republics of Donetsk and Luhansk, in Donbass, ask Putin to recognize them as independent states.
Ukraine announces the death of two soldiers and a civilian in bombings by separatist forces in the Donetsk region.
Putin signs the decrees in which Russia recognizes the independence of Donetsk and Lugansk, and orders the Russian army to send a "peacekeeping" mission to those territories in eastern Ukraine.
The decision is condemned by most Western countries, NATO accuses Moscow of creating a pretext to invade Ukraine and Kiev calls for an urgent meeting of the UN Security Council.
Ant√≥nio Guterres says that this is a "violation of the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine", and that Russia's action "is incompatible with the principles of the United Nations Charter", which is not "'an √† la carte menu'".
Ant√≥nio Costa considers that the Russian decision violates the Minsk Agreements and expresses Portugal's solidarity with Ukraine.
February 22, 2022
Zelensky asks the West for "clear and effective support measures", assures that the Ukrainians "will not give up a single part of the country" and holds Russia responsible for everything that happens.
At an urgent meeting of the UN Security Council, China calls for moderation, Russia says it "does not want a bloodbath in the Donbass", the US finds it ridiculous for Putin to talk about a "peacekeeping force" and Ukraine demands that Moscow revoke the recognition of separatist Ukrainian territories.
Putin's decision causes a general fall in world stock markets, oil exceeds 99 dollars, the highest value since 2014, and the price of natural gas increases by 7%.
The parliaments of the self-proclaimed states of Donetsk and Luhansk ratify the treaties of their recognition by Russia.
Zelensky warns that the recognition of Donetsk and Lugansk aims to create a legal basis for new Russian aggression, demands the immediate suspension of the Russian-German gas pipeline Nord Stream 2 and admits a cut in diplomatic relations with Moscow.
Moscow warns Kiev that a severing of diplomatic relations is "an extremely undesirable scenario".
China, which also has a dispute with the West over Taiwan, expresses concern about the situation and calls for restraint, arguing that "the legitimate security concerns of any country must be respected."
Scholz says he has taken steps to stop certification of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, in a decision welcomed by the EU and the US.
Russia assures that it will continue to supply gas to European countries. Other gas exporting countries warn they have limited capacity to quickly increase supplies to Europe.
The Kremlin clarifies that it recognized Donetsk and Lugansk with the borders they had in 2014, when they proclaimed independence, which includes territory since recovered by Ukraine.
NATO says it expects a large-scale attack from Russia in Ukraine and has put its rapid reaction force on alert to defend allied countries.
Ukraine asks Western allies for more weapons to defend itself against Russia and guarantees of future EU membership.
Portuguese parties condemn Russia, with the exception of the PCP, which criticizes NATO and the USA.
EU, US and UK announce sanctions against Russian interests.
Moscow says it will withdraw its diplomats from Kiev because the Ukrainian authorities do not guarantee their safety.
Blinken cancels a meeting with Lavrov, scheduled for Thursday in Geneva, claiming that it no longer makes sense with the "start of the invasion".
JN/Agencies

translated_text:
A
Stripped of part of its territory in 2014, when Russia annexed the Crimean peninsula, Ukraine is once again facing the possibility of an invasion in the Donbass region, where the war it is waging with pro-Russian separatists has already caused more than 14,000 deaths in eight years.
Russian President Vladimir Putin recognized, on Monday, the self-proclaimed people's republics of Donetsk and Luhansk, in Donbass, and authorized the Russian army to send a "peacekeeping" force to those territories in eastern Ukraine.
The decision was taken after months of high tension between Russia and the West, after Moscow concentrated tens of thousands of troops on the borders with neighboring Ukraine, but is part of a dispute that began three decades ago.
Chronology of the crisis over Ukraine, based on various sources:
1991
- Leonid Kravchuk, leader of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic, declares independence from Moscow.
2004
- Pro-Russian candidate Viktor Yanukovich is declared President, but allegations of electoral fraud spark a protest movement, known as the Orange Revolution, and force a new vote, which results in the election of pro-Western Viktor Yushchenko.
2005
- Yushchenko promises to take Ukraine out of Moscow's orbit, towards the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and the European Union (EU).
2008
- At the Bucharest summit, NATO agrees to the accession of Ukraine and Georgia.
"NATO welcomes the Euro-Atlantic aspirations of Ukraine and Georgia to join NATO. We agreed today that these countries will become members of NATO", reads the summit declaration.
- With Jos√© Manuel Dur√£o Barroso as president of the European Commission (2004-2014), the EU and Ukraine begin talks on an association agreement and declare that "Ukraine's future is in Europe".
2010
- Viktor Yanukovych defeats Yulia Tymoshenko in the presidential election and becomes head of state.
2013
- A week before the signing of the agreement with the EU, in November, Yanukovich suspends the process and announces that Ukraine prefers to join Russia in the Eurasian Customs Union.
The decision generates a wave of protests from supporters of European integration.
2014
- The protests, known as the "Euromaidan" movement, as they are centered on Maidan Square in Kiev, turn violent. Dozens of protesters are killed.
- In February, Yanukovych fled the country when he was facing impeachment proceedings and ended up taking refuge in Russia.
- In March, Russia annexes the Crimean peninsula, in southeastern Ukraine.
- In April, separatists with support from Moscow declare the independence of the republics of Lugansk and Donetsk, in the eastern Ukrainian region of Donbass, starting a war that causes 14,000 deaths in eight years.
- On May 25, businessman Petro Poroshenko wins the presidential elections with a pro-Western agenda.
- On June 6, the leaders of Ukraine, Russia, France and Germany create a dialogue platform to try to resolve the war in Donbass, known as the Normandy Format.
- On July 17, a Russian missile destroyed a Malaysian civilian plane while it was flying over the Donetsk region. Three high-ranking members of the pro-Russian separatist forces in Donbass are accused of the deaths of 298 people on flight MH17.
2017
- The association agreement between Ukraine and the EU comes into force.
2019
- The Orthodox Church of Ukraine formally separates from the Russian Orthodox Church, after 332 years.
- Former actor and comedian Volodymyr Zelenskyy is elected President of the Republic on April 21, and promises to put an end to the conflict in eastern Ukraine.
2021
- Zelenskyy appeals to the new President of the United States of America (USA), Joe Biden, so that Ukraine can join NATO.
Spring 2021
- Russia gathers troops near the borders of Ukraine, which it justifies with training exercises.
November 2021
- Ukraine accuses Russia of having concentrated 100,000 troops and heavy weapons on its borders, prompting a request for an explanation from the US to Moscow.
- Putin accuses the West of exacerbating tensions by "delivering modern weapons to Kiev and conducting provocative military exercises" in the Black Sea.
December 7, 2021
- During a virtual summit, Biden warns that Russia will be subject to harsh economic sanctions if it invades Ukraine and Putin demands that the neighboring country not become a member of NATO.
December 17, 2021
- Moscow announces its demands to the West: treaties prohibiting Ukraine and Georgia from joining NATO and the establishment of military bases in the east, and the withdrawal of allied troops from Romania and Bulgaria, in a return to the situation before 1997.
January 3, 2022
- Biden assures Zelensky that the US will respond "decisively" if Russia invades Ukraine.
January 10, 2022
- The heads of US diplomacy, Antony Blinken, and Russia, Sergei Lavrov, meet in Geneva (Switzerland), but without success.
January 24, 2022
- NATO puts forces on alert and reinforces military presence in eastern Europe. The US puts 8,500 military personnel on alert.
- Some Western countries begin to withdraw non-essential personnel from embassies in Kiev.
January 26, 2022
- USA and NATO announce that they responded to Russian demands without revealing details. They reaffirm, however, that NATO maintains an "open door" policy, which means the rejection of Russia's claim to prevent Ukraine from joining.
Washington offers a "principled and pragmatic assessment" of Russian security concerns through diplomatic channels.
January 27, 2022
- Biden warns that Russia could invade Ukraine in February.
- China tells the US that Moscow's "legitimate security concerns" must be "taken seriously".
January 28, 2022
- Putin says that Russia's main security demands have not been met, but says he is willing to continue talks with the West.
February 4, 2022
- China and Russia denounce US influence and the role of Western military alliances in Europe and Asia, following talks between the leaders of the two countries in Beijing.
February 8, 2022
- French President Emmanuel Macron, whose country presides over the EU Council, meets with Putin in Moscow and announces that Russia has agreed not to worsen the situation.
The Kremlin denies any agreement to ease the crisis.
February 10, 2022
- Russian and Belarusian troops begin 10 days of combat exercises near the Belarusian border with Ukraine.
February 11, 2022
- US national security advisor Jake Sullivan warns that the invasion of Ukraine could occur "at any time".
- The US orders the deployment of an additional 3,000 troops to Poland, while several countries, including Portugal, call on their citizens to leave Ukraine.
February 12, 2022
- Macron and Biden speak to Putin by phone, but the parties limit themselves to reaffirming their positions.
- Dutch airline KLM suspends flights to Ukraine and the use of Ukrainian airspace.
February 13, 2022
- Kiev approves funding to help airlines maintain operations in Ukraine, after insurance companies withdraw coverage.
February 14, 2022
- Zelensky receives German Chancellor Olaf Scholz and argues that Ukraine's inclusion in NATO would guarantee the country's security.
- In a conversation broadcast on Russian television, Lavrov admits to Putin the possibility of an agreement with the West, which raises some optimism among some Western leaders.
- UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres expresses "deep concern" about the situation in contacts with Lavrov and the head of Ukrainian diplomacy, Dmytro Kuleba.
- The USA announces the transfer of its embassy in Kiev to the city of Lviv, in western Ukraine, close to the border with Poland.
- Finance ministers of the G7 (Germany, United Kingdom, USA, France, Canada, Italy and Japan) announce that they are ready to impose sanctions with "massive and immediate consequences for the Russian economy".
February 15, 2022
- A few hours before a Putin-Scholz meeting, Russia announced the withdrawal of some of its troops because they had finished the exercises in which they participated, but without indicating numbers.
- The Russian Parliament (Duma) asks Putin to recognize the independence of Donetsk and Luhansk, which Moscow has supported in the war against Kiev since 2014.
NATO says such recognition would be a "flagrant violation" of Ukraine's sovereignty and integrity, and the US threatens economic sanctions.
- Putin receives Scholz and announces he is ready for talks with the US and NATO on missile limits and military transparency.
Scholz argues that lasting security in Europe "is only possible with Russia" and cannot be achieved against Moscow.
- Ukrainian institutions, including the Ministry of Defense and the armed forces, suffer a cyber attack, with suspicions pointing to Moscow, which denies any involvement.
- Biden says that the US presented Russia with "concrete ideas" about security in Europe, namely new measures to control arms and maintain stability.
February 16, 2022
- The day begins with Ukrainian authorities saying that nothing unexpected happened in the country, after information released in the USA that the Russian attack would begin this morning.
- NATO denounces that Russia continues to reinforce its military presence on its borders with Ukraine.
- The Kremlin welcomes Biden's availability for "serious talks" about security in Europe and announces that Putin will refuse the Duma's request for recognition of Donetsk and Luhansk so as not to violate the Minsk Agreements.
February 17, 2022
- The US accuses Russia of having sent an additional 7,000 troops to the Ukrainian border and warns that a Russian provocation in the Donbass could justify an attack against Ukraine.
- The EU demands from Moscow "visible and concrete evidence" of the reduction of military force on the Ukrainian border and expresses concern about the intensification of fighting in Donbass.
February 18, 2022
- Ukrainian forces and Donbass separatists accuse each other of new attacks. Kiev says it has no intention of attacking Donetsk and Lugansk.
- The Portuguese Prime Minister, Ant√≥nio Costa, argues that the EU must "explore diplomatic channels to the limit" and that sanctions against Moscow must be considered in a "limit situation".
- Separatists in eastern Ukraine announce an operation to evacuate civilians to Russia, which has issued passports to 720,000 local residents in recent months. The US says the operation aims to prepare a military attack from Moscow.
- Macron calls for an end to clashes in eastern Ukraine and a return to dialogue.
Blinken says the intensification of fighting in Donbass is a Russian act to justify an attack on Ukraine.
- Washington accuses Moscow of having positioned up to 190,000 troops on Ukraine's borders, both on the Russian and Belarusian sides.
NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg says that Moscow has promoted the "largest concentration of military forces" in Europe since the Cold War.
- Scholz says that Ukraine's integration into NATO is not on the agenda "in the coming days, months or years", so Russia has no reason to increase tension.
- The EU threatens to impose sanctions on Belarus if it supports Moscow in an invasion of Ukraine.
- Biden says Putin decided to move forward with the invasion "in the next few days."
February 19, 2022
- Putin, accompanied by Belarusian leader Alexander Lukashenko, supervises strategic military exercises with ballistic and cruise missiles.
- China calls for Russia's concerns about Ukraine to be respected.
- Zelensky calls for a clear timetable for Ukraine's accession to NATO and a meeting of the UN Security Council.
- Kiev announces the death of two Ukrainian soldiers in clashes with separatists in Donbass.
- Portugal advises its citizens to leave Ukraine "while they can do so through normal means".
- The Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) announces a record of more than 1,500 ceasefire violations in Donbas in 24 hours.
- Zelensky assures Macron that Ukraine will not respond to Russian provocations and that he remains available for dialogue with Moscow.
January 20, 2022
- Boris Johnson says Russia is planning "the biggest war in Europe since 1945".
- The Portuguese embassy in Kiev appeals to all Portuguese in Ukraine who have not yet been contacted to urgently report their whereabouts.
The Minister of Foreign Affairs, Augusto Santos Silva, announces that 40 Portuguese have already left Ukraine and that around two hundred remain in the country.
- The French Presidency says that Putin promised Macron to work towards a ceasefire in the Donbass and assured that he will withdraw troops from Belarus.
Moscow and Minsk decide, however, that the Russian military remains in Belarus, despite having completed joint exercises. NATO considers the decision as an indicator of action against Ukraine.
- Paris announces that Putin and Biden have agreed "in principle" to hold a summit on security in Europe that was proposed to them by Macron.
February 21, 2022
- The Kremlin says it is premature to talk about a Putin-Biden summit.
- The EU formally adopts emergency aid to Ukraine of 1,200 million euros.
- Poland admits to welcoming up to a million people if there is war in neighboring Ukraine and Hungary says it fears a wave of refugees. Germany and Austria announce preparations to provide humanitarian aid to those fleeing the war.
- The Russian army claims to have killed five "saboteurs" from Ukraine on its territory, but Kiev denies any action in Russia.
- Putin says that Russia faces "a very serious threat" and that the West uses Ukraine as an "instrument of confrontation" with Moscow.
- The leaders of the self-proclaimed people's republics of Donetsk and Lugansk, in Donbass, ask Putin to recognize them as independent states.
- Ukraine announces the death of two soldiers and a civilian in bombings by separatist forces in the Donetsk region.
- Putin signs the decrees in which Russia recognizes the independence of Donetsk and Lugansk, and orders the Russian army to send a "peacekeeping" mission to those territories in eastern Ukraine.
- The decision is condemned by most Western countries, NATO accuses Moscow of creating a pretext to invade Ukraine and Kiev calls for an urgent meeting of the UN Security Council.
- Ant√≥nio Guterres says that this is a "violation of the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine", and that Russia's action "is incompatible with the principles of the United Nations Charter", which is not "'an √† la carte menu'".
- Ant√≥nio Costa considers that the Russian decision violates the Minsk Agreements and expresses Portugal's solidarity with Ukraine.
February 22, 2022
- Zelensky asks the West for "clear and effective support measures", assures that the Ukrainians "will not give up a single part of the country" and holds Russia responsible for everything that happens.
- At an urgent meeting of the UN Security Council, China calls for moderation, Russia says it "does not want a bloodbath in the Donbass", the USA finds it ridiculous for Putin to talk about a "peacekeeping force" and Ukraine demands that Moscow revoke the recognition of separatist Ukrainian territories.
- Putin's decision causes a general fall in world stock markets, oil exceeds 99 dollars, the highest value since 2014, and the price of natural gas increases by 7%.
- The parliaments of the self-proclaimed states of Donetsk and Lugansk ratify the treaties of their recognition by Russia.
- Zelensky warns that the recognition of Donetsk and Lugansk aims to create a legal basis for new Russian aggression, demands the immediate suspension of the Russian-German gas pipeline Nord Stream 2 and admits a cut in diplomatic relations with Moscow.
- Moscow warns Kiev that a break in diplomatic relations is "an extremely undesirable scenario."
- China, which also has a dispute with the West over Taiwan, expresses concern about the situation and calls for restraint, arguing that "the legitimate security concerns of any country must be respected."
- Scholz says he has taken steps to stop certification of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, in a decision welcomed by the EU and the US.
- Russia assures that it will continue to supply gas to European countries. Other gas exporting countries warn they have limited capacity to quickly increase supplies to Europe.
- The Kremlin clarifies that it recognized Donetsk and Lugansk with the borders they had in 2014, when they proclaimed independence, which includes territory since recovered by Ukraine.
- NATO says it expects a large-scale attack from Russia in Ukraine and has put its rapid reaction force on alert to defend allied countries.
- Ukraine asks Western allies for more weapons to defend itself against Russia and guarantees of future EU membership.
- Portuguese parties condemn Russia, with the exception of the PCP, which criticizes NATO and the USA.
- EU, US and UK announce sanctions against Russian interests.
- Moscow says it will withdraw its diplomats from Kiev because the Ukrainian authorities do not guarantee their safety.
- Blinken cancels a meeting with Lavrov, scheduled for Thursday, in Geneva, claiming that it no longer makes sense with the "start of the invasion".

World
Ukrainian government calls for more sanctions on Russia and weapons to contain threat of attack
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
22:07
0
Comments
Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmitro Kuleba today called on the international community to strengthen sanctions on Russia and make weapons available for Ukraine to defend itself against Russian aggression.
"More sanctions must be imposed, we must receive more weapons and diplomatic actions must be multiplied", said Dmitro Kuleba, speaking to journalists, after speaking before the UN General Assembly, which held a session specifically dedicated to the crisis in Ukraine today.
The head of Ukrainian diplomacy repeated several times that the sanctions announced on Tuesday by the United States, the European Union (EU), the United Kingdom and other countries "are appreciated, but are not sufficient."
Dmitro Kuleba warned that one should not wait for Russian missiles to fall on Ukrainian soil to impose new sanctions, arguing that they "should have a dissuasive effect".
For the ruler, Ukraine has the right to equip itself with "defensive weapons" that he hopes will not have to be used.
And he recalled that the President of the United States, Joe Biden, and the Secretaries of State, Antony Blinken, and Defense, Lloyd Austin, have committed to continuing to supply weapons and impose sanctions if Russia does not change its attitude.
Kuleba also criticized countries that limit themselves to generic appeals for peace, considering that in this way "a message is sent that this type of behavior is tolerated", giving Japan as an example.
The situation in eastern Ukraine "is not just a threat against Europe, but against the world order", he warned.
"Russia must be put under pressure. It must be made to feel that the sanctions are not bearable," he said.
Kuleba also revealed that he has repeatedly asked to talk or meet with his Russian counterpart, Sergei Lavrov, but to no avail because until now there has always been "some pretext".
Russia has been criticized for breaking the Minsk Agreements, which aimed to find a solution to the war between Kiev and Moscow-backed separatists that began in 2014, shortly after Russia annexed Ukraine's Crimean peninsula.
In 2014, separatists declared the independence of the Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Lugansk, which Russia recognized on Monday, in a decision seen by the West as a sign of a new invasion of Ukraine.
After the reconnaissance, Putin authorized the Russian army to send a "peacekeeping" force to Donetsk and Luhansk, raising fears of a Russian offensive in eastern Ukraine.
The war in Donbass has caused more than 14,000 deaths and displaced 1.5 million people since 2014, according to the United Nations.

United States Secretary of State, Antony Blinken, announced today the cancellation of the meeting with his Russian counterpart, Sergey Lavrov, which was scheduled for Thursday in Geneva (Switzerland).
Presidents of the USA, Joe Bide (left), and of Russia, Vladimir Putin
¬©¬†Jim WATSON and Grigory DUKOR/AFP

"Now that we see the beginning of the invasion and Russia has made clear its total rejection of diplomacy, there is no point in continuing with this meeting," said Antony Blinken, after Moscow recognized the independence of the Ukrainian separatist regions.
The US Secretary of State was speaking at a press conference in Washington with the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Ukraine, Dmytro Kuleba.
The head of US diplomacy emphasized that if anything, such as an attack on Ukraine, including the capital, Kiev, it would avoid "the worst-case scenario."
Therefore, he stated that Washington remains "open" to diplomacy, but first, he indicated, Russia must show that it is "serious, and in the last 24 hours it has shown exactly the opposite."

The United States will continue to provide "assistance" to Ukraine on economic and security issues, following Russia's recognition of the self-proclaimed republics on Ukrainian territory, US President Joe Biden assured today.
After a reception with the Ukrainian Foreign Minister, the White House said in a statement that Biden reaffirmed before Minister Dmitro Kuleba the "commitment of the United States to defending the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine".
At the meeting, Joe Biden detailed to the head of Ukrainian diplomacy the sanctions that Washington decided to impose, following the announcement by the President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, of the recognition of the independence of the pro-Russian separatist territories of Donetsk and Lugansk, in the Donbass region and the authorization by the Russian Senate to send Russian troops abroad.
"[Joe Biden] also stated that the United States will continue to provide security assistance and macroeconomic support to help Ukraine", the note reads.
During his visit to Washington, Kuleba also met today with Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin.
The White House also stressed that Biden will respond "quickly and decisively" to any future Russian aggression against Ukraine and that he will do so in coordination with European allies.
The US President today announced a set of economic sanctions on Russian individuals, entities and banks, motivated by Russia's actions in eastern Ukraine, stating that the "start of an invasion of Ukraine" is at stake.
In a speech at the White House, without the right to questions, Biden announced sanctions on Russian elites and banks, and warned that Russia "will pay an even higher price if it continues its aggressions" against Kiev.
Joe Biden stated that the United States of America (USA) is immediately imposing a "total blockade" on two large Russian financial institutions and "comprehensive sanctions" on Russian debt.
"We are applying completely blocking sanctions to two major Russian financial institutions: VEB (one of the largest investment and development banks) and its military bank," said the US President.
Also today, the EU approved a "sanctions package" against Russia "unanimously", revealed the head of European diplomacy, Josep Borrell.
The United Kingdom also announced sanctions against three oligarchs known to be close to Russian President Vladimir Putin and against five Russian banks, while German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said today that Berlin has taken steps to stop the certification process for the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, for distributing Russian natural gas to Germany.
Russia on Monday recognized the two separatist Ukrainian territories in the Donbass region as independent and Moscow clarified today that the recognition refers to the territory occupied when the self-proclaimed republics proclaimed this status in 2014, which includes space currently held by Ukrainian forces.
Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
The Russian head of state stated today that the deployment of Russian troops to the Donbass region will depend on the situation on the ground, where clashes "continue" and tend to worsen.
The decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.

Ukraine's National Security and Defense Council this Wednesday asked the Ukrainian parliament to impose a state of emergency across the country, except in the separatist regions of Lugansk and Donetsk. "Depending on local circumstances, there may be stronger or milder measures to guarantee the security of our country. These are preventive measures, with the aim of preserving peace and calm in the country and so that the economy can continue to function"
, he added.

On the same day, the Russian president ordered the mobilization of his country's army for ‚Äúpeacekeeping‚Äù in those territories in eastern Ukraine.

translated_text:
O
Leader of the Labor Party, the main force of the British opposition, Keir Starmer, said there is concern across all parliamentary benches regarding the Government's strategy, stating that it could send "the wrong message" to Moscow.
"If the Prime Minister presents a full sanctions package, including excluding Russia from financial mechanisms such as SWIFT, and a ban on trading in Russian sovereign debt, it will have the full support of the House [of Commons]," he promised.
Boris Johnson responded, claiming to want to give Russian President Vladimir Putin the opportunity to back down, but assured that he is prepared to reinforce sanctions against Russian individuals and entities.
"There is more to come. We will stop Russia from raising sovereign debt, stop Russian companies from raising financing and stop Russian companies from moving funds in dollars and pounds on international markets", promised Boris Johnson, arguing that it is important to work together with international allies to pressure Putin at the same time.
In addition to sending more military material to Ukraine, Johnson also revealed that the Government asked regulator Ofcom (the entity that regulates the media in the United Kingdom) to review the license of the Russia Today television channel due to the risk of spreading "disinformation" about the crisis in Ukraine, but refused to intervene directly.
The leader of the Scottish National Party, Ian Blackford, also defended the need for "tougher and stronger sanctions", including a ban on Russian funding for political parties, denouncing that the Conservative Party benefited from more than two million pounds.
The opposition's concerns are shared by deputies from the Conservative Party, who considered on Tuesday that the sanctions announced by the prime minister fell short of expectations and did not go as far as those of their international partners.
The United Kingdom announced the asset freeze of five Russian banks (Rossiya, IS Bank, General Bank, Promsvyazbank and Black Sea Bank) and three Russian oligarchs (Gennady Timchenko, Boris Rotenberg and Igor Rotenberg), who are also banned from entering the country.
For its part, the European Union (EU) approved sanctions on Tuesday covering 27 individuals and entities and 350 members of the lower house of the Russian parliament (Duma).
Although Johnson has emphasized that sanctions can be tightened, critics of this strategy believe that stronger measures are needed to discourage Moscow from moving forward with a military invasion of Ukraine.
On the Conservative Party's parliamentary bench, Tobias Ellwood, said that "sanctions alone will not be enough" and warned that, if they are poorly designed, "they could contribute to Putin's plan to bring Russia closer and closer to China."
Conservative MP Mark Harper also called for assurances from Boris Johnson of "additional and stronger measures, even if President Putin does not take further action".
The British press is also critical of the Government, with the Daily Express asking Johnson to "punish Putin more now", while the Daily Mirror calls on the executive to "run dirty Russian money out of the UK now".
The Times daily says in an editorial that the package is "woefully inadequate".
The British Government stressed that this package was just the "first tranche" of measures and that it has more in preparation.
Foreign Minister Liz Truss wrote today in The Times newspaper that the United Kingdom "will use all the mechanisms at (its) disposal to stop (Putin)" and assured that "nothing is off the table".
"We have a long list of accomplices in the actions of the Russian leadership. If Russia refuses to withdraw troops, we can continue to increase pressure, targeting more banks, elites and important companies," he explained.
Russian President Vladimir Putin signed, on Monday night, a decree recognizing the separatist regions of Luhansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (east), and ordered the mobilization of Russian armed forces to those Ukrainian territories in a "peacekeeping" mission.
In 2014, Russia annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea, after the fall of the pro-Russian government in Kiev, and held a referendum on the return of the territory to the Russian Federation. Since then, Kiev has been in conflict with pro-Russian separatists in the east of the country.
The war in eastern Ukraine between Kiev forces and pro-Russian separatists has so far killed more than 14,000 people, according to the United Nations.

translated_text:
World
NGOs call for inclusion of vulnerable groups in potential evacuations
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
13:47
0
Comments
Photo EPA
The escalation of tension in Ukraine increases the risk of migration and displacement, the Norwegian Refugee Council and the World Organization Against Torture warned today, calling for vulnerable groups to be included in potential evacuation plans.
Children in specialized institutions, elderly people in nursing homes and inmates in prisons must be taken into consideration if plans are made to evacuate cities or regions, argued the World Organization Against Torture in a statement.
"If the armed conflict worsens, these people, who number in the tens of thousands, have no chance of reaching safe areas [alone]", warned the organization, noting that since the beginning of the conflict in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), in 2014, several attacks on prison institutions have been recorded.
The Norwegian Refugee Council warned, in turn, that "millions of people will suffer from a new conflict", after eight years of division of families living on the line that separates the territory controlled by the Ukrainian army from that dominated by pro-Russian militias.
"With increasing political and military tensions, thousands of families may remain separated indefinitely," said the secretary general of that humanitarian organization, Jan Egeland, who recently visited the conflict zone.
The organization recalled that the conflict in Ukraine is the one that affects the largest elderly population. According to the UN, 30% of the 2.9 million people in need of humanitarian aid are elderly.
The conflict that began in 2014, with the annexation of Crimea by Russia, caused 854,000 internally displaced people and made Ukraine the fifth country in the world with the most civilian victims caused by landmine explosions.
The tension that has increased in recent weeks in the region reached another level on Monday, when Russian President Vladimir Putin recognized the independence of the self-proclaimed separatist republics of Lugansk and Donetsk, in Donbass, and announced that Russian troops will be able to move to the Ukrainian region on a "peacekeeping" mission, which has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
In reaction, the United States, the European Union, the United Kingdom and several others announced sanctions against Russia, which continues to deny any warlike intentions towards Kiev.

translated_text:
Home
International
US cancels meeting with Russian Foreign Minister. "It doesn't make sense"
Antony Blinken, US Secretary of State, was scheduled to meet with his Russian counterpart on Thursday, in Geneva, Switzerland.
¬©¬†EPA/RONALD WITTEK
DN/Lusa
22¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†23:30
Facebook
Twitter
Comment
Share
Topics
USA
Russia
Ukraine
International
Related
politics
Portugal "well aligned" with the EU and NATO
ukraine
Zelensky mobilizes military reserves to reinforce the Army
pentagon
US will deploy 800 more troops to the Baltic countries
The United States Secretary of State, Antony Blinken, announced this Tuesday the cancellation of the meeting with his Russian counterpart, Sergey Lavrov, which was scheduled for Thursday in Geneva (Switzerland).
"Now that we see the beginning of the invasion and Russia has made clear its total rejection of diplomacy, it makes no sense to continue with this meeting," said Antony Blinken, after
Moscow has recognized the independence of the Ukrainian separatist regions.
The US Secretary of State was speaking at a press conference in Washington with the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Ukraine, Dmytro Kuleba.
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
.
@SecBlinken
cancels meeting with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov: "Now that we see the invasion is beginning and Russia has made clear its wholesale rejection of diplomacy it does not make sense to go forward that meeting at this time."
pic.twitter.com/GmEFVZTJQ3
- CSPAN (@cspan)
February 22, 2022
The head of US diplomacy emphasized that if anything, such as an attack on Ukraine, including the capital, Kiev, it would avoid "the worst-case scenario."
Therefore, he stated that the US remains "open" to diplomacy, but first, he indicated, Russia must show that it is "serious, and in the last 24 hours it has shown exactly the opposite."
The United States will continue to provide "assistance" to Ukraine on economic and security issues, following Russia's recognition of the self-proclaimed republics on Ukrainian territory, US President Joe Biden assured today.
After a reception with the Ukrainian Foreign Minister, the White House said in a statement that Biden reaffirmed before Minister Dmitro Kuleba the "commitment of the United States to defending the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine".
Today,
@POTUS
met with Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba of Ukraine to reaffirm the United States" commitment to Ukraine"s sovereignty and territorial integrity, and to update him on the U.S. response to Russia"s actions.
pic.twitter.com/OyHMyBkKfi
- The White House (@WhiteHouse)
February 22, 2022
At the meeting, Joe Biden detailed to the head of Ukrainian diplomacy the sanctions that Washington decided to impose, following the announcement by the President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, of the recognition of the independence of the pro-Russian separatist territories of Donetsk and Lugansk, in the Donbass region and the authorization by the Russian Senate to send Russian troops abroad.
"[Joe Biden] also stated that the United States will continue to provide security assistance and macroeconomic support to help Ukraine,"
can be read in the note.
During his visit to Washington, Kuleba also met today with Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin.
The White House also stressed that Biden will respond "quickly and decisively" to any future Russian aggression against Ukraine and that he will do so in coordination with European allies.
The US president announced this Tuesday a set of economic sanctions on Russian individuals, entities and banks,
motivated by Russia's actions in eastern Ukraine, stating that the "start of an invasion of Ukraine" is at stake.
In a speech at the White House, without the right to questions, Biden announced sanctions on Russian elites and banks, and warned that Russia "will pay an even higher price if it continues its aggressions" against Kiev.
Joe Biden stated that the United States of America (USA) is immediately imposing a "total blockade" on two large Russian financial institutions and "comprehensive sanctions" on Russian debt.
"We are applying completely blocking sanctions to two major Russian financial institutions: VEB (one of the largest investment and development banks) and its military bank," said the US President.
Also today, the EU approved a "sanctions package" against Russia "unanimously", revealed the head of European diplomacy, Josep Borrell.
The United Kingdom also announced sanctions against three oligarchs known to be close to Russian President Vladimir Putin and against five Russian banks, while German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said today that Berlin has taken steps to stop the certification process for the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, for distributing Russian natural gas to Germany.
Russia on Monday recognized the two separatist Ukrainian territories in the Donbass region as independent and Moscow clarified today that the recognition refers to the territory occupied when the self-proclaimed republics proclaimed this status in 2014, which includes space currently held by Ukrainian forces.
Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
The Russian head of state stated today that the deployment of Russian troops to the Donbass region will depend on the situation on the ground, where clashes "continue" and tend to worsen.
The decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.

Putin denies imperial ambition but US says "invasion" has already begun
After the green light for sending military personnel to Donetsk and Luhansk, the Russian president argued that the "best solution" to end the crisis would be for Ukraine to give up membership in NATO. EU and US announced more sanctions, with Biden guaranteeing that they will be tougher than those of 2014.
Russian tanks in the Rostov region, near the border with Ukraine. The US and NATO claim that the "invasion" has already begun, but Putin guarantees that sending troops to Donetsk and Luhansk will depend on the "situation on the ground".
¬©¬†EPA/YURI KOCHETKOV
Helena Tecedeiro
22¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†22:18
Facebook
Twitter
Comment
Share
Topics
Ukraine
International
Russia
Vladimir Putin
Related
USA
Biden announces sanctions against the ‚Äústart of an invasion of Ukraine‚Äù
Russia
UN Charter "is not an '√† la carte' menu" and Russia must apply it in its entirety, says Guterres
politics
Portugal "well aligned" with the EU and NATO
"The Minsk agreements no longer exist", declared Vladimir Putin minutes after the Russian Senate authorized the sending of troops out of Russia. Signed in 2015 by Russia and Ukraine, under Franco-German mediation, these agreements aimed to return the separatist regions of Donetsk and Lugansk, with a Russian-speaking majority, to Ukrainian sovereignty, which a year earlier had self-proclaimed their independence. Now, by recognizing this independence, on Monday, what Putin did was, in practice, tear up these agreements.
Authorized to send troops - which it itself guarantees have the mission of "keeping the peace" - to the Donbass, where Donetsk and Luhansk are located, the US believes that this is nothing more than the "beginning of a Russian invasion" of Ukraine, as the undersecretary for national security, Jonathan Finer, assured on CNN. "An invasion is an invasion and that's what is happening", he stressed.
At the end of the afternoon (2:30 pm in Washington), President Joe Biden also denounced the ‚Äúinvasion‚Äù. And he announced new sanctions against Moscow, "far beyond the steps we and our allies implemented in 2014" following Russia's annexation of Crimea. For now, the US targets are two Russian financial institutions and its military bank, Russian sovereign debt - with the Kremlin prevented from going to Western markets to finance itself - as well as some members of the Russian elite and their families. Biden also announced the sending of more US soldiers and military equipment to the Baltic countries. And he assured that he will continue to supply "defensive" weapons to Kiev.
Close
