News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
In a short statement from the White House, Biden stated that Putin is committed to "gaining more territory by force", stressing: "To put it simply: Russia has announced that it is conquering a large chunk of Ukraine." And he recalled that the Russian president admitted sending troops "beyond the two areas he recognized, reclaiming large areas currently under the jurisdiction of the Ukrainian government."
The US warning was echoed in the words of NATO's secretary general. "Everything indicates that Russia continues to plan a large-scale operation to attack Ukraine," he said, before adding: "We have seen the military build-up... We have seen more and more troops coming out of barracks and preparing for combat. And we see the continued provocations in Donbass and the various false flag operations in which [the Russians] try to create a pretext for an attack. And, of course, we saw last night that more Russian troops have moved into Donbass, into parts of Donetsk and Luhansk".
Stoltenberg explained that NATO has more than a hundred planes and more than 120 warships on alert in locations ranging from the Arctic Circle to the Mediterranean. "NATO will have to respond if we see aggressive acts by Russia, but we continue to fight for dialogue, for de-escalation and we believe it is important to speak out." And he said: "It's never too late" for Russia not to attack, despite Putin's "threatening rhetoric."
The Russian president, for his part, assured that "the best solution" to end the crisis surrounding Ukraine would be for Kiev to give up its ambition to join NATO.
¬©¬†EPA/ALEXEI NIKOLSKY / KREMLIN / SPUTNIK /
During a meeting in the Kremlin with Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliev, Putin further said: "We anticipated that there would be speculation that Russia was preparing to reconstitute an empire." But, he said, "that's not the reality." According to the Russian president, after the fall of the Soviet Union, Russia "recognized the new realities and worked very actively to strengthen" cooperation with other ex-Soviet countries, citing the neighbors of Azerbaijan and Kazakhstan as examples. Ukraine is in a "different situation" because "the territory of this country is used by third countries to threaten Russia", he argued.
The Russian president accused Kiev of being "armed to the teeth" and assured that when President Volodymyr Zelensky regretted Ukraine's decision, in 1994, to give up its military arsenal he had "targeted Russia". Putin defended the "demilitarization" of Ukraine, remembering that it receives weapons from its Western allies. If Western countries "fill the Kiev authorities with modern weapons (...), then the most important point is (...) the demilitarization of today's Ukraine," he argued.
Regarding the sending of troops to the separatist regions, he assured that it will depend on the situation on the ground, where the clashes, he said, "continue" and tend to worsen
Ukraine asks for more weapons
Refusing to cede any of its territory, Ukraine has asked Western countries to provide it with more weapons against Russia. "We will mobilize the whole world to get everything we need to reinforce our defensive capacity," said Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba. In recent weeks, several countries have sent military equipment to Ukraine, including Javelin anti-tank missiles from Estonia and Stringer surface-to-air missiles from Latvia. Kiev is also using Turkish-made Bayrakhtar drones for reconnaissance. Ukraine also received weapons from the US as part of a $200 million defensive package approved by Biden in December.
For now, Germany announced its intention to increase the contingent of soldiers deployed at a NATO base in Lithuania, on the same day that Hungary announced the mobilization of military units in the border areas with Ukraine.
On another "front", Russia announced the soon withdrawal of its diplomatic team in Ukraine to "protect their lives".
A response on sanctions
To Putin's historic-war speech on Monday and the green light for Moscow to send troops to Donetsk and Luhansk, the West's response came in sanctions. The European Union unanimously approved a package of sanctions that aims to "harm hard" on Russian authorities. Specifically, the sanctions cover 27 individuals and entities and 350 members of the lower house of the Russian parliament (the Duma). Regarding financial sanctions, restrictions on the EU's economic relations with the two separatist regions are expected, as well as the freezing of assets of two private Russian banks.
Outside the EU since Brexit, the United Kingdom also announced sanctions against three oligarchs close to Putin - Gennady Timchenko, Boris Rotenberg and his nephew, Igor Rotenberg - and against five Russian banks. And Prime Minister Boris Johnson promised not to stop there, guaranteeing, following what the USA and NATO did, that Moscow's recognition of the independence of the separatists is "a pretext for a large-scale offensive".
Suspended gas pipeline
One of the biggest consequences of the rise in tension with Moscow is a possible crisis in gas supplies in Europe. In this chapter, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced the suspension of authorization for the controversial Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, which connects Russia to Germany.
Nord Stream 2 was completed in November but has not yet come into operation. His project provoked economic and geopolitical doubts from the beginning. Nord Stream 2 extends 1230 kilometers under the Baltic Sea and has a capacity of 55 billion cubic meters of gas per year. It follows the same route as Nord Stream 1, which has been operating since 2012. The gas pipeline avoids Ukrainian territory and will increase the supply of Russian gas to Europe, at a time when its own production is falling.
Promoted by the Russian giant Gazprom and budgeted at more than 10 billion euros, Nord Stream 2 has always been criticized by Ukraine - which fears losing the revenue it obtains from the transit of Russian gas -, by the USA - which fears Europe's increased dependence on Russian gas which could dissuade it from buying American shale gas - and even by European countries such as Poland or the Baltics - which fear seeing Europe bow down to Russian ambitions.
Despite the concerns, Moscow said it was committed to honoring contracts with European countries and continuing to export natural gas "without interruption". Faced with tension in Ukraine, the EU is negotiating with countries such as Qatar, Algeria and Egypt for the supply of liquefied natural gas (LNG) to alleviate possible cuts in Russian supplies. But Qatar's Energy Minister Saad al-Kaabi declared it "impossible" to replace in the short term the volume of gas that Russia supplies to Europe - up to 40% of the EU's imports.

translated_text:
World
US provides economic and security assistance
Lusa Agency
Feb 22, 2022
21:50
0
Comments
Photo EPA
The United States will continue to provide "assistance" to Ukraine on economic and security issues, following Russia's recognition of the self-proclaimed republics on Ukrainian territory, US President Joe Biden assured today.
After a reception with the Ukrainian Foreign Minister, the White House said in a statement that Biden reaffirmed before Minister Dmitro Kuleba the "commitment of the United States to defending the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine".
At the meeting, Joe Biden detailed to the head of Ukrainian diplomacy the sanctions that Washington decided to impose, following the announcement by the President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, of the recognition of the independence of the pro-Russian separatist territories of Donetsk and Lugansk, in the Donbass region and the authorization by the Russian Senate to send Russian troops abroad.
"[Joe Biden] also stated that the United States will continue to provide security assistance and macroeconomic support to help Ukraine", the note reads.
During his visit to Washington, Kuleba also met today with Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin.
The White House also stressed that Biden will respond "quickly and decisively" to any future Russian aggression against Ukraine and that he will do so in coordination with European allies.
The US President today announced a set of economic sanctions on Russian individuals, entities and banks, motivated by Russia's actions in eastern Ukraine, stating that the "start of an invasion of Ukraine" is at stake.
In a speech at the White House, without the right to questions, Biden announced sanctions on Russian elites and banks, and warned that Russia "will pay an even higher price if it continues its aggressions" against Kiev.
Joe Biden stated that the United States of America (USA) is immediately imposing a "total blockade" on two large Russian financial institutions and "comprehensive sanctions" on Russian debt.
"We are applying completely blocking sanctions to two major Russian financial institutions: VEB (one of the largest investment and development banks) and its military bank," said the US President.
Also today, the EU approved a "sanctions package" against Russia "unanimously", revealed the head of European diplomacy, Josep Borrell.
The United Kingdom also announced sanctions against three oligarchs known to be close to Russian President Vladimir Putin and against five Russian banks, while German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said today that Berlin has taken steps to stop the certification process for the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, for distributing Russian natural gas to Germany.
Russia on Monday recognized the two separatist Ukrainian territories in the Donbass region as independent and Moscow clarified today that the recognition refers to the territory occupied when the self-proclaimed republics proclaimed this status in 2014, which includes space currently held by Ukrainian forces.
Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
The Russian head of state stated today that the deployment of Russian troops to the Donbass region will depend on the situation on the ground, where clashes "continue" and tend to worsen.
The decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.

translated_text:
Home
International
UK considers total invasion of Ukraine "highly likely"
The Ukrainian government has already asked its citizens to leave Russia immediately, claiming that the threat of a Russian invasion could complicate the functioning of consular services.
¬©¬†EPA/YURI KOCHETKOV
DN/Lusa
23¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†09:02
Facebook
Twitter
Comment
Share
Topics
Ukraine
International
United Kingdom
Russia
Related
ukraine
Ukraine: Putin says Russian interests are "non-negotiable" but is "open to dialogue"
ukraine
Ukrainian Armed Forces order mobilization of reservists between 18 and 60 years old
ukraine
Russia says US-imposed sanctions will get ‚Äústrong response‚Äù
British Foreign Minister Liz Truss considered this Wednesday "highly likely" that the Russian president would want to invade Ukraine and take Kiev, after recognizing the separatist territories in eastern Ukraine.
"We think it is highly likely that he [Vladimir Putin] will carry out the plan for a total invasion of Ukraine"
, said Liz Truss on the Sky News television channel.
In an article published in the newspaper
The Times
, the minister indicated that the United Kingdom does not rule out anything and will apply more sanctions if Russia proceeds with a "full invasion" of Ukraine, although she acknowledged that there is no evidence of this yet.
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
Liz Truss highlighted that the sanctions announced on Tuesday by the British Government are the first, but that the executive has a list of more banks, oligarchs and companies applying measures.
Ukraine asks its citizens to leave Russia
At the same time, Ukraine asked its citizens to leave Russia immediately, claiming that the threat of a Russian invasion could complicate the functioning of consular services.
"Because of the escalation of Russian aggression against Ukraine, which may lead to a substantial reduction in possible consular assistance in Russia, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs urges citizens of Ukraine to refrain from traveling to Russia and for those in Russia to leave its territory immediately."
, said the ministry, in a statement.
The President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, ordered this Tuesday the partial mobilization of military personnel in reserve to reinforce the Army, but ruled out for now a total mobilization of the armed forces, given the increase in the Russian threat.
Zelensky explained, in a communication to the country, that this new decree applies only to Ukrainians in the operational reserve, mobilized to reinforce the Army that fights pro-Russian militias in the Donbass region and faces the Russian military threat on the border.
The Ukrainian head of state added that, normally, this reserve is activated during periods of hostilities and that it covers "a special period of time", without specifying.
"We need to quickly add additional personnel to the Ukrainian Army and other military formations"
, he stressed.
The Armed Forces of Ukraine comprise around 250,000 soldiers and have a reserve of around 140,000, reports the Associated Press (AP).
Zelensky also announced that military exercises will take place "soon" for the Ukrainians in reserve status who will make up the territorial defense units.
The President of Ukraine ordered an increase in the number of members in these units to two million, which includes hunters and forest guards.
But he assured that, for now, "there is no need for general mobilization" among the population, something that pro-Russian separatists did on Saturday with all men of legal age.
In his address to the nation, Zelensky also ruled out a large-scale war with Russia and, in this way, rejected the imposition of martial law in the Donbas region, despite Moscow's recognition of the independence of the two self-proclaimed separatist republics, Donetsk and Lugansk.
The President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
Zelensky, who considered Moscow's recognition a violation of his country's territorial integrity, did not go ahead with breaking diplomatic relations with Russia, despite having already admitted this scenario and being pressured to do so.
The Ukrainian head of state also regretted that the West did not adopt preventive sanctions against Russia before Moscow recognized the separatist republics.
But he welcomed the decisions already imposed, such as Germany's suspension of the certification of the controversial Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, which was supposed to transport Russian gas directly to Germany, without passing through Ukrainian territory.
Biden talks about "beginning of invasion"
This Tuesday, US President Joe Biden stated that the "start of an invasion of Ukraine" was at stake, which is why he announced economic sanctions on Russian individuals, entities and banks.
In a speech at the White House, without the right to questions, Biden announced sanctions on Russian elites and banks, and warned that Russia "will pay an even higher price if it continues its aggressions" against Kiev.
Joe Biden stated that the United States of America (USA) is immediately imposing a "total blockade" on two large Russian financial institutions and "comprehensive sanctions" on Russian debt.
"We are applying completely blocking sanctions to two major Russian financial institutions: VEB (one of the largest investment and development banks) and its military bank"
, said the President of the USA.
"This means we cut off the Russian government from Western funding. It can no longer obtain capital from the West and it cannot trade its new debt on our markets or European markets."
, announced the president, stressing that Russian elites and their families will not escape economic sanctions.
Biden considered that the actions of his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin, are a "flagrant violation of international law" and require a firm response from the international community. However, he stressed that there was still time "to avoid the worst-case scenario that will inflict enormous suffering on millions of people."
"There is no doubt that Russia is the aggressor, so we are aware of the challenges we face"
, Biden said at the White House.
"We will judge Russia by its actions, not its words. And whatever Russia does next, we are ready to respond with unity, clarity and conviction. I hope the diplomatic path remains open."
, appealed.
One day after the Russian President recognized the independence of "republics" within Ukrainian territory, the American head of state also announced that he authorized the reinforcement of American troops already present in the Baltic countries, without providing numbers.
"Let me be clear, these are completely defensive moves on our part, we have no intention of fighting Russia."
, Biden said, noting that the US and its allies will defend "every inch of NATO territory" in the event of aggression.
Putin still open to dialogue
The President of Russia insisted this Wednesday that the country's interests and security are "non-negotiable", praised Russian military capabilities, but said he was ready to find "diplomatic solutions" to the Ukraine crisis.
"Our country is always open to direct and honest dialogue to find diplomatic solutions to the most complex problems", said Vladimir Putin, in a televised speech broadcast on the occasion of Defender of the Fatherland Day.
"However, the interests and security of our citizens are non-negotiable for us," Putin added.
Russia has demanded guarantees from Western countries that Ukraine will never become a member of NATO.
By citing as threats to Russia "the loosening of the arms control system" and "NATO's military activities", Putin argued, once again, that Russian concerns remain "unanswered".
Russia on Monday recognized the two breakaway Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Luhansk as independent.
On Tuesday, Russian authorities clarified that the recognition refers to territory occupied when the self-proclaimed republics announced this status in 2014, which includes space currently held by Ukrainian forces.
Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
In 2014, Russia invaded eastern Ukraine and annexed the Crimean Peninsula, Ukrainian territory.

Ukraine will declare a state of emergency
Feb 23, 2022 - 11:04 ‚Ä¢
Writing
Kiev government calls on its citizens to leave Russia quickly.
A+
/
A-
Photo: Alisa Yakubovych/EPA
Ukraine is preparing to declare a state of emergency that should initially last 30 days.
The BBC reports that following a meeting of the country's national security council, senior security official Oleksiy Danilov said a state of emergency would be imposed on all regions except Donetsk and Luhansk, where Ukrainian forces are already at war with Russian-backed separatists.
The measure will have to be approved by the Ukrainian parliament.
Meanwhile, the Ukrainian Ministry of Foreign Affairs has already called on Ukrainians, estimated at three million people, to leave Russia as soon as possible in the face of the worsening military situation.
"The ministry recommends Ukrainian citizens to refrain from all trips to Russia and those already there should leave (Russian) territory immediately," Kiev's diplomats said in a statement released this Wednesday.

"Ukraine needs clear and concrete security guarantees immediately," Zelensky said during a press conference in Kiev with his counterparts from Poland, Andrzej Duda, and Lithuania, Gitanas Nauseda.
"I believe that Russia must be among the countries that must give these clear security guarantees," Zelensky added, recalling that he has repeatedly offered to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin in an attempt to find a solution to the crisis.
Zelensky took advantage of the press conference to thank his Polish and Lithuanian counterparts for their support and deliveries of weapons and military equipment to Kiev, saying that what is at stake, on his country's borders, is the future of Europe.
"We are united in the belief that the future of European security is being played out now, here, in Ukraine", explained Zelensky, referring to the escalation of tension in the Donbass region, after, on Monday, Moscow announced the recognition of the self-proclaimed separatist republics of Donetsk and Luhansk.
Ukraine's Security Council today called for a state of emergency to be established in the country amid growing fears of an imminent Russian invasion.
Kiev had already announced today the mobilization of reservists, aged 18 to 60, and called on its citizens to leave Russia, a country that it accuses, together with the West, of preparing a large-scale offensive on Ukrainian territory.

Russia withdraws diplomatic personnel from Ukraine
Kiev has been the scene of some anti-Russian protests
Photo:¬†EPA
23¬†February¬†2022

Comment

Twitter

Comment
Russia began this Wednesday to withdraw staff from all its diplomatic missions in Ukraine for security reasons, a source at the Russian embassy in Kiev told the official TASS news agency.
"The withdrawal of personnel has already started," the diplomatic source told TASS, cited by the Spanish agency EFE.
The decision was announced by the Russian Foreign Ministry on Monday, the day President Vladimir Putin recognized the independence of the breakaway territories of Donetsk and Luhansk, in eastern Ukraine.
"The Russian government has decided, in order to guarantee its life and safety, to withdraw personnel from its missions in Ukraine, which will come into force as soon as possible," the ministry said.
The ministry led by Sergei Lavrov argued that since 2014, the headquarters of Russia's diplomatic missions in Ukraine have suffered "numerous attacks" without any reaction from Ukrainian authorities.
The announcement of the start of the withdrawal of Russian diplomatic personnel from Ukraine was made shortly after the Kiev Government urged Ukrainian citizens to immediately leave Russian territory.
"In connection with the intensification of Russian aggression against Ukraine (...), the Ministry of Foreign Affairs recommends that Ukrainian citizens refrain from traveling to the Russian Federation and those in this country to immediately leave their territory," Ukrainian diplomacy said in a statement.
PUB
Kiev believes that under the current circumstances of military tensions with Russia, its ability to provide consular assistance to Ukrainians in Russia may be limited.
"We emphasize that ignoring these recommendations will significantly complicate the adequate protection of Ukrainian citizens in the Russian Federation," the Ukrainian Foreign Ministry added.
Following the recognition of the independence of Donetsk and Luhansk, Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those territories in eastern Ukraine on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
Ukraine ordered the mobilization of military reserves to reinforce the army.
Ukraine has more than 200,000 reservists, in addition to around 250,000 members of the regular armed forces.
In view of the worsening situation, the Security Council of Ukraine today recommended that a state of emergency be established in the country.
"The Ukrainian parliament must ratify this decision within the next 48 hours," said the secretary of the National Security and Defense Council, Oleksi√Ø Danilov, after a meeting of this structure.
JN/Agencies

translated_text:
World
Russia withdraws its diplomatic staff from Ukraine for security reasons
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
13:30
0
Comments
Photo EPA
Russia today began withdrawing personnel from all its diplomatic missions in Ukraine for security reasons, a source at the Russian embassy in Kiev told the official TASS news agency.
"The withdrawal of personnel has already started," the diplomatic source told TASS, cited by the Spanish agency EFE.
The decision was announced by the Russian Foreign Ministry on Monday, the day President Vladimir Putin recognized the independence of the breakaway territories of Donetsk and Luhansk, in eastern Ukraine.
"The Russian government has decided, in order to guarantee its life and safety, to withdraw personnel from its missions in Ukraine, which will come into force as soon as possible," the ministry said.
The ministry led by Sergei Lavrov argued that since 2014, the headquarters of Russia's diplomatic missions in Ukraine have suffered "numerous attacks" without any reaction from Ukrainian authorities.
The announcement of the start of the withdrawal of Russian diplomatic personnel from Ukraine was made shortly after the Kiev Government urged Ukrainian citizens to immediately leave Russian territory.
"In connection with the intensification of Russian aggression against Ukraine (...), the Ministry of Foreign Affairs recommends that Ukrainian citizens refrain from traveling to the Russian Federation and those in this country to immediately leave their territory," Ukrainian diplomacy said in a statement.
Kiev believes that under the current circumstances of military tensions with Russia, its ability to provide consular assistance to Ukrainians in Russia may be limited.
"We emphasize that ignoring these recommendations will significantly complicate the adequate protection of Ukrainian citizens in the Russian Federation," the Ukrainian Foreign Ministry added.
Following the recognition of the independence of Donetsk and Luhansk, Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those territories in eastern Ukraine on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
Ukraine ordered the mobilization of military reserves to reinforce the army.
Ukraine has more than 200,000 reservists, in addition to around 250,000 members of the regular armed forces.
In view of the worsening situation, the Security Council of Ukraine today recommended that a state of emergency be established in the country.
"The Ukrainian parliament must ratify this decision within the next 48 hours," said the secretary of the National Security and Defense Council, Oleksi√Ø Danilov, after a meeting of this structure.

Crisis
UK sanctions on Russian banks involve asset freezes
Photo:¬†AFP
23¬†February¬†2022
JN/Agencies
23¬†February¬†2022¬†at¬†00:14
Facebook
Twitter
Share
Comment
Topics
World
Russia-Ukraine crisis
Russia
United Kingdom
UK sanctions on Russian banks involve asset freezes
Comment
Facebook
Twitter
WhatsApp
Share
JN/Agencies
23¬†February¬†2022¬†at¬†00:14
Facebook
Twitter
Share
Comment
The United Kingdom explained Tuesday that the sanctions announced against five Russian banks, in retaliation for Moscow's recognition of Ukrainian breakaway regions, involve freezing assets, according to independent Russian news agency Interfax.
"The assets of the five Russian banks involved in financing the Russian occupation are frozen, the decision comes into force immediately," said British Foreign Secretary Liz Truss.
Related
Crisis.
Russian interests are "non-negotiable", but Putin is "open to dialogue"
The banks covered are IS Bank, General Bank, Black Sea Bank, which operate in Crimea, and Promsvyazbank (
Moscow
) and Rossiya Bank (St. Petersburg).
Promsvyazbank is state-owned through the Federal Property Management Agency, being the main creditor of Russia's defense industry sector and serving 70% of the state defense order.
The amount of financing provided to defense industry enterprises is 1.5 billion rubles, said the leader of Promsvyazbank, Pyotr Fradkov, at a meeting with the Russian President,
Vladimir Putin
, last December.
Rossiya Bank has been on the United States sanctions list since 2014, which implies the strictest possible restrictions, including the blocking of properties and accounts, as well as a ban on maintaining business relationships.
The current shareholders of the banking institution are unknown, as the
Kremlin
allowed sanctioned banks not to disclose information about their beneficiaries. The bank occupies 12th place in the Interfax-100 ranking.
PUB
General Bank, which operates in
Crimea
, is owned by Rossiya Bank, and has also been under sanctions for eight years.
The new sanctions, according to the chairman of the board of directors, Elena Blinova, will not affect the bank's financial position and operations.
Also in
Crimea
The Black Sea Bank, which is owned by the local government, has been under US sanctions for several years.
Despite being registered in Moscow, IS Bank carries out operations in
Crimea
, from Simferopol, and has been included on the US sanctions list since 2017.
O
United Kingdom
announced sanctions against three oligarchs known to be close to the Russian President,
Vladimir Putin
, and against five Russian banks, in retaliation for Moscow's recognition of the separatist regions of
Lugansk
and
Donetsk
, in eastern Ukraine. The targeted billionaires are Gennady Timchenko, Boris Rotenberg and the latter's nephew, Igor Rotenberg, revealed the British Prime Minister,
Boris Johnson
, in Parliament.
Johnson warned that he had other sanctions "ready" to be introduced alongside the
United States
and the
European Union
(EU) if the conflict continues to escalate. "This is the first installment, the first load of what we are prepared to do and we have more sanctions ready to be imposed," he said.
The sanctions package was announced after an emergency meeting of ministers and senior officials, held this morning, at the so-called Cobra security committee. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Liz Truss, also said that Russia's ambassador to the United Kingdom, Andrei Kelin, was called "to explain the violation of international law by
Russia
and disrespect for Ukraine's sovereignty".
The head of the British Government told deputies to anticipate a "long crisis" in Ukraine, taking into account that Putin ordered the deployment of troops for alleged "peacekeeping" operations in the regions of
Donetsk
and
Lugansk
. "I can't say what will happen in the next few days, but we should expect a long crisis," he said.
Boris Johnson
.
JN/Agencies

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky this Wednesday demanded "security guarantees" for his country, from the West and Moscow, in the face of the threat of a Russian invasion.
"Ukraine needs clear and concrete security guarantees immediately," Zelensky said during a press conference in Kiev with his counterparts from Poland, Andrzej Duda, and Lithuania, Gitanas Nauseda.
"I believe that Russia must be among the countries that must give these clear security guarantees," Zelensky added, recalling that he has repeatedly offered to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin in an attempt to find a solution to the crisis.
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
Zelensky took advantage of the press conference to thank his Polish and Lithuanian counterparts for their support and deliveries of weapons and military equipment to Kiev, saying that what is at stake, on his country's borders, is the future of Europe.
"We are united in the belief that the future of European security is being played out now, here, in Ukraine", explained Zelensky, referring to the escalation of tension in the Donbass region, after, on Monday, Moscow announced the recognition of the self-proclaimed separatist republics of Donetsk and Luhansk.
Ukraine's Security Council called this Wednesday for a state of emergency to be established in the country amid growing fears of an imminent Russian invasion.
Kiev had already announced today the mobilization of reservists, aged 18 to 60, and called on its citizens to leave Russia, a country that it accuses, together with the West, of preparing a large-scale offensive on Ukrainian territory.

Topics
Jorge Costa Oliveira
Opinion
One of the objectives of the Russian leadership underlying the sending, in recent weeks, of armies to the borders of Ukraine has finally become clear - the recognition, as independent countries, of the provinces of Luhansk and Donetsk, in eastern Ukraine. Russian elites demanded the defense of compatriots in Donbass; but this did not go beyond the separatism of these provinces of Ukraine. Newly signed agreements (with the ink still fresh...) between the Russian Federation and the new separatist "republics" serve as a pretext for Russian armies to enter eastern Ukraine. Meanwhile, the leader of the Russian Federation does
speeches
reiterating the "artificial" nature of Ukraine as a sovereign country.
Today's Russia is an average country in economic terms, with a total GDP slightly higher than that of Spain, a GDP
per capita
(in 2020) from
11,786 dollars
(
between
Turkey and Argentina) and a typical productive structure of a developing country, based on the export of natural resources. It is still a strong military power and that is the card the Russian leader has played now. With this move he managed to: (i) remember that Russia is a relevant military power; (ii) show that European stability, especially in the economic and energy aspects, depends on Russia; (iii) test the cohesion of NATO and AED members; (iv) increase the prices of oil and natural gas, the main products that Russia exports. But it clearly fails in the most relevant aspect for the security of the Russian Federation: forcing Ukraine's future neutrality.
It is important to remember that the Russian Federation is violating its commitments not to expand NATO to the east (
"
not one inch eastward
"
) given in 1990 to leaders of the Soviet Union (during negotiations regarding the German reunification process), which American and European governments
deny exist
. The Eastern European states that have become members of NATO will not leave the Alliance nor will NATO soldiers (placed there
after
the annexation of Crimea). Therefore, the useful effect of this Russian argument was limited to preventing Ukraine from joining NATO. In 2014, the annexation of Crimea and the war in Donbas forged a strong anti-Russian Ukrainian nationalist unity. This anti-Russian sentiment remains strong; Ukraine will no longer return to the space of Russian influence. With the stance now taken by the Kremlin, it is confirmed that Russian leaders know this well. Soon, polls will show that the vast majority of the Ukrainian population supports joining NATO (despite NATO
no
have been open to this until recently).
The Russian leadership has blatantly failed in its main objective regarding Ukraine. The Kremlin must accept this and stop chasing losses. In this dangerous game that began in recent weeks, it is important that Russian leaders realize that it is time to stop, before a serious war causes enormous international economic and financial instability, adding to terrible costs in human lives. This will have harmful effects on the credibility of the Russian Federation, will provoke unprecedented financial sanctions and will greatly alienate friendly countries such as India and China - which must already be on the verge of a nervous breakdown with their support for secessionism...

UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres insisted this Wednesday that the world faces "a moment of danger" and denounced Russia's "violations" in Ukraine, speaking at the opening of a meeting of the United Nations General Assembly.
"Russia's decision to recognize the so-called 'independence' of the Donetsk and Luhansk regions -- and what followed -- are violations of Ukraine's territorial integrity and sovereignty and are incompatible with the principles of the United Nations Charter," he said.
The secretary-general's participation was not initially planned for this meeting, which takes place annually, but Guterres decided to participate after canceling a trip to Africa and returning to New York early.

At the same meeting, Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba stressed that Ukraine is not a threat to Russia.
"Ukraine has never planned and is not planning any military operations in Donbass," he said.
The minister called for "concrete and rapid actions" from the United Nations to stop the spiral of conflict fueled, according to him, by Russia and its military deployments.
"The start of a large-scale war in Ukraine will be the end of the world order as we know it," Kuleba warned.
This meeting of the General Assembly, attended by the 193 members of the United Nations (UN), is an annual session on the "temporarily occupied Ukrainian territories", organized since Russia's annexation of Crimea in 2014.
Several ministers announced that they will intervene during the meeting, which is expected to last all day today.

translated_text:
"The
The withdrawal of personnel has already begun," the diplomatic source told TASS, cited by the Spanish agency EFE.
The decision was announced by the Russian Foreign Ministry on Monday, the day President Vladimir Putin recognized the independence of the breakaway territories of Donetsk and Luhansk, in eastern Ukraine.
"The Russian government has decided, in order to guarantee its life and safety, to withdraw personnel from its missions in Ukraine, which will come into force as soon as possible," the ministry said.
The ministry led by Sergei Lavrov argued that since 2014, the headquarters of Russia's diplomatic missions in Ukraine have suffered "numerous attacks" without any reaction from Ukrainian authorities.
The announcement of the start of the withdrawal of Russian diplomatic personnel from Ukraine was made shortly after the Kiev Government urged Ukrainian citizens to immediately leave Russian territory.
"In connection with the intensification of Russian aggression against Ukraine (...), the Ministry of Foreign Affairs recommends that Ukrainian citizens refrain from traveling to the Russian Federation and those in this country to immediately leave their territory," Ukrainian diplomacy said in a statement.
Kiev believes that under the current circumstances of military tensions with Russia, its ability to provide consular assistance to Ukrainians in Russia may be limited.
"We emphasize that ignoring these recommendations will significantly complicate the adequate protection of Ukrainian citizens in the Russian Federation," the Ukrainian Foreign Ministry added.
Following the recognition of the independence of Donetsk and Luhansk, Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those territories in eastern Ukraine on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
Ukraine ordered the mobilization of military reserves to reinforce the army.
Ukraine has more than 200,000 reservists, in addition to around 250,000 members of the regular armed forces.
In view of the worsening situation, the Security Council of Ukraine today recommended that a state of emergency be established in the country.
"The Ukrainian parliament must ratify this decision within the next 48 hours," said the secretary of the National Security and Defense Council, Oleksi√Ø Danilov, after a meeting of this structure.

The Ukrainian Ministry of Foreign Affairs called on national citizens to leave Russia as quickly as possible in view of the worsening military situation.
"The ministry recommends Ukrainian citizens to refrain from all trips to Russia and those already there should leave (Russian) territory immediately," Kiev's diplomats said in a statement released this Wednesday.
A
Russia
recognized on Monday as independent the two separatist Ukrainian territories of
Donetsk
and
Lugansk
.
On Tuesday, Russian authorities clarified that the recognition refers to the territory occupied when the self-proclaimed republics announced the status in 2014, which includes space currently held by Ukrainian forces.
Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
Meanwhile, the President of Ukraine,
Volodymyr Zelensky
has already determined the partial mobilization of military personnel in reserve to reinforce the Army, but has ruled out "for now" a total mobilization of the armed forces, given the increased Russian threat.
PUB
Zelensky explained, in a communication to the country on Tuesday, that the decree applies only to Ukrainians in the operational reserve, mobilized to reinforce the Army that fights pro-Russian militias in the Donbass region and faces the Russian military threat on the border.
The Ukrainian head of state added that, normally, this reserve is activated during periods of hostilities and that it covers "a special period of time", without specifying.
"We need to quickly add additional personnel to the Ukrainian Army and other military formations," he stressed.
The Armed Forces of Ukraine comprise around 250,000 soldiers and have a reserve of around 140,000 personnel.

‚Ä¢ban on producing and spreading information that may "destabilize the situation";
- Oleksiy Sorokin (@mrsorokaa)
February 23, 2022
These are "preventive measures to maintain calm in the country, so that the economy continues to function",
added the official, ensuring, however, that such measures "will not have a radical impact on the daily lives" of Ukrainians.
"We are ready for anything," Danilov assured.
Ukraine had already announced this Wednesday the mobilization of soldiers in reserve, aged 18 to 60, and called on its citizens to leave Russia, a country that Kiev and the West accuse of preparing a large-scale offensive towards Ukrainian territory.
"We have to react to the events of the last two or three days in Russia", defended Danilov.
Putin is 'as prepared as it is possible to be' for an invasion, US says
Russian President Vladimir Putin is "as prepared as possible" for a large-scale invasion of Ukraine, with "around 100%" of the necessary military forces already in position, a senior US administration official estimated this Wednesday.
Putin "has almost 100% of the set of forces that we had calculated he could mobilize" to invade Ukraine, said a US Department of Defense official
on condition of anonymity, reports the AFP news agency.
According to the same source, 80% of the more than 150,000 Russian soldiers present near the Ukrainian borders are organized in attack formation.
The Russian president is "as prepared as it is possible to be," the official warned, adding that the decision "to move forward or not is in Putin's hands." "They can start at any time," he pointed out.
With Lusa and AFP

Around half of the Russians questioned in a survey published this Wednesday by CNN consider it correct for their country to use military force against Ukraine to prevent Kiev from joining NATO, according to the Spanish agency Efe.
The survey carried out by the company Savanta ComRes among citizens of Ukraine and Russia concludes that
only 25% of Russians consider it wrong to use the army against Ukraine,
while another 25% are unsure about the best option to resolve the current crisis.
The survey reveals that 43% believe it would be a mistake to "reunify", through force, Russia and Ukraine, two countries with a long and complicated history of intertwined relations, but 36% do not believe that this is a bad option.
North American television reports that among Ukrainians the majority refuse to use force by Russia. Of those surveyed,
70% said it would be incorrect for Russia to use military force to prevent Ukraine from joining NATO or to unify the two countries
(73%).
Among all those who responded to the survey in Ukraine, and of all ages, there was a majority consensus on not feeling like "one people", together with Russians, and in defense of the existence of two countries.
In Ukraine,
an average of 28% of respondents agree with the idea that Russians and Ukrainians are "one people"
, while this average rises to 65% among Russian respondents.
Only 21% of Ukrainians anticipate a peaceful end to tensions with Russia, compared to 65% of Russians.
PUB
The survey also points out that only 26% of Ukrainians expect a military defense of Ukraine by NATO or the United States, and consider it more likely that there will be economic sanctions against Russian leaders (46%) or Russian companies (34%).
The survey, carried out among more than a thousand people in each country (1,021 in Russia and 1,075 in Ukraine) was carried out online between February 7th and 15th, before Vladimir Putin's speech on Monday and Moscow's recognition of the independence of the Ukrainian separatist territories of Donbass (Donetsk and Lugansk).
On Tuesday, Russian authorities clarified that the recognition refers to territory occupied when the self-proclaimed republics announced the status in 2014, which includes space currently held by Ukrainian forces.
Russian President Vladimir Putin also announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those pro-Russian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
However, Ukraine ordered the mobilization of military reserves to reinforce the army.

Under this decision, authorities will be able to "strengthen the protection" of public order and strategic infrastructure, "limit the circulation of transport" and reinforce checks on citizens' vehicles and documents.
Russian tanks in the Rostov region, near the border with Ukraine. The US and NATO claim that the "invasion" has already begun, but Putin guarantees that sending troops to Donetsk and Luhansk will depend on the "situation on the ground".

Ukraine's Security Council called this Wednesday for a state of emergency to be established in the country amid growing fears of an imminent Russian invasion.
"The Ukrainian parliament must ratify this decision within the next 48 hours," said the secretary of the National Security and Defense Council, Oleksi√Ø Danilov, after a meeting of this structure.
Under this decision, authorities will be able to "strengthen the protection" of public order and strategic infrastructure, "limit the movement of transport" and reinforce checks on citizens' vehicles and documents, Danilov specified.

These are "preventive measures to maintain calm in the country, so that the economy continues to function", added the official, ensuring, however, that such measures "will not have a radical impact on the daily lives" of Ukrainians.
"We are ready for anything", assured the person in charge.
Ukraine had already announced today the mobilization of reserve soldiers, aged 18 to 60, and called on its citizens to leave Russia, a country that Kiev and the West accuse of preparing a large-scale offensive towards Ukrainian territory.
Moscow, which has massed at least 150,000 troops on Ukraine's borders according to Westerners, earlier this week recognized the independence of two pro-Russian separatist territories in eastern Ukraine, the self-proclaimed republics of Donetsk and Luhansk, and deployed forces to the two regions for alleged peacekeeping missions.
"We have to react to the events of the last two or three days in Russia", defended Danilov.
The decision to recognize separatist territories in eastern Ukraine, announced on Monday by Russian President Vladimir Putin, has been contested by Western countries.
In reaction, several countries, such as the United States and the United Kingdom, and organizations, namely the European Union (EU), have already announced economic sanctions against Moscow, which has denied any warlike intention in relation to Kiev.

Ukraine's Security Council today called for a state of emergency to be established in the country amid growing fears of an imminent Russian invasion.
"The Ukrainian parliament must ratify this decision within the next 48 hours," said the secretary of the National Security and Defense Council, Oleksi√Ø Danilov, after a meeting of this structure.
Under this decision, authorities will be able to "strengthen the protection" of public order and strategic infrastructure, "limit the movement of transport" and reinforce checks on citizens' vehicles and documents, Danilov specified.
These are "preventive measures to maintain calm in the country, so that the economy continues to function", added the official, ensuring, however, that such measures "will not have a radical impact on the daily lives" of Ukrainians.
"We are ready for anything", assured the person in charge.
Ukraine had already announced today the mobilization of reserve soldiers, aged 18 to 60, and called on its citizens to leave Russia, a country that Kiev and the West accuse of preparing a large-scale offensive towards Ukrainian territory.
PUB
Moscow, which has massed at least 150,000 troops on Ukraine's borders according to Westerners, earlier this week recognized the independence of two pro-Russian separatist territories in eastern Ukraine, the self-proclaimed republics of Donetsk and Luhansk, and deployed forces to the two regions for alleged peacekeeping missions.
"We have to react to the events of the last two or three days in Russia", defended Danilov.
The decision to recognize separatist territories in eastern Ukraine, announced on Monday by Russian President Vladimir Putin, has been contested by Western countries.
In reaction, several countries, such as the United States and the United Kingdom, and organizations, namely the European Union (EU), have already announced economic sanctions against Moscow, which has denied any warlike intention in relation to Kiev.

Feb 23, 2022
10:10
0
Comments
Photo¬†EPA/CLEMENS BILAN
The Ukrainian Ministry of Foreign Affairs today called on national citizens to leave Russia as quickly as possible in the face of the worsening military situation.
"The ministry recommends Ukrainian citizens to refrain from¬†all trips to Russia and those already there must leave (Russian) territory immediately," Kiev's diplomacy said in a statement released today.
???????Russia on Monday recognized the two separatist Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Luhansk as independent.
On Tuesday, Russian authorities clarified that the recognition refers to the territory occupied when the self-proclaimed republics announced the¬†status in 2014, which includes space currently held by Ukrainian forces.
Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
Meanwhile, the¬†President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky has already ordered the partial mobilization of military personnel in reserve to reinforce the Army, but has ruled out "for now" a total mobilization of the armed forces, given the increase in the Russian threat.
Zelensky explained, in a communication to the country on Tuesday,¬†that the decree applies only to Ukrainians in the operational reserve, mobilized to reinforce the Army fighting pro-Russian militias in the Donbass region and facing the Russian military threat on the border.
The Ukrainian head of state added that, normally, this reserve is activated during periods of hostilities and that it covers "a special period of time", without specifying.
"We need to quickly add additional personnel to the Ukrainian Army and other military formations," he stressed.
The Armed Forces of Ukraine comprise around 250,000 soldiers and have a reserve of around 140,000 personnel.

translated_text:
World
Half of Russians support war so that Kiev does not join NATO
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
12:44
0
Comments
Photo EPA
Around half of the Russians questioned in a survey published today by CNN consider it correct for their country to use military force against Ukraine to prevent Kiev from joining NATO, according to the Spanish agency Efe.
The survey carried out by the company Savanta ComRes among citizens of Ukraine and Russia concludes that only 25% of Russians believe that it would be wrong to use the army against Ukraine, while another 25% are unsure about the best option to resolve the current crisis.
The survey reveals that 43% believe that it would be a mistake to "reunify", through force, Russia and Ukraine, two countries with a long and complicated history of intertwined relations, but 36% do not believe that this is a bad option.
North American television reports that among Ukrainians the majority refuse to use force by Russia. Of those surveyed, 70% said it would be incorrect for Russia to use military force to prevent Ukraine from joining NATO or to unify the two countries (73%).
Among all those who responded to the survey in Ukraine, and of all ages, there was a majority consensus on not feeling like "one people", together with Russians, and in defense of the existence of two countries.
In Ukraine, an average of 28% of respondents agree with the idea that Russians and Ukrainians are "one people", while this average rises to 65% for Russian respondents.
Only 21% of Ukrainians anticipate a peaceful end to tensions with Russia, compared to 65% of Russians.
The survey also points out that only 26% of Ukrainians expect a military defense of Ukraine by NATO or the United States, and consider it more likely that there will be economic sanctions against Russian leaders (46%) or Russian companies (34%).
The survey, carried out among more than a thousand people in each country (1,021 in Russia and 1,075 in Ukraine) was carried out online between February 7th and 15th, before Vladimir Putin's speech on Monday and Moscow's recognition of the independence of the Ukrainian separatist territories of Donbass (Donetsk and Lugansk).
On Tuesday, Russian authorities clarified that the recognition refers to territory occupied when the self-proclaimed republics announced the status in 2014, which includes space currently held by Ukrainian forces.
Russian President Vladimir Putin also announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those pro-Russian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
However, Ukraine ordered the mobilization of military reserves to reinforce the army.

translated_text:
World
Ukraine's Security Council calls for the establishment of a state of emergency
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
12:42
0
Comments
AFP Photo
Ukraine's Security Council today called for a state of emergency to be established in the country amid growing fears of an imminent Russian invasion.
"The Ukrainian parliament must ratify this decision within the next 48 hours," said the secretary of the National Security and Defense Council, Oleksi√Ø Danilov, after a meeting of this structure.
Under this decision, authorities will be able to "strengthen the protection" of public order and strategic infrastructure, "limit the movement of transport" and reinforce checks on citizens' vehicles and documents, Danilov specified.
These are "preventive measures to maintain calm in the country, so that the economy continues to function", added the official, ensuring, however, that such measures "will not have a radical impact on the daily lives" of Ukrainians.
"We are ready for anything", assured the person in charge.
Ukraine had already announced today the mobilization of reserve soldiers, aged 18 to 60, and called on its citizens to leave Russia, a country that Kiev and the West accuse of preparing a large-scale offensive towards Ukrainian territory.
Moscow, which has massed at least 150,000 troops on Ukraine's borders according to Westerners, earlier this week recognized the independence of two pro-Russian separatist territories in eastern Ukraine, the self-proclaimed republics of Donetsk and Luhansk, and deployed forces to the two regions for alleged peacekeeping missions.
"We have to react to the events of the last two or three days in Russia", defended Danilov.
The decision to recognize separatist territories in eastern Ukraine, announced on Monday by Russian President Vladimir Putin, has been contested by Western countries.
In reaction, several countries, such as the United States and the United Kingdom, and organizations, namely the European Union (EU), have already announced economic sanctions against Moscow, which has denied any warlike intention in relation to Kiev.

"The key question is, what is the role of the United States in the current tensions in Ukraine", he asked, adding: "Someone who throws gasoline on the fire, while accusing others, is someone immoral and irresponsible".
On Monday, after Moscow recognized the two self-proclaimed pro-Russian separatist republics in eastern Ukraine, prompting Washington, the European Union (EU) and several other countries to impose sanctions against Russia, Hua called on actors in the Ukrainian crisis to "show restraint."
Fears of a military escalation at the door of the EU have reached a peak since Vladimir Putin recognized the independence of the territories of Donetsk and Lugansk.
Regarding Western sanctions, one of the most dramatic measures was announced by Berlin, which froze the gigantic Nord Stream II gas pipeline project, which was supposed to bring more Russian natural gas to Germany.
US President Joe Biden announced a "first tranche" of sanctions aimed at preventing Moscow from accessing Western funds to pay its sovereign debt.
Asked about the possibility of China imposing sanctions on Russia, Hua said "this has never been an effective way to solve problems."
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.
That year, the war began in Donbass between pro-Russian separatists supported by Moscow and the Ukrainian army, which has since caused more than 14,000 deaths and 1.5 million people displaced, according to the UN.

Netherlands summons Russian ambassador to The Hague
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
18:31
0
Comments
Photo:¬† EPA/ZURAB KURTSIKIDZE
The Netherlands recalled the Russian ambassador to The Hague on Tuesday, following Moscow's recognition of the Ukrainian separatist regions of Donetsk and Luhansk, the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs confirmed today.
According to the agency France-Presse (AFP), on Tuesday "the Netherlands actually summoned the Russian ambassador", said a spokeswoman for the Dutch ministry.
"The Netherlands has clearly made it known to the Russian ambassador that Russia's recent actions are unacceptable and will have serious consequences," the spokeswoman added.
Austria, the United Kingdom and Canada also recalled their respective Russian ambassadors on Tuesday.
British Foreign Minister Liz Truss said that Russia's ambassador to the United Kingdom, Andrei Kelin, was called "to explain Russia's violation of international law and disrespect for Ukraine's sovereignty."
In Canada, head of diplomacy M√©lanie Joly summoned "the Russian ambassador to ask for explanations about Russia's continued aggression, its violation of international law and its disregard for Ukrainian sovereignty", she said on Twitter.
The recognition of the independence of Donetsk and Luhansk by Russian President Vladimir Putin on Monday drew condemnation from most Western countries, after around two months of tension due to the concentration of tens of thousands of Russian troops near Ukraine's borders.
Pro-Russian separatists in Donetsk and Luhansk, supported by Moscow, went to war with Ukrainian authorities in 2014 following Russia's annexation of the Crimean peninsula.
Since then, the conflict has caused more than 14,000 deaths and displaced 1.5 million people, according to the United Nations.

OSCE reports increase on Monday in ceasefire violations
Lusa Agency
Feb 22, 2022
23:52
0
Comments
Photo EPA
The Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE) reported 1,927 ceasefire violations in eastern Ukraine on Monday, almost double the violations recorded the previous day by its observers.
According to the latest report from the Special Verification Mission (SMM), the Luhansk region recorded 1,224 violations of the ceasefire, including 1,149 explosions, compared to the 333 incidents recorded on Sunday.
At the same time, in the Donetsk region the balance records 703 violations of the ceasefire, including 332 explosions, compared to 579 the previous day.
These incidents coincided with Russia's recognition on Monday of two breakaway Ukrainian territories in the Donbass region as independent.
Russian President Vladimir Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian parliament.
The Russian head of state stated today that the deployment of Russian troops to the Donbass region will depend on the situation on the ground, where clashes "continue" and tend to worsen.

translated_text:
World
Parliament approves establishment of a state of emergency in the country
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
21:00
0
Comments
Photo:¬†JOSE COELHO/LUSA
Ukraine's parliament today approved the establishment of a state of emergency in the country, proposed by President Volodymyr Zelensky in view of the worsening situation in the east of the country and the military threat from Russia.
This extraordinary measure, which comes into force on Thursday for 30 days, is applied throughout the country, except in the regions of Donetsk and Luhansk, which have been under a political-military administration since 2014.
The Ukrainian head of state's proposal was approved by a large majority, with the votes of 335 of the 339 deputies, when the minimum required for approval was the favorable vote of 226 parliamentarians.
The Ukrainian Security Council had already called today for the establishment of a state of emergency in the country due to growing fears of an imminent Russian invasion.
Vladimir Putin signed, on Monday night, a decree recognizing the self-proclaimed republics of Luhansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and another providing for the mobilization of the Russian army to "maintain peace" in these pro-Russian separatist territories.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.
The state of emergency now established in Ukraine allows authorities to impose restrictions on movement, prevent rallies and ban political and party activities in the "interests of national security and public order".
Ukrainian authorities have repeatedly expressed concern that Russia may seek to destabilize the country through Moscow supporters in Ukraine, including a pro-Russian political party represented in parliament.
The document also prohibits the dissemination of "information material that could destabilize the situation in the country."
This state also includes the possibility of evacuation from dangerous locations, control of citizens' documentation and regulation of civil radio and television stations.
If necessary, the state of emergency makes it possible to restrict freedom of movement, the registration of citizens' means of transport and belongings and the application of a mandatory curfew, a decision that is delegated to regional authorities.

translated_text:
O
Minister of Foreign Affairs, Augusto Santos Silva, assumed this Wednesday in an interview with CNN Portugal that "we have to be prepared for all scenarios", including the scenario of war, although the ambition is only to "return to the political and diplomatic plane".
Santos Silva highlights that "at the moment Russia's behavior is unpredictable" and has revealed that the rules are not followed in a stable manner.
"The world felt that it could not trust Russia", recalls the minister, stressing, however, that the diplomatic route always remains open.
However, although the West maintains the desire to resolve the conflict peacefully, Putin's actions place this possibility on the distant horizon.
"Russia said last Sunday that it would end joint military exercises a few kilometers from the Ukrainian border and, apparently, they continued. Putin assured President Macron of his involvement in building the ceasefire and on Monday he surprised everyone and everything with an act that represents the territorial violation of Ukraine", he recalls, highlighting the Russian president's unpredictable behavior.
Augusto Santos Silva adds that Europe "will respond when events happen".
Portuguese in Ukraine? "We recommend abandoning" the country
The Minister of Foreign Affairs recommends "all people who can temporarily leave Ukraine to do so".
"Every day I speak to the ambassador in Kiev. We currently have 202 registered Portuguese citizens, that is, we know who they are, where they are, how they can leave where they are and we have that direct contact", explains the minister.
In areas considered at risk, that is, in Donbass, Santos Silva states that there were three Portuguese people, but that, at the moment, none are there.
Of the 202 Portuguese registered in Ukraine, 90 are in Kiev and the rest are spread across the country.
The minister also details that, of these, 42 are only Portuguese citizens and 160 are Portuguese-Ukrainian citizens. Of these 160, explains Santos Silva, it is clear that "many say they want to stay in Ukraine" since it is also their homeland. "Consular support is different when we are abroad or when we are citizens of the country we are in. These people are a concern for everyone", he further explains.
Finally, the politician once again advises anyone who can do so to leave the country as quickly as possible.

translated_text:
"Unfortunately, the prospects are not the best, given Russia's aggressive stance", wrote Rui Rio, on his Twitter account, after participating in this PPE summit.
The PPE meeting took place on the eve of an extraordinary summit of heads of state and government of the European Union, called today, to discuss the escalation of tension between Ukraine and Russia.
The convening of this extraordinary European Council occurs on the same day that the Committee of Permanent Representatives of the Governments of the Member States of the European Union definitively adopted the sanctions against Russia approved on Tuesday by the 27 Foreign Ministers.
On Tuesday night, the member states' ambassadors to the EU had already given their approval to the list of European sanctions on Russia, which, according to the head of European diplomacy, Josep Borrell, aim to "harm hard" on the Russian authorities, with the package being formally adopted today.
Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu and two private banks in Russia are among those targeted by the sanctions, which cover 27 individuals and entities from the political, military, business and media sectors, as well as around 350 members of the lower house of the Russian parliament (Duma).
Regarding financial sanctions, restrictions are expected on the EU's economic and commercial relations with the two separatist regions, Donetsk and Luhansk, as well as the freezing of assets of two Russian private banks and limits on the Russian State's ability to access the EU's capital and financial markets.
The EU's positions come after Russian President Vladimir Putin signed, on Monday night, a decree recognizing the self-proclaimed republics of Lugansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and ordered the mobilization of the Russian army to "maintain peace" in these pro-Russian separatist territories.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.

Putin makes sending troops to Donbas dependent on the situation on the ground
Feb 22, 2022 - 8:05 pm ‚Ä¢
Lusa
Russian president justifies recognition of the independence of Donetsk and Luhansk with Kiev's refusal to comply with the Minsk agreements on the peaceful resolution of the conflict in the region.
A+
/
A-
Photo: Alexey Nikolsky/EPA
The President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, said this Tuesday that the deployment of Russian troops to the Donbass region, in eastern Ukraine, will depend on the situation on the ground, where clashes "continue" and tend to worsen.
At a press conference in which he also called for international recognition of Russia's sovereignty over Crimea, the Ukrainian peninsula that Moscow annexed in 2014, Putin said that everything will depend on the development of events and the "situation on the ground".
The Russian President, who was speaking after being authorized by the Senate to send Russian troops out of the country, stated that the fighting in the conflict zone "continues" and tends to worsen.
"I didn't say that the troops will go there now, right away", the Russian leader told journalists, adding that at this moment it is "impossible" to predict what will happen and everything will depend on the "concrete situation on the ground".
The Russian leader insisted that Moscow recognized the independence of the self-proclaimed separatist republics of Donetsk and Lugansk due to Kiev's refusal to comply with the Minsk agreements on the peaceful resolution of the conflict in the region.
"It's the beginning of the Russian invasion" of Ukraine. Joe Biden announces new sanctions on Moscow
The United States will move forward with sanctions on two b(...)
See more
"The Minsk agreements died long before the recognition of the republics of Donbass," Putin said, asserting that "the agreements ceased to exist."
In this regard, he regretted that Europe could not influence Kiev to fulfill its commitments under the agreements.
Putin also defended that Russia's 2014 annexation of the Crimean Peninsula should be recognized internationally as a legitimate reflection of the local population's choice, comparing it to the referendum for Kosovo's independence.
The annexation was widely condemned by Western powers as a violation of international law.
To put an end to the current crisis, the Russian President insisted on renouncing the possibility of Ukraine joining NATO, saying that this country should assume a "neutral status", and that the West should stop sending weapons to Kiev.

Japan and Australia have announced sanctions against Russia and the pro-Russian separatist territories of Lugansk and Donetsk, which Russian President Vladimir Putin recognized on Monday as independent.
Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said the government will ban new issuance and distribution of Russian sovereign debt securities in Japan in response to "Russia's actions in Ukraine."
Kishida said the country will also ban trade with Luhansk and Donetsk, suspend the issuance of visas to people linked to the two eastern areas of Ukraine and freeze the assets of these individuals in Japan.
The Japanese Prime Minister said that the sanctions will come into force "as soon as possible".
Kishida indicated that Japan is prepared to adopt additional measures if the situation worsens, in coordination with the remaining G7 member countries.
Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced sanctions against banking institutions such as VEB, one of Russia's largest investment and development banks, and the Russian military bank, among others.
PUB
Australia will also impose sanctions against industries in various sectors, such as energy, mining and hydrocarbons, in the regions of Donestsk and Luhansk, which are now covered by sanctions imposed in 2011 on Crimea and Sevastopol, then occupied by Russia.
Morrison said Australia will also ban entry and apply financial sanctions to eight members of Russia's security council, a body that brings together key Russian decision-makers, in particular the leaders of the Army and secret services.
Both Morrison and Kishida reiterated their condemnation of the Russian decision, which they considered to be a violation of Ukrainian sovereignty and territorial integrity, as well as international law.
Kishida assured that Japan will do everything to protect the Japanese who are still in Ukraine, despite Tokyo having advised its citizens to leave the country ten days ago.
Morrison said there were still around 1,400 Australians living in Ukraine and added that he had ordered the urgent processing of visa applications submitted by 1,400 Ukrainians, including students.
Canberra has already contacted a number of companies to prevent a possible cyber attack on Australian critical infrastructure in retaliation for sanctions imposed against Russia, Morrison said.
Canada, the United Kingdom and the United States had also announced sanctions against Russia and the pro-Russian separatist territories of Luhansk and Donetsk.
On Monday, Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.

Rio participated in the PPE summit and says that ‚Äúprospects are not the best‚Äù
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
20:57
0

Photo: PSD
The president of the PSD, Rui Rio, participated today in the extraordinary summit of the European People's Party on the conflict in Ukraine, held via video conference, and expressed himself pessimistic, criticizing "Russia's aggressive stance".
"Unfortunately, the prospects are not the best, given Russia's aggressive stance", wrote Rui Rio, on his Twitter account, after participating in this PPE summit.
The PPE meeting took place on the eve of an extraordinary summit of heads of state and government of the European Union, called today, to discuss the escalation of tension between Ukraine and Russia.
The convening of this extraordinary European Council occurs on the same day that the Committee of Permanent Representatives of the Governments of the Member States of the European Union definitively adopted the sanctions against Russia approved on Tuesday by the 27 Foreign Ministers.
On Tuesday night, the member states' ambassadors to the EU had already given their approval to the list of European sanctions on Russia, which, according to the head of European diplomacy, Josep Borrell, aim to "harm hard" on the Russian authorities, with the package being formally adopted today.
Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu and two private banks in Russia are among those targeted by the sanctions, which cover 27 individuals and entities from the political, military, business and media sectors, as well as around 350 members of the lower house of the Russian parliament (Duma).
Regarding financial sanctions, restrictions are expected on the EU's economic and commercial relations with the two separatist regions, Donetsk and Luhansk, as well as the freezing of assets of two Russian private banks and limits on the Russian State's ability to access the EU's capital and financial markets.
The EU's positions come after Russian President Vladimir Putin signed, on Monday night, a decree recognizing the self-proclaimed republics of Lugansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and ordered the mobilization of the Russian army to "maintain peace" in these pro-Russian separatist territories.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.

translated_text:
O
Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said the government will ban new issuance and distribution of Russian sovereign debt securities in Japan in response to "Russia's actions in Ukraine".
Kishida said the country will also ban trade with Luhansk and Donetsk, suspend the issuance of visas to people linked to the two eastern areas of Ukraine and freeze the assets of these individuals in Japan.
The Japanese Prime Minister said that the sanctions will come into force "as soon as possible".
Kishida indicated that Japan is prepared to adopt additional measures if the situation worsens, in coordination with the remaining G7 member countries.
Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced sanctions against banking institutions such as VEB, one of Russia's largest investment and development banks, and the Russian military bank, among others.
Australia will also impose sanctions against industries in various sectors, such as energy, mining and hydrocarbons, in the regions of Donestsk and Luhansk, which are now covered by sanctions imposed in 2011 on Crimea and Sevastopol, then occupied by Russia.
Morrison said Australia will also ban entry and apply financial sanctions to eight members of Russia's security council, a body that brings together key Russian decision-makers, in particular the leaders of the Army and secret services.
Both Morrison and Kishida reiterated their condemnation of the Russian decision, which they considered to be a violation of Ukrainian sovereignty and territorial integrity, as well as international law.
Kishida assured that Japan will do everything to protect the Japanese who are still in Ukraine, despite Tokyo having advised its citizens to leave the country ten days ago.
Morrison said there were still around 1,400 Australians living in Ukraine and added that he had ordered the urgent processing of visa applications submitted by 1,400 Ukrainians, including students.
Canberra has already contacted a number of companies to prevent a possible cyber attack on Australian critical infrastructure in retaliation for sanctions imposed against Russia, Morrison said.
Canada, the United Kingdom and the United States had also announced sanctions against Russia and the pro-Russian separatist territories of Luhansk and Donetsk.
On Monday, Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
