translated_text:
World
Japan and Australia announce sanctions against Russia and separatist territories
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
09:15
0
Comments
Photo¬†EPA/CLEMENS BILAN
Japan and Australia today announced sanctions against Russia and the pro-Russian separatist territories of Luhansk and Donetsk, which Russian President Vladimir Putin recognized on Monday as independent.
Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said the government will ban new issuance and distribution of Russian sovereign debt securities in Japan in response to "Russia's actions in Ukraine."
Kishida said the country will also ban trade with Luhansk and Donetsk, suspend the issuance of visas to people linked to the two eastern areas of Ukraine and freeze the assets of these individuals in Japan.
The Japanese Prime Minister said that the sanctions will come into force "as soon as possible".
Kishida indicated that Japan is prepared to adopt additional measures if the situation worsens, in coordination with the remaining G7 member countries.
Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced sanctions against banking institutions such as VEB, one of Russia's largest investment and development banks, and the Russian military bank, among others.
Australia will also impose sanctions against industries in various sectors, such as energy, mining and hydrocarbons, in the regions of Donestsk and Luhansk, which are now covered by sanctions imposed in 2011 on Crimea and Sevastopol, then occupied by Russia.
Morrison said Australia will also ban entry and apply financial sanctions to eight members of Russia's security council, a body that brings together key Russian decision-makers, in particular the leaders of the Army and secret services.
Both Morrison and Kishida reiterated their condemnation of the Russian decision, which they considered to be a violation of Ukrainian sovereignty and territorial integrity, as well as international law.
Kishida assured that Japan will do everything to protect the Japanese who are still in Ukraine, despite Tokyo having advised its citizens to leave the country ten days ago.
Morrison said there were still around 1,400 Australians living in Ukraine and added that he had ordered the urgent processing of visa applications submitted by 1,400 Ukrainians, including students.
Canberra has already contacted a number of companies to prevent a possible cyber attack on Australian critical infrastructure in retaliation for sanctions imposed against Russia, Morrison said.
Canada, the United Kingdom and the United States had also announced sanctions against Russia and the pro-Russian separatist territories of Luhansk and Donetsk.
On Monday, Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.

Pope Francis lamented, this Wednesday, the "increasingly alarming scenarios" that are emerging in Ukraine and that threaten "everyone's peace" in the face of fears of a military escalation by Russia.
"Despite the diplomatic efforts of recent weeks, increasingly alarming scenarios are emerging", said the Argentine Pope at the end of his weekly general audience, adding that, like him, "many people feel anxiety and concern".
"I urge all parties involved to refrain from any action that could cause even more suffering to people and discredit international law," he said.
Francis criticized the fact that "once again, the peace of all" is "threatened by the interests of a few", asking political leaders to "examine their conscience before God, who is the God of peace and not of war".
The Pope also announced for March 2nd - Ash Wednesday - a
day of fasting and prayer for peace
.
The crisis in Ukraine worsened on Monday, when Russian President Vladimir Putin, during a speech to the nation, recognized the self-proclaimed pro-Russian separatist republics of Donetsk and Luhansk (in eastern Ukraine) and called for the mobilization of military personnel to be sent to the region.
PUB
The Pope had already made an appeal for peace in Ukraine on February 13, when he demanded from world leaders "every effort" possible to prevent violence in that country.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.
That year, the war began in Donbass between pro-Russian separatists supported by Moscow and the Ukrainian army, which has since caused more than 14,000 deaths and 1.5 million people displaced, according to the UN.

Joe Biden
, which authorized the transfer of additional troops to the Baltic countries - Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.

and which will be deployed to the Baltic region.

USA
They will also move 20 AH-64 combat helicopters from Germany to those Eastern European countries.
At the same time, the
Pentagon
will send eight F-35 fighters to various locations on NATO's eastern flank, which are in Germany, and also gave the green light for the transfer of 12 AH-64 helicopters, from Greece to Poland.
The same source added that this transfer of soldiers and equipment will allow "to reassure the allies of the
NATO
, deter any potential aggression against Atlantic Alliance member states, and train host nation forces.‚Äù
The US Department of Defense indicated that these movements of troops and equipment are "temporary" and recalled that the
USA
have more than 90 thousand soldiers deployed in
Europe
under rotating and permanent mandates.

On February 11th the
Pentagon
had ordered the sending of three thousand additional soldiers to Poland, due to the increase in tensions in
Ukraine
, which brought to six thousand the number of soldiers deployed by Washington in
Europe
due to this crisis.

Joe Biden
, today announced a set of economic sanctions on Russian individuals, entities and banks, following recognition by
Russia
of the self-proclaimed republics of Donbass, in eastern Ukraine.
Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.

Russia
invaded Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.

‚ÄúI walked in yesterday [on Monday] and there was a television screen [broadcasting news about the conflict between Ukraine and Russia], and I said: ‚ÄòThis is genius.‚Äô Putin declares a large part of Ukraine.
Putin declares it independent. Oh, this is magnificent
", stated the millionaire republished in an interview with the program 'Clay Travis and Buck Sexton Show'.
And he adds:
"So Putin now says, 'It's independent'. A big part of Ukraine. How smart is that? He's going to go there and be a peacemaker."
.
From Trump's perspective, the mobilization of the Russian Army in the separatist regions of Donetsk and Luhansk, recognized as People's Republics by Putin,
‚Äúit‚Äôs the strongest force of peace‚Äù you‚Äôve ever seen
.
"There were more army tanks than I've ever seen. They're going to keep the peace, that's fine. No, but think about it. There's a very experienced person here [Putin]", he concluded.
In a statement, Donald Trump
criticized his successor's management of the conflict
, Joe Biden, and stated that Putin would ‚Äúnever‚Äù act in the same way if he were still president of the USA.
"If managed correctly, there was absolutely no reason for the situation to escalate in Ukraine"
, he said.
"I know Vladimir Putin very well, and he would never have done under the Trump administration what he is doing now, in no way," he concluded.

translated_text:
¬´Shakhtar moved to their rival's house to have peace¬ª
V√≠tor Severino, Ukrainian champion in 2020, speaks to Maisfutebol about a club that has been banished since the conflict broke out in the Donbass region
2022-02-22 23:55
More football
Sergio Pires
Shakhtar is no longer just the name of the most successful club in Ukrainian football over the last two decades. Since 2014, it has also become a symbol of the conflict in the Donbass region.
When war broke out in the east of the country, the emblem revitalized since the mid-1990s by millionaire Rinat Akhmetov had to abandon Donetsk.
Since then, he has been based in Lviv, where he never felt at home, he moved to Kharkiv, until last season he settled permanently in the capital, to play at the Kiev Olympics.
The war took the ‚Äúminers‚Äô club‚Äù to ‚Äúenemy territory‚Äù. It is a paradox that peace has only been found at the home of historic rivals Dinamo, emphasizes V√≠tor Severino.
The 38-year-old Portuguese, who became champion of Ukraine in 2020, in Lu√≠s Castro's technical team, speaks to
More football
, from Qatar, about the tensions of a country that he left a few months ago and about the reality of an exiled club, which left behind a model stadium for Euro 2012: ¬´There are hundreds of Shakhtar employees displaced, they talk about the Donbass Arena as if it were the Colosseum in Rome.¬ª
MOREFOOTBALL: Since 2014, Shakhtar had to leave Donetsk, due to the conflict in the Donbass region. What was the experience of working at an exiled club like?
V√çTOR SEVERINO: After Lviv and Kharkiv, Shakhtar is now in Kiev, like Olimpski Donetsk, or Zorya Luhansk, who had to move to the city of Zaporizhzhia. During the two times we were in Ukraine we experienced two different realities. In the first year [2019/2020], the club was already based in Kiev, but played in Kharkiv [about 450 kilometers away]. We had to travel by plane to play home games. We made more than a hundred flights. It was crazy logistically. In the second year, we moved permanently to the capital and started sharing the Olympic Stadium with Dynamo Kiev.
What was this madness like in logistical terms?
The club is displaced, the employees are displaced... We are talking about hundreds of people who came from Donetsk when the conflict broke out. Meanwhile, the club now has a new training center on the outskirts of Kiev, in an old Soviet sports complex, which was renovated and was our temporary home.
How did this change caused by the conflict affect the relationship with fans?
There were mainly younger people who moved from that region closest to Russia to Kiev. Shakhtar's large support base is in Donbass, but in the last ten years there has been an interesting phenomenon: because it is a winning club, many children and young people have emerged in the rest of the country. This is already seen in Kiev, although there is no comparison with Dynamo, which is the national club. A game at the Olympic Stadium has many more Dynamo Kiev fans than Shakhtar.
Didn't you encounter this resistance in the rest of Ukraine because Shakhtar is a club associated with a region of great Russian influence?
I felt a positive impact on the first ‚Äòderby‚Äô we did at the Kiev Olympics. Instead of leaving by bus, we were told to leave the stadium in our car, take a taxi or even walk home. I found that strange. But we left a game that was simmering inside and walked calmly through the rival's fans: kids with Dinamo scarves asking to take photos and sign autographs. On the other hand, I also knew of cases of great animosity.
In what specific situation?
Dario Srna [former Croatian international, now the club's sporting director, who he represented for 15 seasons] told me that when Shakhtar was based in Lviv there was enormous resistance from the locals. We are talking about the opposite end of the country. In the Donetsk and Luhansk area, everyone speaks Russian. In Kiev, Russian is spoken more, but service in public places is mandatory in Ukrainian. In Lviv, which is close to Poland and is a more European city, only Ukrainian is spoken anymore. They take issue with speaking Russian. Shakhtar people remember that they were never welcome there. The club was heavily criticized for leaving Donetsk to go to Lviv. Those were difficult times. In fact, the club had to leave there.
Is the move to Kiev due to this lack of hospitality?
It wasn't the only reason, but it influenced a lot. Dario, with whom I talked a lot, told me that the big difference was that in Kiev Shakhtar could have more peace. It's even paradoxical, because it happened to be at the home of their great rival.
Is Shakhtar seen as a Russophile emblem?
The club seeks to be neutral in this aspect. Above all, it wants to assert itself as a national club and a reference in European football in many departments. However, even some of my Ukrainian friends were sympathetic to the Russian position on the issue of Donetsk and Luhansk. Now, I clearly feel that the new generations are more pro-European Union, in defense of national values, the Ukrainian language, in short, independence. Sometimes, football served to vent some animosity. What was felt in Lviv was felt in other stadiums: associating Shakhtar with the conflict in that region, which is currently a self-proclaimed republic.
Rinat Akhmetov, the owner and president of Shakhtar, is not only one of Ukraine's greatest fortunes, but also a figure with a controversial career. What idea do you have about him?
Some people consider him controversial, but there are also those who have some sympathy for the figure, especially because he is linked to social causes. It invested millions in combating the pandemic, it has a foundation to promote sport across the country, in addition to Shakhtar, which is one of its flags.
In addition to the phalanx of fans, the Donbass Arena, one of the biggest stages of Euro 2012, was also left behind.
99 percent of Shakhtar's employees are from Donetsk and they all talk about the Donbass Arena as if it were the Colosseum in Rome. They talk about that stadium and the city itself with enormous affection.
Donbass Arena bombed in 2014 (Reuters)
Have these people been able to return over this time?
Some, yes. If they prove that they have family there, with many security measures, they could enter Donetsk and return.
From what you've seen, is there any hope of a return to Donetsk?
President Rinat Akhmetov himself never went to a stadium again. He says he will only return when Shakhtar returns to play at the Donbass Arena. Most people I asked said they would really like to return, but they don't believe it is possible.
Do you believe in resolving the conflict between Ukraine and Russia?
I believe it is very difficult to resolve. According to what was said in Ukraine, the issue of Donbass is even more complex than that of Crimea [annexed by Russia in 2014]. The entrances are guarded, there are many checkpoints with military personnel. It is not possible for a foreigner or a Ukrainian who does not have family to enter there. If there is no resolution, clubs like Shakhtar, Olimpik or Zorya will never return home.
2022-02-22 23:55

Donbass

In a strong speech, the UN Secretary-General also said that "when troops from one country enter the territory of another country without its consent, they cannot be considered impartial peacekeepers", and as such "they are not peacekeeping forces", an expression used by the Russian President

It is a violation of Ukraine's territorial integrity and sovereignty", he stressed.
On the same day that the United States, European Union, United Kingdom and other countries announced sanctions against Russian individuals and entities,
Ant√≥nio Guterres
he also said that the recognition of the separatist territories "is a fatal blow to the Minsk Agreements approved by the Security Council" of the
United Nations
.

Vladimir Putin
, the UN Secretary General rejected this idea.

"At this critical moment, I call for an immediate ceasefire and the restoration of the rule of law. It is high time to resume the path of dialogue and negotiations", he argued
Ant√≥nio Guterres
.

over Crimea, the Ukrainian peninsula that

annexed in 2014, Putin said that everything will depend on the development of events and the "situation on the ground".

translated_text:
"C
Considering the latest dramatic developments in Ukraine, President Metsola has called for an extraordinary meeting of the Conference of Presidents [political party leaders] for Thursday morning", announced the office of the leader of the European assembly, in a note sent to Lusa.
Present at the meeting, which takes place in a hybrid format and which will be "an opportunity to exchange views" on the Ukrainian security crisis, will also be the presidents of the European Council, Charles Michel, and the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen.
The meeting is expected to address various aspects of the crisis, including the European Union's condemnation of "Russian aggression against Ukraine, the violation of international law and the Minsk Agreements, the EU's support for the independence and territorial integrity of Ukraine and the rapid adoption of sanctions by the Council", states Roberta Metsola's office in the note.
The meeting also aims to "express solidarity with the people of Ukraine and remember the importance of the continued unity of the EU", he adds.
Roberta Metsola, who has been very critical of the Russian offensive and active in defending Ukrainian sovereignty, will participate on Thursday night in the extraordinary summit of heads of state and government of the European Union, also called today, to discuss the escalation of tension between Ukraine and Russia.
The convening of this extraordinary European Council occurs on the same day that the Committee of Permanent Representatives of the Governments of the Member States of the European Union definitively adopted the sanctions against Russia approved on Tuesday by the 27 Foreign Ministers.
On Tuesday night, the member states' ambassadors to the EU had already given their approval to the list of European sanctions on Russia, which, according to the head of European diplomacy, Josep Borrell, aim to "harm hard" on the Russian authorities, with the package being formally adopted today.
Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu and two private banks in Russia are among those targeted by the sanctions, which cover 27 individuals and entities from the political, military, business and media sectors, as well as around 350 members of the lower house of the Russian parliament (Duma).
Regarding financial sanctions, restrictions are expected on the EU's economic and commercial relations with the two separatist regions, Donetsk and Luhansk, as well as the freezing of assets of two Russian private banks and limits on the Russian State's ability to access the EU's capital and financial markets.
The EU's positions come after Russian President Vladimir Putin signed, on Monday night, a decree recognizing the self-proclaimed republics of Lugansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and ordered the mobilization of the Russian army to "maintain peace" in these pro-Russian separatist territories.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.

The president of the European Council called this Wednesday an extraordinary summit of heads of state and government of the European Union (EU) for Thursday, in Brussels, to discuss the escalation of tension between Ukraine and Russia.
"The use of force and coercion to change borders has no place in the 21st century. I convene a special European Council for tomorrow [Thursday] in Brussels to discuss the latest developments related to Ukraine and Russia," Council President Charles Michel announced on Twitter. The summit will be held in person and is scheduled for 8 pm local time (7 pm in mainland Portugal).
In the letter of invitation addressed to the leaders, including Prime Minister Ant√≥nio Costa, the President of the European Council begins by thanking the 27 "for the unity demonstrated in recent days, particularly through the rapid adoption of the sanctions package" against Russia, in light of Moscow's recognition of the self-proclaimed republics of Luhansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and the decision of Russian President Vladimir Putin to mobilize military forces in the region.
Reiterating that "aggressive actions by the Russian Federation violate international law and the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine" and "also undermine the European security order", Charles Michel says it is important that the 27 remain "united and determined, to jointly define the approach and collective actions" in the face of the current situation.
The President of the European Council specifies that the objective of this extraordinary summit is to discuss "the latest developments", how the EU can "protect the rules-based international order", "how to deal with Russia, including holding it accountable for its actions", and "how to continue supporting Ukraine and its population".
The convening of this extraordinary European Council occurs on the same day that the Committee of Permanent Representatives of the Governments of the Member States of the European Union definitively adopted the sanctions against Russia approved by the 27 Foreign Ministers, on Tuesday.
PUB
On Tuesday night, the member states' ambassadors to the EU had already given final approval to the list of European sanctions on Russia, which, according to the head of European diplomacy, Josep Borrell, aim to "harm hard" on the Russian authorities, with the package being formally adopted today.
Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu and two private banks in Russia are among those targeted by the sanctions, which cover 27 individuals and entities from the political, military, business and media sectors, as well as around 350 members of the lower house of the Russian parliament (Duma).
Regarding financial sanctions, restrictions are expected on the EU's economic relations with the two separatist regions, Donetsk and Lugansk, as well as the freezing of assets of two Russian private banks and limits on the Russian State's ability to access the EU's capital and financial markets.
The EU's positions come after Russian President Vladimir Putin signed, on Monday night, a decree recognizing the self-proclaimed republics of Lugansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and ordered the mobilization of the Russian army to "maintain peace" in these pro-Russian separatist territories.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.
EU leaders already discussed the crisis in Brussels in person last week, in Brussels, in an informal meeting held immediately before the EU-Africa summit, with the president of the European Council deciding to schedule this summit as a matter of urgency in light of this week's developments, which have increased fears of a large-scale military conflict.

translated_text:
A
Information was provided to the Lusa agency today by European sources following the final confirmation by the Committee of Permanent Representatives of the Governments of the Member States of the European Union to the sanctions approved by the 27 Foreign Ministers, on Tuesday.
According to the same sources, the "approval of the sanctions is confirmed", covering "two Russian banks", as well as the "Russian Minister of Defense".
"The Russian ambassador in Brussels will be informed," they added.
Also according to these European sources, "some countries are asking for Russian oligarchs to be included in the next sanctions", a position that was expressed at the meeting of the committee of representatives.
On Tuesday night, member states' ambassadors to the EU gave final approval to the list of European sanctions on Russia, following Russian recognition of separatist territories in eastern Ukraine.
Confirmation followed today.
Also on Tuesday night, the head of EU diplomacy, Josep Borrell, announced the approval, unanimously among the 27 member states of the community bloc, of a package of sanctions against Russia, aiming to "hit hard" the Russian authorities.
Specifically, the sanctions cover 27 individuals and entities from the political, military, business and media sectors, in addition to around 350 members of the lower house of the Russian parliament (Duma), as Lusa had already advanced.
The Council of the EU explains, in a statement released in the meantime, that "the restrictive measures include an asset freeze and a ban on making funds available to individuals and entities on the list", as well as "a travel ban" to the community space.
Also as Lusa has advanced, with regard to financial sanctions, restrictions are expected on the EU's economic and commercial relations with the two separatist regions, Donetsk and Lugansk, as well as the freezing of assets of two Russian private banks and limits on the Russian State's ability to access the EU's capital and financial markets.
According to the Council, "by restricting the ability of the Russian State and Government to access EU financial and capital markets and services", the aim is to "limit the financing of offensive and aggressive policies".
Today, the President of the European Council, Charles Michel, called an extraordinary summit of EU heads of state and government for Thursday, in Brussels, to discuss the escalation of tension between Ukraine and Russia.
The EU's position comes after Russian President Vladimir Putin signed, on Monday night, a decree recognizing the self-proclaimed republics of Luhansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and ordered the mobilization of the Russian army to "maintain peace" in these pro-Russian separatist territories.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.

Conflict to the east. The minute evolution of the conflict between Russia and Ukraine
by RTP

Viacheslav Ratynskyi - Reuters
Here we follow all developments regarding the growing tension between Russia, Ukraine and the West. Kiev is preparing to declare a state of emergency throughout the territory and is already calling up thousands of military reservists.
More updates
6:35 pm ‚Äì EU very determined to free itself from dependence on Russian gas
This Wednesday, the president of the European Commission assumed that it was essential to invest in a strategy of greater energy independence in order to reduce dependence on gas from Russia as much as possible.
Ursaula Von der Leyen accused Moscow of instrumentalizing the energy issue, but Brussels' objective may be difficult to achieve, as journalist Jo√£o Alexandre says.
6:24 pm ‚Äì President of the European Parliament convenes benches for emergency meeting
European Parliament President Roberta Metsola today scheduled an extraordinary meeting with political party leaders for Thursday due to "dramatic developments in Ukraine", to discuss coordinating the European response to the Russian offensive.
"Considering the latest dramatic developments in Ukraine, President Metsola has called for an extraordinary meeting of the Conference of Presidents [political party leaders] for Thursday morning", announced the office of the leader of the European assembly, in a note sent to Lusa.
Present at the meeting, which takes place in a hybrid format and which will be "an opportunity to exchange views" on the Ukrainian security crisis, will also be the presidents of the European Council, Charles Michel, and the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen.
The meeting is expected to address various aspects of the crisis, including the European Union's condemnation of "Russian aggression against Ukraine, the violation of international law and the Minsk Agreements, the EU's support for the independence and territorial integrity of Ukraine and the rapid adoption of sanctions by the Council", states Roberta Metsola's office in the note.
The meeting also aims to "express solidarity with the people of Ukraine and remember the importance of the continued unity of the EU", he adds.
6:16 pm ‚Äì Analysts anticipate that tension will cause wheat prices to soar
Henrique Tom√©, an analyst at brokerage firm XTB, told the Lusa agency that "both Russia and Ukraine play an important role when it comes to cereal exports on a global scale", with "both countries representing around 30% of exports".
"In the event of an armed conflict, the prices of certain raw materials, in addition to oil and natural gas, could rise substantially. For example, the price of wheat, which in turn will have an impact on food paid by consumers", he explained.
The analyst estimates that wheat "is one of the cereals that could see the biggest rise in prices", highlighting that "prices have already risen by around 9% this year".
6:04 pm ‚Äì Netherlands summons Russian ambassador to The Hague
According to the agency France-Presse (AFP), on Tuesday "the Netherlands actually summoned the Russian ambassador", said a spokeswoman for the Dutch ministry.
"The Netherlands has clearly made it known to the Russian ambassador that Russia's recent actions are unacceptable and will have serious consequences," the spokeswoman added.
Austria, the United Kingdom and Canada also recalled their respective Russian ambassadors on Tuesday.
5:50 pm ‚Äì Guterres denounces Moscow‚Äôs ‚Äúviolations‚Äù and warns that the world faces danger
UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres insisted today that the world faces "a moment of danger" and denounced Russia's "violations" in Ukraine, speaking at the opening of a meeting of the United Nations General Assembly.
"Russia's decision to recognize the so-called 'independence' of the Donetsk and Luhansk regions - and what followed - are violations of the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine and are incompatible with the principles of the United Nations Charter," he said.
The secretary-general's participation was not initially planned for this meeting, which takes place annually, but Guterres decided to participate after canceling a trip to Africa and returning to New York early.
5:47 pm ‚Äì Two Russian convoys with military equipment seen traveling towards Ukraine
Two convoys with military equipment were seen in the last few hours heading to the city of Donetsk, in eastern Ukraine, from Russia.
According to Reuters, one of the convoys brought nine tanks and an infantry fighting vehicle, while the other was made up of trucks and tanks.
5:40 pm ‚Äì Ukraine appears to be preparing for a long war
The question remains about President Vladimir Putin's next move. The Ukrainians do not know whether the Russian military will only stay in the east of the country or whether, on the other hand, they will begin to advance south, thus making a connection with Crimea.
RTP's special envoy in Kiev, C√¢ndida Pinto, noted that Ukraine appears to be preparing for a long war.
Until about a week ago, the population ruled out this possibility and believed that the conflict, as has been the case over the last eight years, would be limited to the Donbass border region.
Now, however, Ukrainians' concerns have risen and many are moving their families out of the country.
5:31 pm ‚Äì Ukraine will only be satisfied ‚Äúwhen the last Russian soldier withdraws‚Äù from its territory
The Ukrainian Foreign Minister said this Wednesday that he will only be satisfied when ‚Äúthe last Russian soldier withdraws from Ukrainian territory‚Äù.
‚ÄúUntil then, I cannot be fully satisfied,‚Äù Dmytro Kuleba explained to journalists.
Asked about the talks with the United States on the last day, the official said that the US gave him ‚Äúthree very clear messages‚Äù.
The first was that ‚Äúthey will support Ukraine no matter what happens‚Äù.
The second message was that the US will continue to provide Ukraine with ‚Äúdefensive weapons so that we can better defend our country ‚Äì but we would be very pleased if we never had to use these weapons on the battlefield, because we want peace,‚Äù Kuleba said.
Finally, Washington conveyed that ‚Äúthere will be more painful sanctions from the United States on Russia, carried out in close coordination with allies in Europe and the rest of the world, in order to guarantee their maximum efficiency‚Äù.
‚ÄúOur partners should not wait for Russian missiles to reach Ukraine or invade our airspace for new sanctions to be imposed,‚Äù said the Ukrainian minister.
5:10 pm ‚Äì Sanctions do not yet worry Russians, but they will have long-term effects
The sanctions announced on the last day by the EU and the USA are not yet worrying the Russians, who consider them ‚Äúmild‚Äù.
Some Russian millionaires had already been warned by Vladimir Putin three years ago that they should not have all their fortune in their names, but rather distributed it among family members.
However, in the long term, middle and lower class Russians will feel the effects of the sanctions on food prices and even their pensions, which will be reduced.
RTP's correspondent in Russia, Evgueni Mouravitch, explains that the Russian state's media outlets should soon begin launching propaganda, persuading residents that Western intrigues are to blame.
4:49 pm ‚Äì One Ukrainian soldier died and another was injured on the eastern front
A Ukrainian soldier was killed today, and another was injured, in a bombing carried out by pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine, the Ukrainian army said.
The Ukrainian Armed Forces did not clarify the exact location of the attack, saying only, in a statement, that one soldier "died from injuries" and another survived, also with injuries during the bombing.
4:37 pm ‚Äì Spain recommends its citizens to leave Ukraine ‚Äúas quickly as possible‚Äù
The Spanish Minister of Foreign Affairs has just recommended that Spaniards in Ukraine temporarily leave that country as quickly as possible.
‚ÄúWe recommend temporarily leaving the country as soon as possible and warn against traveling to Ukraine under any circumstances,‚Äù minister Jos√© Manuel Albares told a parliamentary committee, according to Reuters.

4:15 pm ‚Äì NATO warns that ‚Äúrisk of conflict is real‚Äù
NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg said this Wednesday that ‚Äúthere is a lot at risk in the crisis‚Äù caused by Russia.
"The risk of conflict is real. Russia is using force and ultimatums not only to redraw borders in Europe, but also to try to rewrite the entire global security architecture", he warned in a joint conference with the Dutch Prime Minister.
3:35 pm ‚Äì Russia promises ‚Äústrong response‚Äù to US sanctions
Russia today promised a "strong response" to the sanctions imposed on it by the United States, including restrictions on Russian sovereign debt transactions.
"There should be no doubt that the sanctions will have a strong, not necessarily symmetrical, but considered and sensitive response on the US side," the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement cited by the Spanish agency EFE.
The ministry led by Sergei Lavrov said this was the 101st series of sanctions against Moscow and accused the US of wanting to "try to change Russia's course".
"Despite the obvious futility of efforts made over the years to hinder the development of our economy, the US is once again using restrictive instruments that are ineffective and counterproductive from the point of view of US interests," he said.

3:28 pm ‚Äì Ukrainian banks affected by possible cyber attack
The Ukrainian Minister for Digital Transformation added that several Ukrainian banks were also hit this Wednesday, after several
websites
state-owned companies began to fail this afternoon.

websites
by flooding a network with ‚Äúfake traffic‚Äù, preventing it from operating normally.
3:22 pm - An extraordinary summit of leaders is called for tomorrow in Brussels to discuss the situation in Ukraine
The leaders will discuss how to hold Russia accountable for its actions and increase support for Ukraine and the Ukrainian people.
"It is important that we remain united and determined and that we jointly define our approach and collective actions," said the head of the European Council, Charles Michel, in a statement this Wednesday.
"The use of force and coercion to change borders has no place in the 21st century. I am convening a special European Council for tomorrow [Thursday] in Brussels to discuss the latest developments related to Ukraine and Russia," he announced.
The summit will be held in person and is scheduled for 8pm Brussels (7pm Lisbon).
3:06 pm ‚Äì Ukraine. Government, Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Parliament websites are inaccessible
Various
websites
Ukrainian state-owned companies, including the Government and MNE pages, were inaccessible early Wednesday afternoon. Ukrainian authorities had already this week warned of warnings that
hackers
Russians would be preparing major cyber attacks on government agencies, banks and the Defense sector.
2:59 pm ‚Äì Large-scale invasion is expected to happen ‚Äúin the next 48 hours‚Äù
According to information collected by US authorities and transmitted to Ukrainian officials, Russia is preparing to launch a large-scale invasion of the country "in the next 24 hours".
"The president of Ukraine has been warned that Russia will likely launch an invasion within 48 hours," a US official told the US magazine
Newsweek
.
2:27 pm ‚Äì ‚ÄúObscene perversion.‚Äù Australia criticizes Moscow for saying Russian soldiers in Ukraine are "peacekeeping forces"
During a visit to Prague, Czech Republic, the Australian Foreign Minister said it was "an obscene perversion" to classify Russian troops in Ukraine as peacekeeping forces.
"President Putin's claim that Russian soldiers are acting as peacekeepers is an obscene perversion of the noble and vital role that several generations of peaceful forces have played around the world," he said.
Marise Payne also added that Canberra will not hesitate to impose more sanctions if Russia worsens the situation further.
"Any suggestion that there is a legitimate basis for Russia's actions is pure propaganda and disinformation," he further stated.
2:14 pm - Erdogan on the phone with Putin: "Turkey will not recognize any measure that affects the territorial integrity of Ukraine"
Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan spoke on the phone with Vladimir Putin this Wednesday to guarantee that Turkey will not recognize measures that affect Ukraine's territorial integrity.
"Turkey will not recognize any measures that affect the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine," the Turkish presidency said.
In this phone call, Erdogan also repeated the Turkish offer to mediate the conflict and help find a diplomatic solution, according to Erdogan's office.
"President Erdogan, who renewed the call for the problem to be resolved through dialogue, stated that it is important to put diplomacy at the forefront and that Turkey also maintains a constructive stance within NATO", adds the Turkish leader's office.
2:11 pm ‚Äì Ukraine demands immediate ‚Äúsecurity guarantees‚Äù from the West and Moscow
The Ukrainian president demanded this Wednesday "security guarantees" for the country. "Ukraine needs clear and concrete security guarantees immediately," from both the West and Russia, said the Ukrainian head of state.
1:45 pm ‚Äì In case of war, Ukraine will ask Turkey to close Russia‚Äôs access to the Black Sea
Ukraine views the presence of Russian warships near its Black Sea borders as a threat and will ask Turkey to consider closing two access routes for Russian ships in the event of an invasion.
The information was confirmed this Wednesday by the Ukrainian ambassador to T√ºrkiye, Vasyl Bodnar. It asks Ankara to close access to the "aggressor state" in the event of an open conflict.
Turkey borders Ukraine and Russia across the Black Sea. The country, a member of NATO, opposes the sanctions applied to Moscow, but considers that Russian recognition of the Ukrainian republics as independent is an unacceptable measure.
1:32 pm - Poland and Lithuania argue that Ukraine deserves EU candidate status due to current security challenges
Warsaw and Vilnius made a joint statement this Wednesday calling for Ukraine to be recognized as a candidate to join the European Union.
The declaration was signed by Polish President Andrzej Duda, Lithuanian counterpart Gitanas Nauseda and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenski and mentions the "current security challenges" facing Ukraine.
In addition to asking for European Union candidate status for Kiev, the three leaders call on the international community for a "rapid introduction" of "robust" sanctions against Russia.
1:29 pm - "Future of European security" is being decided in Ukraine, says Zelensky
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said this Wednesday that "the future of European security" is being decided in Ukraine, a country where an imminent Russian invasion is feared.
"We are united in the conviction that the future of European security is being played out in our home right now. In Ukraine", declared Zelensky when receiving Polish and Lithuanian representatives in Kiev.
12:56 pm ‚Äì United Kingdom will provide more military support to Ukraine
The United Kingdom will provide Ukraine with more military support, including defense weapons, according to British Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
"In light of Russia's increasingly threatening behavior and in line with our previous support, the UK will soon provide a further package of military support to Ukraine. This will include lethal aid in the form of defensive weapons and non-lethal aid," Johnson announced in the UK Parliament this Wednesday.
12:46 pm - Permanent Committee of the AR will debate Ukraine with MNE on Thursday
The Minister of Foreign Affairs will be heard at the Permanent Committee of the Assembly of the Republic on Thursday about the situation in Ukraine, the conference of leaders confirmed today.
12:27 pm ‚Äì Half of Russians support war so that Ukraine stays out of NATO
One
poll revealed today by CNN
concludes that half of the Russians surveyed agree with the use of force to prevent Ukraine from joining NATO. The survey was carried out by the company Savanta ComRes and concluded that only 25% of Russians believe that it would be wrong to resort to the army against Kiev.
Another 25% are not sure what the best option is to resolve the current crisis.
12:12 pm ‚Äì Russian Defense Minister is one of the targets of EU sanctions
A new package of EU sanctions against Russia is expected to be announced this Wednesday.
According to the British newspaper
The Guardian
, Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu and the commanders-in-chief of the Russian Air Force and the Black Sea Fleet are expected to be targeted by new sanctions, along with the 351 State Duma deputies.
12:05 pm ‚Äì In Portugal, natural gas consumers will experience an ‚Äúinevitable‚Äù increase in prices, admits the Minister of the Environment
Speaking to journalists this Wednesday morning, the Minister of Environment and Climate Action, Jo√£o Matos Fernandes, admitted that those who directly consume natural gas will experience an "inevitable" increase in prices due to the situation in Ukraine.
"Those who directly use natural gas will feel this increase because it is inevitable, Portugal does not set this price, it is the price of a 'commodity' [raw material], which is fixed at a global level", he said.
Even though around 35% of electricity in Portugal is generated from natural gas, the government official recalled that this is a price increase at the source that does not mean an increase for consumers.
"Those who are in the regulated market will not feel this increase, but especially industrial producers, despite the effort the Government made to ensure there were almost no increases, admittedly have shorter contracts and, therefore, this risk [of price increases] exists", added the minister.
The increase in natural gas prices is expected to be driven by Germany's decision to interrupt the certification process for the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, which would distribute Russian gas directly to the country.
11:46 am ‚Äì The lines of action in Kiev: call up reservists, declare an emergency, protect citizens on Russian territory
During the morning of this Wednesday, the Ukrainian authorities adopted a set of measures to protect citizens.
In summary:
- Parliament is expected to approve in the next few hours
the declaration of a state of emergency throughout the territory.
The decision follows a recommendation from the Security and Defense Council of Ukraine.
- The state of emergency must be in force
for at least 30 days and allows the Government to adopt exceptional decisions
, such as the imposition of mandatory curfews.
- At least
36 thousand Ukrainian military reservists aged between 18 and 60 have already started to be called up
. These soldiers will have to serve for one year.
- With the imminent escalation of the conflict,
Kiev calls on all Ukrainian citizens to leave Russia.
There are around three million, according to estimates.
11:31 am ‚Äì Ukraine prepares to declare a state of emergency
The BBC reports this morning that Kiev is preparing to declare a state of emergency in the country following a decision by the country's Security and Defense Council. The decision will still have to be approved in Parliament.
In the same sense, the newspaper
The Guardian
quotes Alexei Danilov, secretary of the council, who indicated to journalists that the state of emergency will be declared throughout Ukraine, except in the regions of¬†Luhansk and Donetsk, where it has been in force for several years.
The state of emergency is expected to last 30 days and allows the Government to establish restricted control in the territory, including movement restrictions and mandatory curfews.
Alexei Danilov also confirms that the country is already calling up the first 36 thousand military reservists.
11:22 am ‚Äì EU and US launch sanctions against Russia. What are the targets?
The US announced a set of sweeping economic sanctions on Russia on Tuesday night for what President Joe Biden called ‚Äúthe start of a Russian invasion of Ukraine‚Äù. The European Union also approved a package of sanctions to ‚Äúaffect Russia‚Äù.
Get to know
here
the most relevant sanctions that have already been announced.
11:13 am ‚Äì China accuses the US of creating ‚Äúfear and panic‚Äù about the situation in Ukraine
The spokesperson for the Chinese MNE, Hua Chunying, stated that China is opposed to new unilateral sanctions imposed on Russia and accuses the United States of fueling tension in Ukraine.
"Unlike the US, which continues to send weapons to Ukraine, creating fear and panic and reinforcing the threat of war, China asks all parties to respect and listen to each other's legitimate security concerns", highlights the official.
Beijing also calls on all countries to work together to resolve the situation through negotiations and diplomacy, in order to maintain regional peace and stability.
11:07 am ‚Äì Taiwan condemns sending Russian troops to separatist territories
Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen condemns Russia for ordering troops to be sent to pro-Russian separatist territories.
"Our government condemns Russia's violation of Ukraine's sovereignty (...) and calls on all parties to continue resolving conflicts through peaceful and rational means," Tsai said.
Taiwan, which is also under threat of annexation by neighboring China through the use of force, is closely watching the crisis in Ukraine.
Still, Tsai described Taiwan and Ukraine as being "fundamentally different in terms of geostrategy, geographic environment and importance of international supply chains", in reference to the island's status as one of the main pillars of the world economy, mainly due to the semiconductor industry.
10:25 am ‚Äì Satellite photographs show movements near the border
Maxar Technologies, a US space technology company, has published several satellite images showing new troop and equipment movements in Russia and more than 100 vehicles in southern Belarus. That is, in all places close to the borders of Ukraine.
10:17 am ‚Äì Parliament in Kiev authorizes Ukrainians to carry firearms and act ‚Äúin self-defense‚Äù
The Ukrainian parliament just passed a bill this morning that gives Ukrainians permission to carry firearms and act in self-defense.
‚ÄúThe adoption of this law is entirely in the interests of the State and society‚Äù, say the authors of the bill.
They consider that this law is necessary due to ‚Äúthe existing threats and dangers for the citizens of Ukraine‚Äù.
10:11 am ‚Äì UN General Assembly debates situation in Ukraine
The United Nations General Assembly will debate the situation ‚Äúin the temporarily occupied territories‚Äù in Ukraine this Wednesday. The meeting starts at 3:00 pm (10:00 am in New York).
9:33 am ‚Äì Ukrainian appeal. "Hit harder. Hit hard. Hit now"
The appeal comes from the Ukrainian Foreign Minister, who asks the West to apply heavier sanctions against Vladimir Putin's close circle.
"To stop Putin from carrying out more aggression, we ask our partners to impose more sanctions on Russia now. Yesterday the first decisive steps were taken and we are grateful for them. Right now, the pressure needs to increase to stop Putin. Hit his economy and his cronies. Hit harder. Hit hard. Hit now," wrote Dmytro Kuleba on Twitter.
To stop Putin from further aggression, we call on partners to impose more sanctions on Russia now. First decisive steps were taken yesterday, and we are grateful for them. Now the pressure needs to step up to stop Putin. Hit your economy and chronicles. Hit more. Hit hard. Hit now.
‚Äî Dmytro Kuleba (@DmytroKuleba)
February 23, 2022
9:28 am ‚Äì Pope Francis appeals for peace
The supreme pontiff spoke this Wednesday about the situation in Ukraine, stating that the possibility of a conflict in the country causes him ‚Äúa great pain in his heart‚Äù.
At the end of the weekly audience from the Vatican, Francis asks the leaders involved to examine their conscience and refrain from actions that could further increase human suffering in the region.
9:15 am ‚Äì Ukraine asks citizens to leave Russia
Ukraine on Wednesday asked its citizens not to visit Russia and warned any Ukrainians already in the country to leave immediately.
"The Ministry of Foreign Affairs recommends that citizens of Ukraine refrain from any travel to the Russian Federation, and those in this country leave the territory immediately," read a statement in Russian.
The MNE says the "intensification of Russian aggression against Ukraine" means it will not be able to offer consular assistance to Ukrainians in Russia.
The measure could affect the approximately 3 million Ukrainian citizens living in Russia.
9:00 am ‚Äì Ukrainian reservists begin to be called up
Kiev began mobilizing reserve defense force members aged between 18 and 60, following a decree from Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zekensky.
The military says that the maximum period of service will be one year and recruits with specific skills, such as mechanics, will be sent to specialized units.
Authorities add that anyone who ignores the summons could face charges of ‚Äúcriminal liability.‚Äù
According to estimates, there are about 900 thousand people as potential military personnel in the reserve defense forces in Ukraine.
Status point
On Monday, Russian President Vladimir Putin recognized the independence of Donetsk and Lugansk in eastern Ukraine. For the Kremlin, these are two pro-Russian separatist regions that do not want to be part of Ukraine.
Russian President Vladimir Putin's decision is being seen as opening the door to a large-scale invasion of Ukraine.
In the last few hours, the US Secretary of State, Antony Blinken, canceled the meeting he had planned for Friday with his Russian counterpart, Sergei Lavrov.
The person responsible for North American diplomacy stated that the invasion was Vladimir Putin's plan since the beginning of a ‚Äúmanufactured‚Äù crisis.
At this press conference, Blinken also announced that the possibility of a summit between President Joe Biden and his Russian counterpart had been taken off the table.
‚ÄúNow that we see that the invasion has begun, Russia has made clear its total rejection of diplomacy, so it makes no sense to move forward with this meeting at this time,‚Äù he explained.
However, on Tuesday, US President Joe Biden announced sanctions against Russia. These sanctions will target Russian banks and sovereign debt, as well as prominent members of the Russian ‚Äúelite.‚Äù
Dmytro Kuleba, MNE of Ukraine, welcomed the sanctions, but considers that they are not enough to discourage Putin. From Washington, alongside Blinken, Kuleba considered that the US must help the country in a more determined way, especially because the future of the world order ‚Äúis now being decided in Ukraine‚Äù.
In turn, Russian President Vladimir Putin indicated this Wednesday that there is still room for diplomacy, but that Moscow's interests and security are "non-negotiable".
"Our country is always open to direct and honest dialogue to find diplomatic solutions to the most complex problems. "However, the interests and security of our citizens are not negotiable for us," said Vladimir Putin in a televised speech.
Sanctions
Even earlier, the United Kingdom and the European Union also announced similar sanctions to the USA, as well as Australia, Canada and Japan. Of all these countries and the various sanctions announced, the highlight goes to Germany, which suspended the certification of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline and to the United Kingdom, which targeted five Russian banks and three oligarchs with the announced sanctions.
The European Union also applied a package of sanctions against Moscow, which affects ‚Äú351 members of the Duma [lower house of the Russian Federal Assembly] who approved this violation of the territorial integrity of Ukraine‚Äù.
It will also apply to 27 individuals and entities with a ‚Äúthreatening role for the independence of Ukraine‚Äù, announced Borrell.
Regarding financial sanctions, restrictions are expected on the EU's economic relations with the two separatist regions, Donetsk and Lugansk, as well as the freezing of assets of two private Russian banks.

translated_text:
World
President of the European Parliament convenes benches for emergency meeting
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
18:20
0
Comments
Photo:¬† EPA/JOHANNA GERON
European Parliament President Roberta Metsola today scheduled an extraordinary meeting with political party leaders for Thursday due to "dramatic developments in Ukraine", to discuss coordinating the European response to the Russian offensive.
"Considering the latest dramatic developments in Ukraine, President Metsola has called for an extraordinary meeting of the Conference of Presidents [political party leaders] for Thursday morning", announced the office of the leader of the European assembly, in a note sent to Lusa.
Present at the meeting, which takes place in a hybrid format and which will be "an opportunity to exchange views" on the Ukrainian security crisis, will also be the presidents of the European Council, Charles Michel, and the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen.
The meeting is expected to address various aspects of the crisis, including the European Union's condemnation of "Russian aggression against Ukraine, the violation of international law and the Minsk Agreements, the EU's support for the independence and territorial integrity of Ukraine and the rapid adoption of sanctions by the Council", states Roberta Metsola's office in the note.
The meeting also aims to "express solidarity with the people of Ukraine and remember the importance of the continued unity of the EU", he adds.
Roberta Metsola, who has been very critical of the Russian offensive and active in defending Ukrainian sovereignty, will participate on Thursday night in the extraordinary summit of heads of state and government of the European Union, also called today, to discuss the escalation of tension between Ukraine and Russia.
The convening of this extraordinary European Council occurs on the same day that the Committee of Permanent Representatives of the Governments of the Member States of the European Union definitively adopted the sanctions against Russia approved on Tuesday by the 27 Foreign Ministers.
On Tuesday night, the member states' ambassadors to the EU had already given their approval to the list of European sanctions on Russia, which, according to the head of European diplomacy, Josep Borrell, aim to "harm hard" on the Russian authorities, with the package being formally adopted today.
Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu and two private banks in Russia are among those targeted by the sanctions, which cover 27 individuals and entities from the political, military, business and media sectors, as well as around 350 members of the lower house of the Russian parliament (Duma).
Regarding financial sanctions, restrictions are expected on the EU's economic and commercial relations with the two separatist regions, Donetsk and Luhansk, as well as the freezing of assets of two Russian private banks and limits on the Russian State's ability to access the EU's capital and financial markets.
The EU's positions come after Russian President Vladimir Putin signed, on Monday night, a decree recognizing the self-proclaimed republics of Lugansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and ordered the mobilization of the Russian army to "maintain peace" in these pro-Russian separatist territories.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.

translated_text:
World
UN Charter "is not an '√† la carte' menu" and Russia must apply it throughout
Lusa Agency
Feb 22, 2022
23:04
0
Comments
Photo Facebook UN
The principles of the "United Nations Charter are not an '√† la carte menu'" and Russia must "apply them all" in relation to Ukraine, UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres said today, criticizing the Kremlin's position.
"[The principles of the Charter] cannot be applied selectively. All member states have accepted them and everyone must apply them", insisted Guterres, reaffirming that Moscow's recognition of the "so-called independence" of the Ukrainian separatist regions, Donetsk and Lugansk, is "a violation of the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine".
In a strong speech, the UN Secretary-General also said that "when troops from one country enter the territory of another country without its consent, they cannot be considered impartial peacekeeping forces", and as such "they are not peacekeeping forces", an expression used by Russian President Vladimir Putin to justify Russian military intervention in the separatist "republics".
"Let me be clear: the decision of the Russian Federation to recognize the so-called 'independence' of certain areas of the Donetsk and Luhansk regions is a violation of the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine," he stressed.
On the same day that the United States, the European Union, the United Kingdom and other countries announced sanctions against Russian individuals and entities, Ant√≥nio Guterres also said that the recognition of separatist territories "is a fatal blow to the Minsk Agreements approved by the Security Council" of the United Nations.
Asked if he considered whether there was "genocide" underway in eastern Ukraine, as Vladimir Putin stated, the UN Secretary General rejected this idea.
"I don't think that's the case," he said, noting that "genocide is a clearly defined crime."
"At this critical moment, I call for an immediate ceasefire and the restoration of the rule of law. It is high time to resume the path of dialogue and negotiations", argued Ant√≥nio Guterres.
The President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, stated today that the deployment of Russian troops to the Donbass region, in eastern Ukraine, will depend on the situation on the ground, where clashes "continue" and tend to worsen.
At a press conference in which he also called for international recognition of Russia's sovereignty over Crimea, the Ukrainian peninsula that Moscow annexed in 2014, Putin said that everything will depend on the development of events and the "situation on the ground".
The Russian President, who was speaking after being authorized by the Senate to send Russian troops out of the country, stated that the fighting in the conflict zone "continues" and tends to worsen.
"I didn't say that the troops will go there now, right away", the Russian leader told journalists, adding that at this moment it is "impossible" to predict what will happen and everything will depend on the "concrete situation on the ground".

Russia promised a "strong response" to the sanctions imposed on it by the US
Photo:¬†EPA/ALEXEI NIKOLSKY/KREMLIN

Russia promised this Wednesday a "strong response" to the sanctions imposed on it by the United States, including restrictions on Russian sovereign debt transactions, due to Moscow's recognition of the independence of separatist territories in Ukraine.
"There should be no doubt that the sanctions will have a strong response, not necessarily symmetrical, but considered and sensitive on the side of the
USA
", said the
Ministry of Foreign Affairs
Russian in a statement cited by the Spanish agency EFE.
The United States of America (USA),
United Kingdom
, Canada,
European Union
(EU),
Australia
and
Japan
imposed or announced sanctions against
Russia
for its recognition of the independence of Donetsk and Lugansk, and the announcement of a possible deployment of Russian soldiers to these two territories in eastern Ukraine.
The ministry led by Sergei Lavrov said this was the 101st series of sanctions against Moscow and accused the
USA
of wanting to "try to change the course of
Russia
".
"Despite the obvious futility of efforts made over the years to hinder the development of our economy,
USA
are once again using restrictive instruments that are ineffective and counterproductive from the point of view of the interests of
USA
", he said.
PUB
For Moscow's diplomacy, the
Russia
has demonstrated that it is capable of minimizing damage, despite all the costs of sanctions.
"Moreover, the pressure of sanctions cannot affect our determination to firmly defend our interests," he said.
The ministry accused the
USA
of being "trapped by the stereotypes of a unipolar world with the false conviction" that "they still have the right and can impose their own rules of world order on everyone."
From this perspective, he continued, "in the arsenal of North American foreign policy" there are "no other means left than blackmail, intimidation and threats".
"With regard to world powers, especially the
Russia
and other key international actors, this doesn't work," he said.
In view of the sanctions policy, the
Russia
is open "to diplomacy based on the principles of mutual respect, equality and consideration of each other's interests", the Russian Foreign Ministry added.
The President of the USA,
Joe Biden
, announced direct economic sanctions against two important Russian financial institutions, VEB (one of the country's main investment and development banks) and the PSB military bank, which is considered critical to Russia's defense sector.
Biden also approved sanctions against the country's sovereign debt
Russia
to block Moscow's access to Western financing.
A day earlier, he signed an executive order prohibiting new investment, trade and other economic transactions by U.S. institutions and citizens in
Donetsk
and
Lugansk
.
The measure aims to isolate the two regions from the dollar-based international financial system.
The recognition of the independence of Donetsk and Luhansk by the Russian President,
Vladimir Putin
, on Monday, drew condemnation from most Western countries, after around two months of tension due to the concentration of tens of thousands of Russian troops near the borders of
Ukraine
.
Moscow-backed pro-Russian separatists from Donetsk and Luhansk went to war with Ukrainian authorities in 2014 following Russia's annexation of the Crimean peninsula.
Since then, the conflict has caused more than 14,000 deaths and displaced 1.5 million people, according to the United Nations.

translated_text:
O
A survey carried out by the company Savanta ComRes among citizens of Ukraine and Russia concludes that only 25% of Russians believe that it would be wrong to use the army against Ukraine, while another 25% are unsure about the best option to resolve the current crisis.
The survey reveals that 43% believe that it would be a mistake to "reunify", through force, Russia and Ukraine, two countries with a long and complicated history of intertwined relations, but 36% do not believe that this is a bad option.
North American television reports that among Ukrainians the majority refuse to use force by Russia. Of those surveyed, 70% said it would be incorrect for Russia to use military force to prevent Ukraine from joining NATO or to unify the two countries (73%).
Among all those who responded to the survey in Ukraine, and of all ages, there was a majority consensus on not feeling like "one people", together with Russians, and in defense of the existence of two countries.
In Ukraine, an average of 28% of respondents agree with the idea that Russians and Ukrainians are "one people", while this average rises to 65% for Russian respondents.
Only 21% of Ukrainians anticipate a peaceful end to tensions with Russia, compared to 65% of Russians.
The survey also points out that only 26% of Ukrainians expect a military defense of Ukraine by NATO or the United States, and consider it more likely that there will be economic sanctions against Russian leaders (46%) or Russian companies (34%).
The survey, carried out among more than a thousand people in each country (1,021 in Russia and 1,075 in Ukraine) was carried out online between February 7th and 15th, before Vladimir Putin's speech on Monday and Moscow's recognition of the independence of the Ukrainian separatist territories of Donbass (Donetsk and Lugansk).
On Tuesday, Russian authorities clarified that the recognition refers to territory occupied when the self-proclaimed republics announced the status in 2014, which includes space currently held by Ukrainian forces.
Russian President Vladimir Putin also announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those pro-Russian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
However, Ukraine ordered the mobilization of military reserves to reinforce the army.

Denis Pushilin, leader of the separatist region of Donetsk, stated that, for now, there are no Russian troops in the territory, but said that the documents he signed allow him to request help from Moscow.
Denis Pushilin is the leader of the self-proclaimed separatist republic of Donetsk in eastern Ukraine

The leader of the self-proclaimed separatist republic of Donetsk, in eastern Ukraine, admitted asking Russia for military help in the event of Ukrainian aggression, taking advantage of Moscow's recognition of its territorial claims.
"At the moment there are no Russian troops here. But, in the event of a Ukrainian aggression, this is possible. The documents we signed allow us to request this help", said Denis Pushilin, leader of the separatist region of Donetsk, today during a press conference, quoted by the Russian agency Interfax.
On Tuesday, Russia's Federation Council (Senate) gave Russian President Vladimir Putin 'carte blanche' to openly intervene in the conflict in eastern Ukraine, authorizing him to use armed forces outside Russia's borders.

Putin has already clarified that the recognition of the self-proclaimed separatist republics of Donetsk and Luhansk, in eastern Ukraine, announced on Monday, includes the admission of territory in these two provinces that still remains under Kiev's control.
"The situation is such that the enlargement of the Donetsk and Luhansk people's republics to their historical borders can be resolved by itself, but we prefer it to be by peaceful means," Pushilin said.
Separatist leader says Donetsk city was hit by rocket fire
The pro-Russian separatist leader assured that, at the moment, the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic is not considering that objective.
"We are not at that stage yet. We are at a stage where rival troops are on the line of contact and at any moment they can go on the offensive. We haven't resolved that yet," explained Pushilin.
The leaders of the two self-proclaimed separatist provinces, Donetsk and Lugansk, denounced this Wednesday the intensification of attacks by Ukrainian forces against the cities they control.
According to Pushilin, for the first time in a long time, the city of Donetsk was hit by rocket fire, and pro-Russian separatists in Lugansk accused the Ukrainian army of attacking 12 locations with artillery.
The authorities in Kiev, in turn, hold the separatists responsible for violations of the ceasefire, which have increased considerably in recent days, at a time when Moscow ordered the withdrawal of all diplomatic personnel from Ukrainian territory and Ukraine ordered the mobilization of military reserves to reinforce the army.
Moscow-backed pro-Russian separatists from Donetsk and Luhansk went to war with Ukrainian authorities in 2014 following Russia's annexation of the Crimean peninsula.
Since then, the conflict has caused more than 14,000 deaths and displaced 1.5 million people, according to the United Nations.

translated_text:
"There should be no doubt that the sanctions will have a strong, not necessarily symmetrical, but considered and sensitive response on the US side," the Russian Foreign Ministry said in a statement cited by the Spanish agency EFE.
The United States of America (USA), the United Kingdom, Canada, the European Union (EU), Australia and Japan have imposed or announced sanctions against Russia for its recognition of the independence of Donetsk and Lugansk, and the announcement of a possible deployment of Russian soldiers to these two territories in eastern Ukraine.
The ministry led by Sergei Lavrov said this was the 101st series of sanctions against Moscow and accused the US of wanting to "try to change Russia's course".
"Despite the obvious futility of efforts made over the years to hinder the development of our economy, the US is once again using restrictive instruments that are ineffective and counterproductive from the point of view of US interests," he said.
For Moscow's diplomacy, Russia has demonstrated that it is capable of minimizing damage, despite all the costs of sanctions.
"Moreover, the pressure of sanctions cannot affect our determination to firmly defend our interests," he said.
The ministry accused the US of being "trapped by stereotypes of a unipolar world with the false conviction" that "it still has the right and can impose its own rules of world order on everyone."
From this perspective, he continued, "in the arsenal of North American foreign policy" there are "no other means left than blackmail, intimidation and threats".
"When it comes to world powers, especially Russia and other key international actors, this doesn't work," he said.
In view of the sanctions policy, Russia is open "to diplomacy based on the principles of mutual respect, equality and consideration of each other's interests", added the Russian Foreign Ministry.
US President Joe Biden announced direct economic sanctions against two important Russian financial institutions, VEB (one of the country's main investment and development banks) and the PSB military bank, which is considered critical to Russia's defense sector.
Biden also approved sanctions against Russia's sovereign debt to block Moscow's access to Western financing.
A day earlier, he signed an executive order prohibiting new investment, trade and other economic transactions by US institutions and citizens in Donetsk and Luhansk.
The measure aims to isolate the two regions from the dollar-based international financial system.
The recognition of the independence of Donetsk and Luhansk by Russian President Vladimir Putin on Monday drew condemnation from most Western countries, after around two months of tension due to the concentration of tens of thousands of Russian troops near Ukraine's borders.
Moscow-backed pro-Russian separatists from Donetsk and Luhansk went to war with Ukrainian authorities in 2014 following Russia's annexation of the Crimean peninsula.
Since then, the conflict has caused more than 14,000 deaths and displaced 1.5 million people, according to the United Nations.

I sincerely hope that there will be no escalation of the conflict in Ukraine. Also because war is a bit boring and so on, but more because, at the moment, Donald Trump is not president of the United States of America. And what does
communicates
social tion had promised was that it would be
donald trump
, as soon as he was elected, to declare as the first measure of his mandate the
start of the Third World War. Therefore, my appeal to the conflicting parties in Ukraine is this: hey man, calm down. Calm down, wait until 2024 to confirm whether Trump runs again and wins, and then, yes, fight there as you please.
Anyway, there will be those who say that Trump would never go to war with Russia because he is Putin's friend. So much so that throughout his term there were even strong suspicions that Trump was a Russian spy. It is true that it was that type of strong, highly unfounded suspicion, fueled by a very strong disinformation campaign, carried out by a very strong social media in deception. But it doesn't matter. Were there suspicions, or were there not? There was. And there is no point in pointing out that Putin took advantage of Obama's presidency to annex Crimea and Biden's presidency to invade Ukraine, having been very quiet during Trump's presidency. Yes, because the most likely thing is that Putin and Trump took advantage of the latter's years of presidency to celebrate the annexation of Crimea and plan the invasion of Ukraine.
No, seriously now. What is happening in Ukraine is quite simple. It's so simple that even I can explain it. There is an individual, Sh√¥r Putin, who wants to expand his empire. Since Russia is a somewhat shy country. And how does he intend to do it? Taking advantage of the moments when they are in the White House, either presidents who, on their days off from promoting hysteria around global warming, acquire mansions next to the beach on the island of Martha's Vineyard, like Obama, or presidents who, because they have been here long enough to remember the Little Ice Age, have difficulty remembering their own name, let alone Putin's name. Whoever deciphers a Mafu label deciphers this.
But this issue was joined by a new problem. That the United States has a dictatorial regime to the south of its territory ‚Äì Cuba ‚Äì is a fact known to everyone. What we discovered these days is that also in the north of the USA, in Canada, there is a desire to establish a Castro-inspired regime, led by Justin Trudeau. Trudeau, who even knelt at a demonstration of the
Black Lives Matter
As a sign of support for this movement, it is now resorting to a state of emergency to demobilize truck drivers in protest against vaccine mandates. Now, it is the case that, alongside the ‚Äúmostly peaceful‚Äù manifestations of
Black Lives Matter
‚Äì in which the majority of people minus twenty-odd individuals survived, and in which the majority of infrastructure minus property worth two billion dollars did not suffer any damage ‚Äì this demonstration by Canadian truckers is a manifestation of Mother Teresas of Calcutta. After taking a dose of Valium. With valerian tea. At the end of a Hatha Yoga session (Google says it is one of the best Yoga variants to combat stress).
Despite everything, Canadian truck drivers do not seem to have any intention of abandoning their positions. By the way, do you know who Canadian truck drivers remind me of? Rui Rio. Who is also not going anywhere. The man will not leave the leadership of the PSD even if Trudeau sends the
Real Pol
there
Canadian Mounted Company
there
. Rui Rio doesn't leave and that's it. While Chic√£o stopped wanting to lead the CDS when the party ended, Rui Rio does not want to stop leading the PSD until the party ends.

British Prime Minister Boris Johnson corrected, this Wednesday, a previous statement in Parliament regarding the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, clarifying that Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich is not subject to UK sanctions.
During the announcement of a package of sanctions on five Russian banks and three businessmen considered close to the President,
Vladimir Putin
,
Boris Johnson
he was questioned by the opposition because he did not extend the measures to other so-called oligarchs. The Prime Minister wrongly said that "Abramovich is already subject to sanctions", but today he formally clarified that "
Roman Abramovich
was not the target of targeted measures."
The owner of the Chelsea football club, who in 2021 obtained Portuguese nationality through the law that benefits the descendants of Sephardic Jews expelled at the end of the 15th century, until four years ago had an investor visa in the
United Kingdom
.
Abramovich has since obtained an Israeli passport and, although he cannot live or work in
United Kingdom
, you can cross the border without needing a tourist visa.
In 2018, he withdrew his application for renewing his British visa due to the diplomatic conflict between the
United Kingdom
and
Russia
following the poisoning of former spy Sergei Skripal with a neurotoxic agent in
England
.
At the time, then-Prime Minister Theresa May ordered a reassessment of the visas granted to hundreds of "Russian oligarchs" in the country, but the "golden visa" scheme was only ended last week.
PUB
According to the organization openDemocracy, since 2015, 202 of those visas have been granted to Russian billionaires who have invested at least two million pounds (2.4 million euros) each in British companies, also benefiting more than 250 family members.
On Tuesday, the British Government announced sanctions against the "oligarchs" Gennady Timchenko, Boris Rotenberg and the latter's nephew, Igor Rotenberg, whose assets in
United Kingdom
were frozen, in addition to being banned from entering the country. He also ordered the freezing of the assets of Bank Rossiya, Black Sea Bank, IS Bank, Genbank and Promsvyazbank and said he was ready to move forward with more financial sanctions.
Boris Johnson
is under pressure from the opposition and members of his party to toughen sanctions against
Russia
, which recognized on Monday as independent the two separatist Ukrainian territories of
Donetsk
and
Lugansk
, in the region of
Donbass
, worsening the military situation in the region.
Moscow
It also created legal conditions for sending Russian military personnel to the area, a situation that repeats the invasion of Ukraine in 2014, when it annexed the Crimean peninsula.
