translated_text:
World
British PM corrects that Roman Abramovich is not subject to sanctions
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
18:38
0
Comments
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson today corrected a previous statement in Parliament regarding the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, clarifying that Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich is not subject to UK sanctions.
During the announcement of a package of sanctions on five Russian banks and three businessmen considered close to President Vladimir Putin, Boris Johnson was questioned by the opposition why he did not extend the measures to other so-called oligarchs.
The Prime Minister wrongly said that "Abramovich is already subject to sanctions", but today he formally clarified that "Roman Abramovich was not the target of targeted measures".
The owner of the Chelsea football club, who in 2021 obtained Portuguese nationality through the law that benefits the descendants of Sephardic Jews expelled at the end of the 15th century, had an investor visa in the United Kingdom until four years ago.
Abramovich has since obtained an Israeli passport and, although he cannot live or work in the UK, he can cross the border without needing a tourist visa.
In 2018, he withdrew his request to renew his British visa due to the diplomatic conflict between the United Kingdom and Russia following the poisoning of former spy Sergei Skripal in England with a neurotoxic agent.
At the time, then-Prime Minister Theresa May ordered a reassessment of the visas granted to hundreds of "Russian oligarchs" in the country, but the "golden visa" scheme was only ended last week.
According to the organization openDemocracy, since 2015, 202 of those visas have been granted to Russian billionaires who have invested at least two million pounds (2.4 million euros) each in British companies, also benefiting more than 250 family members.
On Tuesday, the British Government announced sanctions against "oligarchs" Gennady Timchenko, Boris Rotenberg and the latter's nephew, Igor Rotenberg, whose assets in the United Kingdom were frozen, in addition to being banned from entering the country.
He also ordered the freezing of the assets of Bank Rossiya, Black Sea Bank, IS Bank, Genbank and Promsvyazbank and said he was ready to move forward with more financial sanctions.
Boris Johnson is under pressure from the opposition and members of his party to tighten sanctions against Russia, which on Monday recognized the two separatist Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Luhansk, in the Donbass region, as independent, worsening the military situation in the region.
Moscow also created legal conditions for sending Russian military personnel to the area, a situation that repeats the invasion of Ukraine in 2014, when it annexed the Crimean peninsula.

Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu and two private Russian banks are among those targeted by European Union sanctions on Moscow following President Vladimir Putin's recognition of separatist territories in eastern Ukraine.
The information was provided to the Lusa agency by European sources this Wednesday, after the final confirmation by the Committee of Permanent Representatives of the Governments of the Member States of the European Union to the sanctions approved by the 27 Foreign Ministers, on Tuesday.
According to the same sources, the "approval of the sanctions is confirmed", covering "two Russian banks", as well as the "Russian Minister of Defense". "The Russian ambassador in Brussels will be informed," they added.
Also according to these European sources, "some countries are asking for Russian oligarchs to be included in the next sanctions", a position that was expressed at the meeting of the committee of representatives.
On Tuesday night, member states' ambassadors to the EU gave final approval to the list of European sanctions on Russia, following Russian recognition of separatist territories in eastern Ukraine. Confirmation followed today.
Also on Tuesday night, the head of EU diplomacy, Josep Borrell, announced the approval, unanimously among the 27 member states of the community bloc, of a package of sanctions against Russia, aiming to "hit hard" the Russian authorities.
PUB
Specifically, the sanctions cover 27 individuals and entities from the political, military, business and media sectors, in addition to around 350 members of the lower house of the Russian parliament (Duma), as Lusa had already advanced.
The Council of the EU explains, in a statement released in the meantime, that "the restrictive measures include an asset freeze and a ban on making funds available to individuals and entities on the list", as well as "a travel ban" to the community space.
Also as Lusa has advanced, with regard to financial sanctions, restrictions are expected on the EU's economic and commercial relations with the two separatist regions, Donetsk and Lugansk, as well as the freezing of assets of two Russian private banks and limits on the Russian State's ability to access the EU's capital and financial markets.
According to the Council, "by restricting the ability of the Russian State and Government to access EU financial and capital markets and services", the aim is to "limit the financing of offensive and aggressive policies".
Today, the President of the European Council, Charles Michel, called an extraordinary summit of EU heads of state and government for Thursday, in Brussels, to discuss the escalation of tension between Ukraine and Russia.
The EU's position comes after Russian President Vladimir Putin signed, on Monday night, a decree recognizing the self-proclaimed republics of Luhansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and ordered the mobilization of the Russian army to "maintain peace" in these pro-Russian separatist territories.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.

British Prime Minister Boris Johnson this Wednesday corrected a previous statement in Parliament regarding the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, clarifying that Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich is not subject to UK sanctions.
During the announcement of a package of sanctions on five Russian banks and three businessmen considered close to President Vladimir Putin, Boris Johnson was questioned by the opposition why he did not extend the measures to other so-called oligarchs.
The prime minister wrongly said that ‚ÄúAbramovich is already subject to sanctions‚Äù, but this Wednesday he formally clarified that ‚ÄúRoman Abramovich was not the target of targeted measures‚Äù.
Who are the senior Russian Defense positions that the European Union will sanction?
The owner of the Chelsea football club, who in 2021 obtained Portuguese nationality through the law that benefits the descendants of Sephardic Jews expelled at the end of the 15th century, had an investor visa in the United Kingdom until four years ago.
PUB
‚Ä¢ CONTINUE READING BELOW
Abramovich has since obtained an Israeli passport and, although he cannot live or work in the UK, he can cross the border without needing a tourist visa.
In 2018, he withdrew his request to renew his British visa due to the diplomatic conflict between the United Kingdom and Russia following the poisoning of former spy Sergei Skripal in England with a neurotoxic agent.
At the time, then-Prime Minister Theresa May ordered a reassessment of the visas granted to hundreds of ‚ÄúRussian oligarchs‚Äù in the country, but the ‚Äúgolden visa‚Äù scheme was only ended last week.
According to the organization openDemocracy, since 2015, 202 of those visas have been granted to Russian billionaires who have invested at least two million pounds (2.4 million euros) each in British companies, also benefiting more than 250 family members.
On Tuesday, the British Government announced
sanctions against ‚Äúoligarchs‚Äù Gennady Timchenko, Boris Rotenberg and the latter's nephew Igor Rotenberg
, whose assets in the United Kingdom were frozen, in addition to being banned from entering the country.
He also ordered the freezing of the assets of Bank Rossiya, Black Sea Bank, IS Bank, Genbank and Promsvyazbank and said he was ready to move forward with more financial sanctions.
Boris Johnson is under pressure from the opposition and members of his party to tighten sanctions against Russia, which on Monday recognized the two separatist Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Luhansk, in the Donbass region, as independent, worsening the military situation in the region.
Moscow also created legal conditions for sending Russian military personnel to the area, a situation that repeats the invasion of Ukraine in 2014, when it annexed the Crimean peninsula.

Ukraine is being targeted by a "massive" cyberattack, Digital Transformation Minister Mikhail Fyodorov said this Wednesday. The main websites of the Kiev Government and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs are below.
The government official announced that the cyber attack began this afternoon and affected several banks and official websites, without specifying its origin. However, most of Ukraine's main news websites were working, as were the websites of banks and the country's main public institutions.
Fyodorov said the working sites were able to "switch traffic to another service provider in order to minimize damage."

Ukraine/Russia war scenario will trigger energy and wheat
One of the main effects of a possible armed conflict will be on the price of natural gas, with a consequent impact on electricity rates for companies and families.
Freezing natural gas exports could cause problems for the Russian economy in the medium term.
¬©¬†Natalia KOLESNIKOVA / AFP
Diogo Ferreira Nunes
23¬†February,¬†2022¬†‚Ä¢¬†07:05
Share
this article
Facebook

Email

Comment
Nearly four thousand kilometers separate Lisbon from Kiev, but the distance may be insufficient for Portugal not to feel the effects of a war scenario between Ukraine and Russia. In Dinheiro Vivo, three economists anticipate what could happen to the national and international economy if tension in Eastern Europe worsens.
"In a conflict of this scale, no one wins. In the short term, the biggest impact could be on energy prices, especially gas and oil", points out Filipe Garcia, economist at IMF-Informa√ß√£o de Mercados Financeiros.
Paulo Rosa recalls that the Russians supply 35% of natural gas to Europe and are one of the world's main wheat producers. "If the situation worsens, we could have less wheat on the market, which would end up affecting the price of bread and cereals", fears the senior economist at Banco Carregosa.
The possible decrease in natural gas shipments could also have effects on the electricity market. "As the markets are global, this is reflected in Portugal and in the prices of access to energy by companies and families", highlights the economist and president of Endesa Portugal, Nuno Ribeiro da Silva.

The engineer also recalls that gas "is the main source of revenue" for Russia. In the short term, the reduction in supply to central Europe could "give an advantage" to the country led by Vladimir Putin. In the medium term, however, "European countries are alert not to trust Russia as a supplier and to invest more in their energy independence, particularly through renewable sources".
If the conflict worsens, there could also be effects on the European economy. "The inflation rate could continue to rise, instead of slowing down, hindering the economic recovery", warns the senior economist at Banco Carregosa.
On stock markets, the effects will not be as severe. "Share markets have been fragile mainly due to a possible withdrawal of stimulus to the economy by central banks", understands Filipe Garcia.

translated_text:
D
uring the announcement of a package of sanctions on five Russian banks and three businessmen considered close to President Vladimir Putin, Boris Johnson was questioned by the opposition why he did not extend the measures to other so-called oligarchs.
The Prime Minister wrongly said that "Abramovich is already subject to sanctions", but today he formally clarified that "Roman Abramovich was not the target of targeted measures".
The owner of the Chelsea football club, who in 2021 obtained Portuguese nationality through the law that benefits the descendants of Sephardic Jews expelled at the end of the 15th century, had an investor visa in the United Kingdom until four years ago.
Abramovich has since obtained an Israeli passport and, although he cannot live or work in the UK, he can cross the border without needing a tourist visa.
In 2018, he withdrew his request to renew his British visa due to the diplomatic conflict between the United Kingdom and Russia following the poisoning of former spy Sergei Skripal in England with a neurotoxic agent.
At the time, then-Prime Minister Theresa May ordered a reassessment of the visas granted to hundreds of "Russian oligarchs" in the country, but the "golden visa" scheme was only ended last week.
According to the organization openDemocracy, since 2015, 202 of those visas have been granted to Russian billionaires who have invested at least two million pounds (2.4 million euros) each in British companies, also benefiting more than 250 family members.
On Tuesday, the British Government announced sanctions against "oligarchs" Gennady Timchenko, Boris Rotenberg and the latter's nephew, Igor Rotenberg, whose assets in the United Kingdom were frozen, in addition to being banned from entering the country.
He also ordered the freezing of the assets of Bank Rossiya, Black Sea Bank, IS Bank, Genbank and Promsvyazbank and said he was ready to move forward with more financial sanctions.
Boris Johnson is under pressure from the opposition and members of his party to tighten sanctions against Russia, which on Monday recognized the two separatist Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Luhansk, in the Donbass region, as independent, worsening the military situation in the region.
Moscow also created legal conditions for sending Russian military personnel to the area, a situation that repeats the invasion of Ukraine in 2014, when it annexed the Crimean peninsula.

Five questions and answers to understand the conflict between Russia and Ukraine
The deployment of troops to Ukraine's borders raised alarms in the West. How did we get here and what military power do the two countries have in the event of an invasion?
Facebook
Twitter
Linkedin
email
07:16 February 23, 2022
16:09 February 23, 2022
|
Ana Luisa Monteiro
Tension between Ukraine and Russia has been increasing day by day. Vladimir Putin had Senate authorization to send Russian troops out of the country. The West responded with sanctions and the US ordered a new movement of troops into the Baltic.
It is important to know how we got here, what Putin's motivations are, what happened in the pro-Russian separatist territories and what the military power of the two countries is.
Why did Putin send military personnel to the border?
Since the end of the Cold War, NATO has expanded to the East, incorporating 14 new countries, including three countries from the former Warsaw Pact, the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland, and three others that were part of the Soviet Union ‚Äì Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia.
Russia viewed the accession of these countries, some whose territories are contiguous to Russia, as you can see on the map, as an imminent danger to its borders.
Ukraine is not a member of NATO, but has been committed since 2008 to possible membership.
Since the fall of pro-Russian Ukrainian President V√≠ktor Yanukovych in 2014, Ukraine has moved closer politically to the West. It carried out joint military exercises with NATO and received weapons from the United States and drones from Turkey.
Kiev and the US see these maneuvers as legitimate moves to strengthen Ukraine's defense after the Crimea crisis in 2014. However, Putin sees Ukraine's rapprochement with NATO as dangerous. According to the Russian President, NATO can use Ukrainian territory to attack Moscow and, therefore, has defended red lines to avoid an attack.
It was based on these arguments that Putin sent thousands of soldiers to the border between the two countries, denying, however, that he was preparing an invasion of Ukraine. The Russian President claimed that the deployment of Russian troops is a response to threats and provocations. Vladimir Putin wants to ensure that Ukraine does not join NATO.
The United States estimates that, at this time, Russia likely has¬†between 169,000 and 190,000 troops deployed¬†in and along Ukraine's border.
What could have motivated Putin to move forward now?
Putin, who called the dissolution of the Soviet Union the greatest geopolitical catastrophe of the last century, dedicated his presidency to restoring Moscow's influence throughout the post-Soviet space, challenging the West and trying to reaffirm Russia as a global power.
Putin's public statements about Ukraine suggest that his actions are not only motivated by political moves, but also by personal convictions. Ukraine has been involved in the highs and lows of Putin‚Äôs Presidency ‚Äì the pro-Western revolutions in 2004 (the so-called ‚Äúcolor revolutions‚Äù) and 2014 (with the fall of the pro-Russian Ukrainian President) were blows to Russian interests, but the seizure of Crimea was presented by Putin as a historic victory.
After 22 years as Russia's leader, some analysts believe Putin may be reflecting on his legacy and trying to close unfinished business with Ukraine.
What's going on in Donetsk and Lugansk?
The Russian President signed a decree this Monday
recognize independence
from two breakaway regions in eastern Ukraine ‚Äì Donetsk and Lugansk, known as Donbass. These regions proclaimed themselves independent republics in 2014 and broke away from the control of the Ukrainian government.
Since then, Ukraine says that around 15,000 people have been killed in fighting in these territories, with the separatists being supported by the Moscow regime. The United Nations (UN) also reiterated that the conflict has already claimed 13 thousand lives, including more than three thousand civilians.
(Photo by ANATOLII STEPANOV/AFP via Getty Images)
Russia, however, denies being part of the conflict, but has secretly supported the separatists with military equipment, financial aid, issuing passports and even anti-covid-19 vaccines.
This was the first time that Russia did not consider Donbass to be part of Ukraine.
International agencies said that Russian troops entered Donbass this Monday night. The decrees signed by the President of Russia order the mobilization of the Army to the pro-Russian separatist territories in eastern Ukraine for ‚Äúpeacekeeping‚Äù.
Putin had already recognized the independence of two breakaway regions of Georgia ‚Äì Abkhazia and South Ossetia ‚Äì after fighting a short war with the country in 2008. The Russian President provided extensive financial support to the regions and extended Russian citizenship to the population.
How can sanctions hit Russia?
This Tuesday, the
President of the United States announced sanctions
to Russia. Joe Biden reported that he will apply sanctions to Russia and Russian political elites, which go ‚Äúbeyond what the allies implemented in 2014‚Äù, in addition to blocking the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, decided together with Germany.
O
United Kingdom
got the ball rolling: five Russian banks (Rossiya, IS Bank, General Bank, Promsvyazbank and Black Sea Bank) will be targeted by sanctions. Bank Rossiya has already been under US sanctions since 2014 for its close ties to Kremlin officials.
The British are also targeting three Russian oligarchs. Gennady Timchenko and billionaires Igor and Boris Rotenberg, whose fortunes grew dramatically after Putin's rise to power, will also be targeted by sanctions. The three men are already sanctioned by the US.
The European Union has also given final approval to the list of European sanctions on Russia, following Russian recognition of separatist territories in eastern Ukraine, the French presidency of the Council announced.
Specifically, the approved sanctions cover 27 individuals and entities from the political, military, business and media sectors, in addition to around 350 members of the lower house of the Russian parliament (Duma).
Regarding financial sanctions, restrictions are expected on the EU's economic relations with the two separatist regions, Donetsk and Lugansk, as well as limits on the Russian State's ability to access the EU's capital and financial markets, specified Josep Borrell.
(AP)
Canada has also announced a ‚Äúseries‚Äù of sanctions. It will prohibit citizens from carrying out any transactions to the pro-Russian separatist territories, it will impose sanctions on Russian parliamentarians who voted in favor of the ‚Äúillegal decision to recognize the territories‚Äù and it will prohibit the population from participating in purchases of Russian debt.
What is Russia's military power in relation to Ukraine's?
The Ukrainian Armed Forces are heavily outnumbered by Russia. However, military experts believe that Ukrainian forces would be able to resist and inflict casualties if Russia decided to invade the country.
Ukraine's army is better equipped and better trained than in 2014, when Russia captured the Crimean peninsula from Ukraine without a fight. Ukrainian soldiers are also seen as highly motivated to defend the heartland of the country.
According to data from IISS, the International Institute for Strategic Studies, Russia has 900,000 active military personnel, while Ukraine only has 196,000 active military personnel.
Also in the Navy, there is an imbalance between the two countries. Russia has 74 warships and 51 submarines. Ukraine has only two warships.
Regarding the Air Force, Putin has ten times more tankers and helicopters at his disposal than Ukraine.
In reserve ‚Äì those who have received military training in the last five years ‚Äì Ukraine has 900,000 soldiers and Russia has two million.
According to
Sky News
, some analysts believe that a Russian attack on Ukraine would take place with long-range weaponry. And, once again, Russia has the advantage: the country has more than 500 ballistic missile launchers.
Several countries in the European Union, the United States and the United Kingdom have provided military aid and weapons to Ukraine to improve its ‚Äúdefensive capacity‚Äù.

During the ceremony, the head of state observed a minute of silence and then presided over the parade of the Kremlin Guard of Honor.
In a congratulatory film for the military, Putin highlighted that the Armed Forces are the guarantee of Russia's national security and development.
"We see that the international situation is not at all simple, we see the dangers posed by existing challenges, such as the weakening of arms control systems or the military activity of the NATO bloc," said Putin.
The President pointed out that in recent years (Russia) has done a lot to modernize the Armed Forces, which has made it possible to demonstrate that the military is capable of "fulfilling the most complex missions".
"We will continue to develop innovative weapons systems, including hypersonic (weapons) based on new principles," he said.
According to the Russian President, these are, "in fact, weapons of the future that will increase the combative potential" of the Russian Armed Forces several times over.
Marking February 23 in Russia is a tradition that dates back to the communist regime of the former Soviet¬†Union.
The history of the date begins in 1922, when Soviet leaders proposed celebrating the fourth anniversary of the creation of the Red Army and Navy.
The decree on the organization of the two military branches dates back to January 23, 1918, the day on which the first volunteers for the Red Army and Navy were enlisted.
The date was then officially named Red Army Day and continued to be marked after the fall of the Soviet Union.
This year, the day is marked in the same week that the Kremlin announced the recognition of the self-proclaimed pro-Russian separatist republics in eastern Ukraine, at war with Kiev since 2014, and at the same time that thousands of Russian troops are located along the Ukrainian border, including on Belarusian territory.

Tensions between Russia and the West have economic implications.

Tensions between Russia and the West have economic implications.
The 6 shocks that the conflict in Ukraine will cause to the¬†economies
Text of
Edgar Caetano
,
Beatriz Ferreira
,
Ana Suspiro
,
Alexandra Machado
and
Ana Martingo
More expensive oil, natural gas and cereals; inflation (even) more worrying; banking vulnerable to ‚Äúserious disruption‚Äù; underestimated risks in stock markets? Here are the 6 shocks that conflict can cause.
Feb 23, 2022, 9:55 pm
Index
Index
You have free access to all Observador articles by being our subscriber.
A war conflict always has an impact on the economy. This tension between Russia and the West, regarding Ukraine, is no exception. But economists are saying that everything will depend on the size of the conflict or the level of sanctions and, of course, how long it lasts. The armed intervention creates new shocks, not yet calculated. We could be facing ‚Äúa war between Russia and Ukraine that would be a human tragedy and, possibly, the greatest threat to global security since the Cuban missile crisis in 1962‚Äù, considers Holger Schmieding, from the Berenberg bank.
One thing seems consensual. This escalation of the conflict, which will imply more severe sanctions on Russia ‚Äî and further closure of the Russian economy and global impact ‚Äî will have a first obvious implication: prices will continue to rise, particularly due to the effect of the increase in natural gas and oil tariffs, which already reached 100 dollars this Thursday and should continue at that level, even surpassing that milestone. And a worsening of energy prices drags down other sectors.
Food items can also be affected. After all, Ukraine is called the breadbasket of the world for a reason. And so, although no one is yet pointing out a shortage, higher prices are already anticipated, especially because, in Portugal, there is a period of drought.
Inflation, which has already been rising ‚Äî in the Euro Zone it reached 5.1% in January ‚Äî was being the reason for intervention by central banks. But now the prospect of the conflict having an impact on economic growth could mix things up. March is a decisive month for decisions at the North American Federal Reserve (Fed) and the European Central Bank. Money police are once again key.
PUB
‚Ä¢ CONTINUE READING BELOW
‚ñ≤
Germany blocked certification of Nord Stream II that would bring more gas from Russia to the European Union
dpa/picture alliance via Getty I
Energy. Portugal is far from the eye of the storm, but it does not escape expensive prices
The energy crisis is at the forefront of the impacts of the escalation in Ukraine. For now, the repercussions are felt in prices: of natural gas, but even more so of oil, worsening an increase that has already occurred in recent months due to the economic recovery and increasing pressure on the prices of food products and services. But the big concern has more to do with supply. Russia supplies 40% of Europe's gas and Putin has assured that it will continue to do so. But, in past conflicts, it did not hesitate to use gas as a weapon, reducing supplies to some countries in the sphere of the former Soviet Union, which in turn had an impact on central European states.
In this crisis, Europe is better prepared to respond to possible disruptions or failures in supply and the supplier diversification strategy is being managed at the level of the European Commission. But although some countries such as the United States are available to reinforce exports, taking advantage of high prices to do business, there are several limitations, starting with gas transport and distribution infrastructure ‚Äî the ships that bring liquefied gas to Europe and the gas pipelines that transport it across the continent.
Portugal, together with Spain, could be part of the solution, since the Iberian Peninsula has eight liquefied natural gas terminals whose capacity far exceeds the needs of both markets, but the weak interconnection with France does not allow Iberia to be an alternative, as the authors of a publication published on the
think
tank
Bruegel with the title: ‚Äú
Can Europe survive without pain if it does not have Russian gas‚Äù?
Still, the answer to this question will not be the same, now when winter is coming to an end, as it would be, for example, in autumn, a period when demand for natural gas is greater, anticipating winter. Considering that Europe went through a less cold winter, Bruegel analysts consider that the European economy could withstand significant cuts in the supply of Russian gas, albeit with some pain: reducing industrial demand (with the suspension of production by large producers) or demand from the electricity sector.
Portugal is little exposed to Russian gas and has secured the supply it needs, at least for now, as the Secretary of State for Energy told the Observer. Jo√£o Galamba recognizes, however, that the economy cannot escape the risk of higher prices that will affect not only gas, but also the electricity that is generated from gas and which has been largely responsible for the record prices reached in the wholesale market even before the Ukrainian crisis.
Jo√£o Galamba on the gas crisis. ‚ÄúWe are protected in volume, the main risk is the price‚Äù and it will reach electricity
The exposure of the Portuguese economy to the price of natural gas could be further aggravated due to the ongoing drought, which is affecting the production of electricity from dams, forcing the use of more thermal plants, which in the national case could mean the need for greater gas consumption. Portugal no longer has coal plants ‚Äî and Russia is also a major supplier of this ore ‚Äî and in the event of a lack of gas, it could always in theory resort to a petroleum derivative to operate thermal plants, which has never happened.
This year, the Government approved the reinforcement of strategic reserves of natural gas for industrial and domestic consumption and for the electricity sector.
Agriculture. The ‚Äúbreadbasket of Europe‚Äù from which Portugal buys 18% of the cereals it consumes
The list of the main products exported by Ukraine helps to explain why the country has earned the nickname, over the last decade, ‚Äúthe breadbasket of Europe‚Äù. According to data from the Observatory of Economic Complexity (created at MIT, in the USA), corn is the main product exported by the country (in 2019, in a volume equivalent to 4.77 billion dollars), with seed oils appearing in second place and wheat in fourth.
The imminence of a conflict was already making markets nervous and the signs are also beginning to be evident in the case of cereals.
According to Bloomberg
,¬†hard red winter wheat futures contracts in the Chicago market reached 2012 highs, rising 2.3% this Wednesday after a 6% jump on Tuesday. All for
heightened tension and concern about possible constraints on the Ukrainian and Russian markets, which will now be more pressing with the escalation of the conflict
. In fact, the two countries represent practically a quarter of global wheat exports.
With possible constraints on switching back to importers, ‚Äúthe price could easily double‚Äù, said Carlos Mera, from the Dutch¬†Rabobank, to
The Wall Street Journal
. But even a minor conflict, which does not go far beyond the border, could increase prices, already pressured by the pandemic.
The problem is made worse because the Ukrainian regions that produce the most wheat, as well as the ports that transport the grain to some of the main destinations, are located close to the pro-Russian separatist zones. The Wall Street Journal recalls, by the way, that when Russia annexed Crimea in 2014, wheat prices soared by around 25% in two months due to concerns about possible interruptions in supplies originating in the Black Sea.
It turns out that, according to the US Department of Agriculture,
95% of Ukraine's wheat exports are transported through the Black Sea
, whose activity may be conditioned by a conflict in the region. The main importers of Ukrainian cereals ‚Äî Egypt (15%), China (11.3%) and Spain (9.81%) in 2019 ‚Äî may end up having to look for alternatives, as well as many countries in the Middle East and North Africa that depend on imported cereals to feed the population.
The problem for Portugal ‚Äî which only receives 1.74% of the cereals exported by Ukraine, but which has Ukraine as its main source of corn ‚Äî will be if these alternatives are some of the sources of supply for the Portuguese market. The consequence may, here too, be the
price increase
. According to data from the Observatory,
Ukraine is the second main country to supply Portugal with cereals (18.4%)
, after France (20.7%) and before Brazil (14.6%).
In the case of corn, the problem could be more serious. Portugal has Ukraine as its main corn supplier, purchasing 40.1% of the corn it consumes from that country. Data from the National Statistics Institute (INE) reveals, in fact, that Portugal imported more than 152 million euros in cereals from Ukraine in 2021.
To the Observer, the secretary general of the National Association of Stockists, Traders and Importers of Cereals and Oilseeds (ACICO), Jos√© Miguel Ascens√£o, argued that, if a conflict occurs, combined with a worsening of Western sanctions, in the cereals sector the most affected markets in Portugal will be, precisely, wheat and corn.
‚ÄúNaturally, the interruption of imports from the Black Sea will have a
immediate repercussions on the prices and availability of these products
and others of this origin,
like barley, sunflower
, etc.‚Äù, he observes.
The effect can, by drag, reach the prices of bread, meat, milk and eggs
.¬†‚ÄúThis interruption of imports from this source, combined with all the logistical problems that have occurred since 2020 and 2021 worldwide, availability of ships and freight costs, will have a profound impact on the prices and availability of raw materials with a corresponding impact on the prices of bread, meat, milk and eggs‚Äù, he states.
ACICO does not foresee, for now, that there will be a shortage of cereals in Portugal. Jos√© Miguel Ascens√£o notes, however, that the cereals purchased from Ukraine and Russia are mainly intended for animal feed. Alternative sources would be other exporting countries such as the USA, Brazil, Argentina, South Africa and Australia.
Not only buyers from Ukraine can feel the shrapnel of a conflict. Russia completes the top 5 of its exports, precisely, with wheat. In the early 1980s, together with corn, wheat represented two-thirds of US exports to the USSR (Soviet Union). With the collapse of the Soviet bloc, the country removed barriers to business, allowing producers to enter international markets and invest in technology. Now, Russia is the world's main exporter of wheat (Ukraine, according to the Observatory, is the fifth).
And who does Russia export wheat to? Especially for Egypt (31.3%), Turkey (17%) and Bangladesh (6.44%). Specifically in Europe, it is Latvia that benefits most from Russian wheat exports, before Belarus and Greece.
In the Portuguese case, cereals are only the 11th most imported product from Russia. First come ‚Äúmineral fuels, mineral oils and products of their distillation; bituminous materials; mineral waxes‚Äù, as well as ‚Äúcast iron, iron and steel‚Äù and ‚Äúfish and crustaceans, molluscs and other aquatic invertebrates‚Äù.¬†Portugal's exports, in turn, should not be strongly affected by possible disruptions in Ukraine and Russia, in general. The two countries are not in the top 10 of business partners.
Financial system. Direct exposure isn't great, but SWIFT can be a problem
The international financial system's relations with Russia have reduced in recent years, with most Western banks reducing their exposure to the country and its companies, in the context of the sanctions that were applied to it after the annexation of Crimea (in 2014). Since then, the US and Europe have sought to limit the access of Russian banks and companies to the Western financial system ‚Äì as well as some individuals being ‚Äúblacklisted‚Äù ‚Äì which has led to
Today, direct connections are not very significant
.
Second
data from the Bank for International Settlements
(better known by the Anglo-Saxon acronym BIS), banks
Italy
,
France
and
Austria
are those that have the greatest exposure to Russia, with the first two banks having an exposure equivalent to 25 billion dollars (each) and the Austrian ones 17.5 billion.
All of these countries have banks with a presence in Russia (including UniCredit and Soci√©t√© G√©n√©rale), which explains why they concentrate a large part of the country's global exposure ‚Äì which, according to the BIS, is equivalent to 121.5 billion dollars.
Portuguese banks, according to the same data, have an exposure of 149 million
.
The Observer questioned the main banks in Portugal about the degree of exposure to Russia (and Ukraine). O
BPI
responded that ‚Äúthe bank does not have any direct or indirect exposure to Russian and/or Ukrainian assets‚Äù, in the same vein as what the
Caixa Geral de Dep√≥sitos
. Already the
MillenniumBCP
, which has an important presence in Poland, indicated that ‚Äúthe Millennium group does not have relevant exposure to the aforementioned geographies‚Äù, that is, Russia and Ukraine. O
New Bank
did not respond until the publication of this work.
National banks have 132 million euros in Russia
This Wednesday, the
Bloomberg agency
reported that the ECB is asking eurozone banks to make a kind of ‚Äú
stress test
‚Äù ‚Äì in other words, banks that have exposure to Russia must scrutinize their own balance sheets to estimate the impact of possible diplomatic or even military scenarios.
For now, the
new sanctions applied by the European Union
this Wednesday include limitations on the access of Russian companies and banks to European capital markets ‚Äì whether for participation in the primary market (issuance or purchase of new securities) or in the secondary market (transaction of existing securities). But sanctions could worsen and the conflict could bring new problems.
And then, the main fear is related to the impact that could be on global payment systems. The leader of
Financial Stability Board
, a kind of financial supra-regulator created by the G20, warned at the end of last week that the
The West has to ‚Äúthink twice‚Äù before imposing tougher sanctions on Russia, but there is already talk of this possibility.
Quoted by
Financial Times
,
Klaas Knot
stressed that if Russia is vetoed from the
SWIFT
, the system that is the ‚Äúheart‚Äù of global payments, this ‚Äúcould result in a
serious disruption in payment flows ‚Äì we always have to think twice
and be aware of the consequences.‚Äù
‚ñ≤
Klaas Knot, leader of the Financial Stability Board, warns of what could happen if Russia's access to the SWIFT payments system is blocked.
AFP/Getty Images
Blocking access by Russian companies and banks to SWIFT (acronym for Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication) is one of the possible sanctions that have been admitted by the USA. ‚Äú
It is obvious that this could have some financial ramifications and I challenge policymakers to take these ramifications into consideration
‚Äù, warned Klaas Knot, who is also governor of the central bank of the Netherlands and, therefore, sits on the Governing Council.
The official recalled that there have been military conflicts in the past which, contrary to fears, ended up not having a major impact on financial systems ‚Äì but warned that, if the conflict assumes greater proportions, there will be a
risk of repercussions ‚Äúvery, very difficult to predict‚Äù
because it is not possible to anticipate ‚Äúthe degree of loss of confidence we will have in the markets, how much risk aversion will increase, how many investors will start to flee certain markets, etc‚Äù.
The risk to inflation. O
timing
It couldn't be worse for central banks
Economists tend to think that the direct impact of the conflict on economies and the financial system may be manageable, unless we are talking about a large-scale armed confrontation. But it will be enough for the conflict to drag on for a few weeks or months to
worsen inflationary pressures
that have already tormented the West in recent months (and that have kept central bank officials up at night).
In addition to the likely increases in some food items, the consultancy Capital Economics estimates that, in the worst case scenario, the price of oil could rise to between 120 and 140 dollars. Something that, if it happens, would add up to two percentage points to the inflation rates that are predicted for developed economies, especially in Europe (which already has consumer price indices above 5%).
‚ÄúIn normal times, central banks would tend to ignore a rise in inflation that was caused by such a rise in energy prices, but given the high rates that already exist ‚Äì which raise fears that they will take root in inflation expectations ‚Äì it is possible that this will be
yet another cause for concern for central bank officials
, putting more pressure on them to raise interest rates.‚Äù
On the other hand, the ECB has already included geopolitical risks among those that justify the monetary authority being more cautious in normalizing its policy. In other words, it is a factor that creates instability in economies and financial markets, therefore, the ECB may be even more afraid of moving towards a faster rise in interest rates or a withdrawal of other stimuli that the central bank has in progress, including sovereign debt purchases.
Interest rates threaten the pockets of the Portuguese. Euribor could rise above zero as early as June
In anticipation of the next (and decisive) central bank meeting, scheduled for March 10, one of the most influential members of the ECB ‚Äì the French
Fran√ßois Villeroy de Galhau
‚Äì he said this Wednesday
that the risks associated with the conflict in Ukraine will be analyzed at this central bank summit meeting, including the possible indirect consequences for the eurozone.
This conflict, he argued, shows that at this stage ‚Äì ‚Äúmore than ever‚Äù ‚Äì the ECB must maintain great ‚Äúflexibility‚Äù and ‚Äúoptionality‚Äù in the way it conducts monetary policy. ‚Äú
We will assess the more indirect consequences for inflation and growth at the March Council ‚Äì and we will be guided by the facts
‚Äú, he stated.
But if persistent inflation in Europe has unpredictable consequences, putting pressure on family budgets across the continent, this increase in raw materials could be socially explosive in countries like Egypt and Turkey, a region of the globe that imports the majority of these cereals from Russia and Ukraine and that has already experienced times of exchange rate and economic instability.
Capital market. Stock markets are not yet reflecting (all) possible bad news
The main world stock markets are having a terrible start to 2022, with the US stock market (measured by the S&P 500 index) skidding more than 10% and, therefore, entering what is called ‚Äú
correction ground
‚Äú. This correction must be read in light of the fact that the same index soared by almost 27% in 2021, however, it is evidence that the stock markets entered the new year more nervous, mainly due to the fact that higher and more persistent inflation than expected generated fears of faster monetary tightening (by central banks).
A
Geopolitical instability, in this context, is throwing more fuels on the fire, worsened by the escalation of the conflict.
European stock markets had a ‚Äúblack‚Äù session on Monday, reacting to the news that Russia had recognized the territories of Donbass and Luhansk (and sent ‚Äúpeacekeeping‚Äù forces there). It was on Tuesday morning that oil prices climbed very close to the 100 dollar threshold, at their highest levels since September 2014, and this Thursday they once again touched that territory, in which they are expected to remain now that one of the main exporters of black gold is in armed conflict and suffering economic sanctions that have not yet reached these products.
After the negative Monday, since mid-morning on Tuesday, investors' fears seemed to have eased a little, with the stock exchanges recovering some ground and even the price of
gold
had corrected some of the gains made thanks to the refuge movement and risk aversion among investors ‚Äì which led the precious metal to surpass 1,900 dollars per ounce. However, the start of the military operation by Russia this Thursday made the markets react downwards.
This Thursday, European stock markets opened sharply lower and the Moscow stock market began with a historic drop of more than 30%, after having already lost a similar amount in a week.
Putin advances to ‚Äúspecial military operation‚Äù. Ukraine imposes martial law and sirens have sounded in Kiev
‚ÄúMost of the correction that stock markets have seen since the beginning of the year can be attributed to the prospect of interest rate hikes by the world's most important central banks,‚Äù says Capital Economics, adding that ‚Äúthis suggests that,
If the conflict worsens, there is still significant downside potential for global equity markets
‚Äù, and an increased appetite for safe-haven assets like US Treasury debt or gold.
‚ñ≤
‚ÄúIf the conflict worsens, there is still a significant downside potential for global equity markets,‚Äù warns Capital Economics.
JUSTIN LANE/EPA
Furthermore, it could lead to a reversal of the trend that has been seen so far on stock markets this year, which has seen European markets performing better than US stock markets, concludes Capital Economics. In the same vein, Goldman Sachs estimated that in a war scenario the US stock market could fall by 6% and
European shares up more than 9%
.
‚ñ≤
Paolo Gentiloni, European Commissioner, has already warned about energy prices
STEPHANIE LECOCQ/EPA
GDP. Economic recovery threatened?
The European Commission has revised downwards estimates for European growth this year. It did so in February, cutting the growth outlook for the Euro Zone and the European Union from 4.3% to 4% in 2022. And it warned, from the outset, that the risks in growth projections are worsened by geopolitical tensions. In the winter projections, the European Commission did not openly mention the Russia/Ukraine conflict, but that was what everyone was thinking about, and it never spoke of a war scenario.
In the same sense was the analysis of the European Central Bank, which in the economic bulletin highlighted that ‚Äúalthough uncertainties regarding the pandemic have decreased, geopolitical tensions have increased‚Äù, even highlighting that ‚Äúpersistently high energy costs may have a stronger impact than expected on consumption and investment‚Äù.
Despite the reduced economic interconnection at a commercial level (as a whole) between Russia and the European Union, it is certain that there are fuels that mess up the accounts, not least because the impact on price increases could put a question mark on the economic recovery, leaving more room for discussion within central banks, particularly the ECB.
Half of Russia's exports go to the European Union (in particular to its neighbors to the East) ‚Äì which has China as its second largest trading partner, with a weight of 14%. Conversely, the European Union imports 5% of Russia's goods. As signed by the
think tank
Brugel, ‚ÄúRussia is much more vulnerable to trade shocks than the EU.‚Äù
However, as Jason Furman, a Harvard economist who was an advisor to President Barack Obama, points out, quoted by The News York Times, ‚ÄúRussia is a surprisingly unimportant player in the global economy, with the exception of the oil and gas sector‚Äù, which leads him to define Putin's country as ‚Äúbasically a large gas station‚Äù. Europe obtains almost 40% of its natural gas from Russia, in addition to 25% of its oil and oil products. And this is where tensions in Russia/Ukraine lead to questions about the European and even global economic future.
In recent days, oil, natural gas, corn, wheat, aluminum and nickel ‚Äî some of Russia's main exports to the world ‚Äî have risen in price and have seen gains, since the beginning of the year, on average of around 20%. Prices may rise further not only for fuel but also for food and other raw materials.
Still emerging from the pandemic and economies recovering from aggressive confinements, the world was already assimilating the rise in prices and the disruptions in supply chains, two impacts that are now exacerbated by tensions to the east. And they can be more or less serious depending on the evolution of the conflict and sanctions.
V√≠tor Const√¢ncio, former governor of the Bank of Portugal, used Twitter to make his analysis: ‚ÄúThe complete package of sanctions will harm Russia's economy, but it will greatly harm Western economies, especially in Europe‚Äù.
The full package of sanctions will cripple Russia‚Äôs economy, but it will greatly hurt the West economies, mainly in Europe. Facing a limited annexation, will European unity stand for the full sanctions? The US has been silent about the sanctions¬¥ calibration in that case 3
pic.twitter.com/zeQv46AuIM
‚Äî Vitor Const√¢ncio (@VMRConstancio)
February 22, 2022
The Russian economy was already being penalized by the sanctions enacted since 2014 when it annexed Crimea.
The IMF estimated
, in 2015, a loss of 1% to 1.5% in Russian GDP, in the short term, with the sanctions applied, adding, however, that longer sanctions could lead to a reduction in Russia's product of 9%, as well as less capital accumulation and technological transfer. Capital Economics now says that the relatively mild sanctions that have been announced could remove around 1% from the Gross Domestic Product (GDP), but
the economic shock could be much greater if there are tougher sanctions ‚Äì cutting access to the SWIFT system could take 5% off Russian GDP.
Russia's long-term economic prospects ‚Äúare already quite weak, with a rapidly aging population and an economy that depends on fossil fuel extraction and little integration into global value chains‚Äù, notes Bruegel, adding that ‚Äúthe wide range of sanctions being discussed, as well as possible Russian counter-sanctions, will further weaken these prospects‚Äù.
This for Russia. For the European economy, there are still no revised values ‚Äã‚Äãsince the conflict escalated in February. Holger Schmieding, economist at Berenberg Bank, believed in the central scenario in which there could be potentially lasting tension but without open conflict. In a second phase, some recovery is therefore expected, if there is greater clarity on how the situation will evolve. But this will not save Europe from a ‚Äútemporary setback in business and consumer confidence‚Äù that will delay the recovery of economies after the recent pandemic wave (caused by the √ìmicron variant). However, it is ‚Äúunlikely‚Äù that there will be a technical recession (two consecutive quarters of negative growth), says the Berenberg economist, even in a more serious scenario.
‚ÄúThe euro zone is more exposed than the US and other advanced economies, but even so the economic impact is expected to be small,‚Äù says Capital Economics. Among the largest countries in Europe, Germany has the most significant trade links but Russia still only represents 2% of German exports. In the latest data arriving from Germany, business confidence has not deteriorated. On the contrary, in the February data, economic sentiment in the European engine improved, with the improvement in business expectations, even so the
institute that measures trust (Ifo) warns
that the escalation of the crisis in Ukraine continues to be a risk factor.
In Portugal, the economic prospects have not yet been penalized. In fact, the European Commission even revised Portugal's growth upwards for 2022, after GDP rose in 2021 more than expected ‚Äî 4.9%. This was before the sanctions and the rise in oil prices.
Brussels improves economic growth forecasts in Portugal: 5.5% in 2022 and 2.6% in 2023
Ant√≥nio Costa has already made it known that the State Budget for this year, which should only come into force in July, will have reformulated economic forecasts. A
tension in Eastern Europe increases, at a time when Russian President Vladimir Putin
recognized the breakaway territories of Donetsk and Lugansk
, in the Donbass region. Portuguese parties began to react and, despite the PCP's disparate position, there is a large consensus in condemning Putin's maneuvers.
In a statement, the communists considered that
"the current situation and its recent developments are inseparable from decades of political tension and increasing confrontation"
of the United States of America (USA) and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) against Russia.
O
PCP
criticized the
"continuous enlargement of NATO and the systematic advancement of the installation of military assets and contingents of this political-military bloc increasingly closer to the borders"
from Russian territory. The communists also hold Kiev responsible for
‚Äúconstant violations of the ceasefire‚Äù and ‚Äúsuccessive provocations‚Äù.
O
PEV
considered that Ukraine "is on the verge of being crushed by the revivalism" of the Cold War,
blaming the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO)
for advocating a "logic of endless war".
Also in a statement, the
PSD
condemned Russia's decision to recognize the independence of the self-proclaimed people's republics of Donetsk and Lugansk, considering that the Kremlin undermined the sovereignty of other countries by changing borders "by force".
"Russia must be condemned. I am part of a generation that lived through the Cold War and the nightmare of Mutually Assured Destruction; a generation that dreamed of the day the Berlin Wall fell.
This is the time when Russia must decide whether to return to the nightmare or embrace peace
", said Rio, in a post on the social network Twitter.
Russia must be condemned. I am part of a generation that lived through the Cold War and the nightmare of Mutual Assured Destruction; a generation that dreamed on the day the Berlin Wall fell. This is the time when Russia must decide whether to return to the nightmare or embrace peace.
‚Äî Rui Rio (@RuiRioPSD)
February 22, 2022
In a video statement, Andr√© Ventura reacted to Russia's recognition, on Monday night, of the independence of the self-proclaimed people's republics of Donetsk and Lugansk,
stating that it is a "new narrative that clearly violates international law and the sovereignty of a territory".
According to the leader of
Enough
, Russian attitudes "cannot go unpunished, nor should they be ignored by politicians across Europe", calling on European bodies to take "a firm, joint and strong position in relation to the acts committed against Ukraine".
Also the
Liberal Initiative
manifested itself,
saying it is in solidarity with the Ukrainian people and the community of this country residing in Portugal
, condemning "the latest violations of international law and Ukraine's sovereignty" by Russia.
"The Liberal Initiative condemns the most recent violations of International Law and Ukraine's sovereignty by Russia, in an escalation of aggression aimed at intimidating a sovereign country and
extend Russia's autocratic influence beyond its borders
", reads a note sent to the press.
O
Left Bloc
bear in mind that the story does not begin now, but rather condemns Putin's position and calls for diplomatic solutions. Having not made a statement, the party's Twitter account read: "The Left Bloc considers Putin's decision
absolutely reprehensible
".
"It is necessary to stop the imperialist wave in Russia." O
@BlocoDeEsquerda
considers Putin's decision "absolutely reprehensible"
Lu√≠s Fazenda reinforces the importance of finding ‚Äúspace for the ‚Äúdiplomatic route‚Äù and ‚Äúpolitical dialogue‚Äù.
https://t.co/W9zFi57Bbj
‚Äî Bloco de Esquerda (@BlocoDeEsquerda)
February 22, 2022
Despite the
P.S.
also having not yet made any official communication on the subject, Ant√≥nio Costa used Twitter to ‚Äúvehemently‚Äù condemn the Russian recognition of the two separatist regions, saying that this
‚Äúclearly violates the Minsk agreements and calls into question the territorial integrity of Ukraine‚Äù
.
Russian recognition of Ukraine's two breakaway regions clearly violates the Minsk agreements and calls into question Ukraine's territorial integrity. We strongly condemn this action and express full solidarity with Ukraine.
‚Äî Ant√≥nio Costa (@antoniocostapm)
February 21, 2022
The spokesperson for the
PAN
He defended, this Tuesday, that the maintenance of peace ‚Äúis fundamental‚Äù and that ‚Äúit makes no sense‚Äù for a possible war involving Ukraine and Russia, a country he accused of ‚Äúirresponsibility‚Äù.
‚ÄúRegarding this issue of Ukraine and Russia,
We cannot help but regret not only Vladimir Putin's position, but also that of the Russian state itself
.
For us, it is essential to maintain international peace‚Äù, stated In√™s Sousa Real.
Finally, Rui Tavares, from
Free
, said in statements to TSF that he was concerned about the situation in Eastern Europe. "Even the least worrying scenario, I emphasize, is extremely worrying, because
recognizing the independence of two separatist regions of the neighboring country and then sending troops to vacate them is the type of practices that occurred in Europe in the most tragic pages of the 20th century
which, when repeated, means opening a Pandora's box", he said.

Russian President Vladimir Putin marked Defender of the Fatherland Day, formerly Red Army Day, this Wednesday, by laying a wreath at the monument to the Unknown Soldier next to the Kremlin wall.
At the ceremony, the head of state observed a minute of silence and then presided over the parade of the Kremlin Guard of Honor.
In a congratulatory film for the military, Putin highlighted that the Armed Forces are the guarantee of Russia's national security and development.
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
"We see that the international situation is not at all simple, we see the dangers posed by existing challenges, such as the weakening of arms control systems or the military activity of the NATO bloc," said Putin.
The President pointed out that in recent years (Russia) has done a lot to modernize the Armed Forces, which has made it possible to demonstrate that the military is capable of "fulfilling the most complex missions".
"We will continue to develop innovative weapons systems, including hypersonic (weapons) based on new principles," he said.
According to the Russian President, these are, "in fact, weapons of the future that will increase the combative potential" of the Russian Armed Forces several times over.
Marking February 23rd in Russia is a tradition that dates back to the communist regime of the former Soviet Union.
The history of the date begins in 1922, when Soviet leaders proposed celebrating the fourth anniversary of the creation of the Red Army and Navy.
The decree on the organization of the two military branches dates back to January 23, 1918, the day on which the first volunteers for the Red Army and Navy were enlisted.
The date was then officially named Red Army Day and continued to be marked after the fall of the Soviet Union.
This year, the day is marked in the same week that the Kremlin announced the recognition of the self-proclaimed pro-Russian separatist republics in eastern Ukraine, at war with Kiev since 2014, and at the same time that thousands of Russian troops are located along the Ukrainian border, including on Belarusian territory.

translated_text:
"P
To our great regret, the Secretary General of the United Nations (...) came under pressure from the West and made several statements about what is happening in eastern Ukraine that are not in accordance with its status and powers under the UN Charter," said Sergei Lavrov at the beginning of his meeting with the United Nations special envoy for Syria, Geir Pedersen.
The head of Russian diplomacy stated that "in any conflict (...) the UN General Secretariat is obliged to maintain impartiality and is always obliged to defend direct dialogue between the countries in conflict".
However, it considered that Guterres "never raised his voice in favor of the need to fulfill the requirements of the Minsk Agreement (for peace in Donbass) supported by Security Council resolution 2202, which directly demands the resolution of all problems through dialogue between Kiev, Donetsk and Luhansk".
"No one in the West has ever mentioned this, and unfortunately the secretary general followed these sad examples," Lavrov said.
Pedersen defended Guterres by highlighting that the secretary-general "expressed his concern about the recent decision of the Russian Government regarding the two self-proclaimed republics [of Donetsk and Lugansk] and also called for a reduction in tension and dialogue, as well as a peaceful solution to this crisis based on the principles of the UN Charter".
"I hope [Guterres] can contribute to the achievement of these goals," Pedersen said.
The UN special envoy recalled that the UN Secretary-General "emphasized the UN's continued support for principles such as the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Ukraine, in strict adherence to the principles of the UN Charter and relevant resolutions of the UN General Assembly and Security Council."
Furthermore, the UN special envoy for Syria expressed concern that "the development of events (around Ukraine) could have a negative impact on the resolution of the conflict in Syria."
"I hope that doesn't happen," Pedersen emphasized.
Russia on Monday recognized the two breakaway Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Luhansk as independent.
On Tuesday, Russian authorities clarified that the recognition refers to the territory occupied when the self-proclaimed republics announced the status in 2014, which includes space currently held by Ukrainian forces.
Russian President Vladimir Putin also announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to the self-proclaimed pro-Russian separatist republics on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
However, Ukraine ordered the mobilization of military reserves to reinforce the army.

i canceled the meeting between the heads of diplomacy of the USA and Russia
, although

By SIC Not√≠cias
Netherlands summoned Russian ambassador
After Moscow's recognition of the Ukrainian separatist regions of Donetsk and Lugansk, the Netherlands summoned the Russian ambassador to The Hague, the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs confirmed today.
According to the agency France-Presse (AFP), on Tuesday ‚Äúthe Netherlands clearly informed the Russian ambassador that Russia's recent actions are unacceptable and will have serious consequences‚Äù, revealed the Dutch ministry spokesman.
Austria, the United Kingdom and Canada also summoned their respective Russian ambassadors.
11 minutes ago
By SIC Not√≠cias
World faces ‚Äúa moment of danger‚Äù, warns Guterres
UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres insisted today that the world faces ‚Äúa moment of danger‚Äù and denounced Russia‚Äôs ‚Äúviolations‚Äù in Ukraine, speaking at the opening of a meeting of the United Nations General Assembly.
‚ÄúRussia‚Äôs decision to recognize the so-called ‚Äòindependence‚Äô of the Donetsk and Lugansk regions ‚Äì and what followed ‚Äì are violations of the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine and are incompatible with the principles of the United Nations Charter,‚Äù he said.
At the same meeting, Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba stressed that Ukraine is not a threat to Russia.
‚ÄúUkraine has never planned and is not planning any military operation in the Donbass‚Äù, stated the Ukrainian ruler, demanding ‚Äúconcrete and rapid actions‚Äù from the United Nations to stop the spiral of conflict fueled, according to him, by Russia and its military deployments.
‚ÄúThe start of a large-scale war in Ukraine will be the end of the world order as we know it,‚Äù warned Kuleba.

By SIC Not√≠cias

Photo by Spencer Platt/Getty Images
With the possibility of war in Ukraine, the world must prepare for a new ‚Äúrefugee crisis‚Äù.
‚ÄúIf Russia continues on this path, it could, according to our predictions, create a new, and one of the biggest, refugee crisis‚Äù, said the American ambassador to the UN, Linda Thomas-Greenfield, before the United Nations General Assembly, pointing to around ‚Äúfive million displaced people‚Äù.
52 minutes ago
By SIC Not√≠cias
Another Ukrainian soldier dies
A Ukrainian soldier was killed this Wednesday and another was injured in a bombing carried out by pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine, the Ukrainian Army said.
The Ukrainian Armed Forces did not clarify the exact location of the attack, saying only, in a statement, that one soldier ‚Äúdied from injuries‚Äù and another survived, also with injuries during the bombing.
Since the beginning of the year, given the escalation of tension on Ukraine's eastern front, nine soldiers from the Ukrainian Armed Forces and one civilian have been killed, most of them victims of artillery fire.
58 minutes ago
By SIC Not√≠cias
The three possible starting points for the Russian invasion of Ukraine
There are three possible starting points for a Russian invasion of Ukraine, according to the United States and the United Kingdom, which allegedly had access to Russia's attack plans.

By SIC Not√≠cias

‚Äú
There should be no doubt that the sanctions¬†will have a strong, not necessarily symmetrical, but thoughtful and sensitive response on the U.S. side
‚Äù, said the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs in a statement cited by the Spanish agency EFE.

‚Äútrying to change the course of Russia‚Äù
.

Russian Defense Minister and two private banks among sanctions targets
Photo by Ramil Sitdikov ‚Äì Host Photo Agency via Getty Images
Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu and two private Russian banks are among those targeted by European Union (EU) sanctions on Moscow following President Vladimir Putin's recognition of separatist territories in eastern Ukraine.
The information was provided to the Lusa agency today by European sources after the final confirmation by the Committee of Permanent Representatives of the Governments of the Member States of the European Union to the sanctions approved by the 27 Foreign Ministers, on Tuesday.
According to the same sources,
the ‚Äúapproval of the sanctions is confirmed‚Äù, then covering ‚Äútwo Russian banks‚Äù, as well as the ‚ÄúRussian Minister of Defense‚Äù
.
‚ÄúThe Russian ambassador in Brussels will be informed,‚Äù they added.
Also according to these European sources, ‚Äúsome countries are asking for Russian oligarchs to be included in the next sanctions‚Äù, a position that was expressed at the meeting of the committee of representatives.

By SIC Not√≠cias

Ukrainian Communications Center confirmed to the BBC that the country is being targeted by a new large-scale cyberattack, less than a week after Ukraine suffered a similar incident.
‚ÄúWe have never seen anything like this, this has reached a new level,‚Äù an official source told the BBC.
1 hour ago
By SIC Not√≠cias
Portugal ‚Äúmust condemn Putin‚Äôs military adventure‚Äù
The Left Bloc (BE) argues that Portugal should condemn ‚Äúthe military adventure‚Äù of Russian President Vladimir Putin in relation to Ukraine, but distance itself from ‚Äúpositions in support of the USA and the expansion of NATO‚Äù.
In a note from the BE Political Committee, entitled ‚Äú
No to Russia's imperialist aggression. For an integral and neutral Ukraine
‚Äù, the party led by Catarina Martins states that ‚Äúin the face of the annexation of Donbass, the Bloc condemns Putin's military adventure, which is accompanied by an imperialist discourse that denies Ukraine's right to exist as an independent state‚Äù.
‚ÄúThis is a rejection of the Minsk Agreements, violated by both parties over the years. This annexation represents, without a doubt, a break with the previous process, the partition of the territory of Ukraine, whose borders are recognized by the United Nations, completely in disregard of international law. Putin's actions only find significant support from well-known figures on the European far right‚Äù, he criticizes.
Thus, for BE, ‚ÄúPortugal must condemn Putin's military adventure and distance itself from positions of support for the USA and the expansion of NATO‚Äù.
Portugal can, in the blocists' analysis, ‚Äúsupport the application of sanctions to Russian leaders, their oligarch supporters and their respective international companies, offering its political and diplomatic solidarity to Ukraine for the preservation of its territory‚Äù.
‚ÄúThe Portuguese government must, within the framework of the European Union, insist on diplomatic channels to define terms for a ceasefire in the Donbass and for coexistence in the region‚Äù, they argue.

By SIC Not√≠cias

The president of the European Council has called an extraordinary summit of heads of state and government of the European Union (EU) for tomorrow, in Brussels, to discuss the escalation of tension between Ukraine and Russia.
‚ÄúThe use of force and coercion to change borders has no place in the 21st century. I convene a special European Council for tomorrow [Thursday] in Brussels to discuss the latest developments related to Ukraine and Russia‚Äù, announced the President of the Council, Charles Michel, on his official account on the social network Twitter.

By SIC Not√≠cias

Several websites of Ukrainian government institutions were the target of a ‚Äúmass‚Äù cyber attack.
This is the case with the page of the Ukrainian Parliament, as well as the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and security services.
However, speaking to the Interfax agency, a minister added that ‚Äúseveral banks‚Äù were also affected.

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan warned his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin, this Wednesday in a telephone conversation, that ‚ÄúTurkey will oppose any action that affects the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Urcania‚Äù.
Erdogan also told the Russian President that ‚Äúa military conflict will not bring anything positive to anyone‚Äù.
This telephone conversation was announced by the Turkish presidency, which does not mention how long the two leaders spoke.

Berlin promises to compensate Germans for rising gas prices by blocking Nord Stream 2
EPA/CLEMENS BILAN
German Vice Chancellor and Economy Minister Robert Habeck
, today defended the blocking of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, claiming that it should never have been built and promised to compensate citizens and companies for the expected increase in gas prices.
‚ÄúWe will mitigate the momentary rise in the price of gas and its burden on citizens and companies,‚Äù said Habeck, vice-chancellor of Olaf Scholz's government, speaking to German public radio Deutschlandfunk.
Habeck, from Os Verdes, who has headed the super-ministry of Economy and Climate since December, assured that
Germany has enough gas and the supply is guaranteed
, as measures have been taken in this regard.
The minister also said that
Germany can do without Russian gas completely
, but warned that this would be costly.
Habeck considered that
Nord Stream 2 should never have been built
for being ‚Äúa huge risk factor in the Baltic‚Äù, a position he has always defended because, among other reasons, it implies a strong energy dependence on Moscow.
4 hours ago
By SIC Not√≠cias

With the Russian advance into eastern Ukraine, elderly people, women and children are being removed from the separatist regions. From Donetsk and Luhansk arrive
reports of bombings and an increase in violence
in a region that is already at war, before it was declared.
4 hours ago
By SIC Not√≠cias

The Minister of Foreign Affairs,
Augusto Santos Silva, was on SIC's Primeiro Jornal this Wednesday
, to talk about the situation in Ukraine and the consequences that could result for the world and for Portugal, warning from the outset that Russia ‚Äúis following a very dangerous path‚Äù.
Asked about the degree of certainty that there is that the sanctions, approved by the United Kingdom, USA and UR, will actually halt Russia's advance, the minister admitted
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not sure‚Äù
. In this sense, he explained, the sanctions ‚Äúrepresent the first response to a concrete act by Russia‚Äù, recognizing the independence of the Ukrainian republics Lugansk and Donetsk.
The West, he assured, is willing to ‚Äúgo as far as necessary, [and to] apply sanctions on a scale never seen before, such as cutting off funding for the Russian state and harming Russia's position in international trade‚Äù.

By SIC Not√≠cias
Putin talks about Russian military modernization on Defender of the Fatherland Day
(Alexei Nikolsky, Kremlin Pool Photo via AP)
Russian President Vladimir Putin marked Defender of the Fatherland Day this Wednesday
, formerly Red Army Day, laying a wreath at the monument to the Unknown Soldier next to the Kremlin wall.
At the ceremony, the head of state observed a minute of silence and then presided over the parade of the Kremlin Guard of Honor.
In a congratulatory film for the military,
Putin highlighted that the Armed Forces are the guarantee of Russia's national security and development.
‚ÄúWe see that the international situation is not at all simple, we see the dangers posed by existing challenges, such as the weakening of arms control systems or the military activity of the NATO bloc,‚Äù said Putin.
The President pointed out that
In recent years (Russia) has done a lot to modernize the Armed Forces, which has made it possible to demonstrate that the military is capable of ‚Äúfulfilling the most complex missions‚Äù.
‚ÄúWe will continue to develop innovative weapons systems, including hypersonic (weapons) based on new principles,‚Äù he said.
4 hours ago
By SIC Not√≠cias

(Photo by STRINGER/AFP via Getty Images)
About half of Russians surveyed in a
poll published today by CNN
considers it correct for his country to use military force against Ukraine to prevent Kiev from joining NATO, according to the Spanish agency Efe.
The survey carried out by the company Savanta ComRes among citizens of Ukraine and Russia concludes that only
25% of Russians believe it would be wrong to use the army against Ukraine
, while another 25% are unsure about the best option to resolve the current crisis.
The survey reveals that
43% believe it would be a mistake to ‚Äúreunify‚Äù through force
, Russia and Ukraine, two countries with a long and complicated history of intertwined relations, but 36% do not believe this is a bad option.
Most Ukrainians disagree with the use of force
North American television reports that among Ukrainians the majority refuse to use force by Russia. Of those surveyed, 70% said it would be incorrect for Russia to use military force to prevent Ukraine from joining NATO or to unify the two countries (73%).
Among all those who responded to the survey in Ukraine, and of all ages, there was a
majority consensus on not feeling like ‚Äúone people‚Äù
, together with Russians, and in defense of the existence of two countries.
In Ukraine, an average of 28% of respondents agree with the idea that Russians and Ukrainians are ‚Äúone people‚Äù, while this average rises to 65% for Russian respondents.
Only 21% of Ukrainians anticipate a peaceful end to tensions with Russia, compared to 65% of Russians.
The survey also points out that only
26% of Ukrainians expect military defense of Ukraine by NATO or the United States
, and consider it more likely that there will be economic sanctions against Russian leaders (46%) or Russian companies (34%).
The survey, carried out among more than a thousand people in each country (1,021 in Russia and 1,075 in Ukraine) was carried out online between February 7th and 15th, before Vladimir Putin's speech on Monday and Moscow's recognition of the independence of the Ukrainian separatist territories of Donbass (Donetsk and Lugansk).
5 hours ago
By Lusa
Natural gas consumers will experience an ‚Äúinevitable‚Äù price increase, admits Environment Minister
(Photo by Horacio Villalobos#Corbis/Corbis via Getty Images)
The Minister of the Environment admitted, this Wednesday, that anyone who directly consumes natural gas will feel
‚Äúinevitable‚Äù price increase
, due to the situation in Ukraine, which led Germany to suspend the certification of Nord Stream 2, for the transport of Russian gas.
‚ÄúThose who directly use natural gas will feel this increase because it is inevitable,
Portugal does not set this price, it is the price of a ‚Äòcommodity‚Äô [raw material], which is fixed at a global level
‚Äù, the Minister of Environment and Climate Action, Jo√£o Matos Fernandes, told journalists, on the sidelines of the final conference of the E+C Project ‚Äì More Circular Economy promoted by CIP ‚Äì Confedera√ß√£o Empresarial de Portugal, at the Thalia Theater, in Lisbon.

The United States (USA) estimates that a broader Russian invasion of Ukraine could displace five million people.
‚ÄúIf Russia continues down this path, it could create a new and major refugee crisis,‚Äù warns US Ambassador to the UN, Linda Thomas-Greenfield, this Wednesday.

,
that an armed conflict in Ukraine "could worsen the refugee crisis"
which began in 2014 with the annexation of Crimea by Russia.
"It is very important that the people of Ukraine, after previous conflicts, which have already generated many refugees and displaced people and still remain, come to add a war conflict. It is aggravating a situation that is already very serious", explained Pedro Neto, at the time.

Ant√Énio Guterres, Secretary-General of the UN Photo: Jason Szenes/EPA
UN Secretary-General Ant√Énio Guterres insisted this Wednesday that the world faces "a moment of danger" and denounced Russia's "violations" in Ukraine, speaking at the opening of a meeting of the United Nations General Assembly.
"Russia's decision to recognize the so-called 'independence' of the Donetsk and Lugansk regions - and what followed - are violations of the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine and are incompatible with the principles of the Charter of the United Nations," he said.
The secretary-general's participation was not initially planned for this meeting, which takes place annually, but Guterres decided to participate after canceling a trip to Africa and returning to New York early.
At the same meeting, Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba stressed that Ukraine is not a threat to Russia.
"Ukraine has never planned and is not planning any military operations in Donbass," he said.
The minister called for "concrete and rapid actions" from the United Nations to stop the spiral of conflict fueled, according to him, by Russia and its military detachments.
"The start of a large-scale war in Ukraine will be the end of the world order as we know it," warned Kuleba.
This meeting of the General Assembly, attended by the 193 members of the United Nations (UN), is an annual session on the "temporarily occupied Ukrainian territories", organized since the annexation of Crimea by Russia in 2014.
Several ministers announced that they will intervene during the meeting, which should last throughout this Wednesday.
