Interview
Jos√© Pedro Teixeira Fernandes. ‚ÄúThe West must withdraw the initiative from Russia‚Äù
Feb 22, 2022 - 11:30 pm ‚Ä¢
Jos√© Bastos
‚ÄúIt is time to invest in diplomacy that sets the stage and the way to cut the corner is to have a great plan to rethink security in Europe‚Äù, argues strategy specialist Jos√© Pedro Teixeira Fernandes.

The tug-of-war between the West and Russia has again been fueled by the Russian president's decision to ‚Äúsend peacekeeping troops,‚Äù in the Kremlin's euphemism, to the pro-Russian separatist regions in eastern Ukraine. A new step by Putin after recognizing the independence of the self-proclaimed republics of Donestk and Lugansk in a speech sprinkled with historical references in which he even described Ukraine as a ‚Äúcolony of the United States‚Äù.
Beyond the consequences on the ground, Putin nullifies French President Macron's initiative to hold a summit with Joe Biden. Although it is difficult to predict how far the two parties are willing to go to prevent this crisis from moving to a battlefield closer to Kiev (ceasefires in the Donbass are frequently broken), the costs of a war are of such magnitude that it seems unlikely that the option will be a reality.
But, at the same time, Putin suggests that he makes Russia's future dependent on the equal sharing of major geopolitical roles with the United States and China and does not seem to admit concessions. Europe is now at risk of a serious crisis, not only due to the immediate effects on the ground and on the behavior of the markets, the energy market in particular, but due to the reconfiguration of a space of confrontation identical to that experienced during the Cold War.
With this background, there still seems to be enough elements for the risks of conflict to be neutralized with an exercise in realism, argues professor Jos√© Pedro Teixeira Fernandes, a specialist in geostrategy. In this interview with
Renaissance
, the researcher at IPRI, the Portuguese Institute of International Relations, evaluates the Russian and Western strategies in this crisis, suggesting the need to rethink a major plan for Europe's security.
By entering South Ossetia and Abkhazia (2008) and Crimea (2014) ‚Äòmode‚Äô, Putin gave his own ‚Äòhistory lesson‚Äô, from the Kremlin. It is the Russian vision that leads to going against the European order born from the end of the USSR. How can Europe respond?
The big question is knowing how to respond with some reasonableness, that is, firmly defining the principles, but also with reasonableness to all of this so as not to fuel the conflict and lead to the worst scenario: an extended military conflict.
But the first angle to mention, related to Russia, is that this is a kind of "return of history" in the worst way. This is due to Russian dissatisfaction that has existed since the 90s, with the way Europe has been reconfigured. Firstly, the territorial losses of the former Soviet Union, Ukraine a greater loss, but also of territories where Moscow traditionally had a great influence such as in the Balkan area, in particular the former Yugoslavia.
All of this has been germinating since the 90s, although at that time the Russian protests were relatively inconsequential, because Russia was in an internal process of upheavals, transformations, facing the wars in Chechnya, at a moment of weakness in which it had no real possibility of contesting the new international order.
At the same time, with greater or lesser historical accuracy, especially because we never have all the data, the Russians constantly repeat, although there was no formal treaty, that all the spirit of the agreements, including the reunification of Germany under the terms that were accepted by Gorbachev, were in the sense of not expanding NATO to the Russian borders, or close to its borders as the alliance is today.
This is the widely - if not unanimously - accepted perception in Russia and has essentially created the idea that the West cannot be trusted. And there is a central aspect: when we see, essentially, actions in the name of democracy and human rights, Russia sees - possibly also this - a geopolitical expansion of the West. A reading that makes sense from a Russian point of view. Anchoring itself on these principles, the West always expands into its areas of interest and does not consider Russia's points of interest.
Photo: Russian Ministry of Defense/EPA
At this point, circumstances are more favorable to Russia. You don't need to be a specialist in international issues to understand that these circumstances are much more favorable to Moscow than they were in the 1990s. First of all, because of the transformation on a global level and because Russia itself is in a process of consolidation that is much stronger than it was three decades ago. This Russia is not the Soviet Union, but it is stronger than it was.
Another key component of this scenario, China, is a power making a tacit game of understanding with Moscow and the United States is widely perceived by its rivals as being on a trajectory of some decline in power.
Russia does not accept speech only about values, respect for human rights, and democracy, as the West reads them. The Russians think that the motivation for actions is always the geopolitical interests of the West and nothing more than that.
Is it this perception that leads to an issue on Moscow's side, such as the ongoing violation of international law both in Crimea and now in Donbass, not even being considered as such and being framed within this historical logic?
If we try to imagine Russian logic from a historical perspective and from a particular vision of the world, obviously mixed with a lot of propaganda because, as we know, in Russia there is no free press, that is a possibility. Deep down, Russians reason - and in a transversal way and not just Putin's supporters - in this historical affiliation.
In comparison with previous interventions, in the case of Kosovo, the United States and NATO, for example, acted in the name of human rights, in the name of protecting the Kosovar Albanian minority who were being mistreated by the Serbs. But, in reality, what resolved the problem was not the West saying that these principles overlapped with those of State sovereignty - Serbia claimed that it was an internal matter - nor did the UN charter break the tie because it did not have anything specific on which the intervention could be anchored, but what decided the issue was NATO's power to carry out military action on the ground.
Now, seen from Moscow, the Russian reading is this: if the United States could do this with a certain vision of the world with unilateral actions in the 90s because they had the power and we didn't count on it, now it's time to do the same. This may seem almost caricatural, but the Russians try to almost replicate the same arguments: Western intervention was to protect minorities and Moscow now invokes the protection of Russian minorities.
The West then alluded to a humanitarian intervention to maintain peace, but if we try to see this from a historical and political perspective of Russia and especially in light of the argument of the universality of values ‚Äã‚Äã- the West self-justifies the interventions in the light of good principles for humanity, human rights - which provoke distrust on the other side.
Russians do not accept this discourse just about values, respect for human rights, and democracy, as the West reads them. The Russians think that the motivation for actions is always the geopolitical interests of the West and nothing more than that.
In this case, the risk of Ukraine evolving into a liberal democracy in the best Western style...
That is certainly the heart of the dispute at this point. For the reasons I was referring to, the fact that there is an expansion of states absorbing universalist values ‚Äã‚Äãfrom the West is a problem seen from there.
We correctly see Western democracy and respect for human rights as the appropriate model for most states, but we know that, strategically, this framework of values ‚Äã‚Äãprojects the influence and material interests of the West, even the European Union.
Now, this second aspect is exactly what the Russians don't want. This is not a simple question of democracy vs authoritarianism. It's much more than that: it's geostrategy.
In Munich, President Zelensky said something important that received no response. The Ukrainian president asked NATO and the Europeans to be clear and say whether Ukraine can join NATO and give it a timetable for membership and, as far as I know, he has not received any response so far... and probably, under these circumstances, he will not.
Look at the way Putin supported Lukashenko in the recent protests in Belarus...
Without a doubt. This crisis in Ukraine gave Putin and Lukashenko an excellent opportunity to stifle these protests in Minsk. At the moment, Russia has troops on the border with Ukraine and the Belarusian issue has completely disappeared from the radar. The protests were erased.
In this sense, the Ukraine crisis played another role here, that of once again asserting Putin's influence with Lukashenko showing himself, as much as possible, on Russia's side and even readying himself to receive some weapons - even of a nuclear nature, in the new extreme - paying the favor to Moscow.
Ukraine has a delicate situation here: the construction of a liberal democracy faces geopolitical problems with the Russian position, but it is also a problem for the West. A problem that is sometimes not treated correctly. It is the creation of expectations in Ukraine that the West cannot, or will not, meet.
In the case of NATO, at the Munich security summit last weekend, there is a detail that almost goes unnoticed, but it is worth remembering. President Zelensky, among other things, said something important that received no response. The Ukrainian president asked NATO and the Europeans to be clear and say whether Ukraine can join NATO and give it a timetable for membership and, as far as I know, he has not received any response so far... and probably, under these circumstances, he will not.
In Western support for Ukraine, there is also a set of ambiguities here. An ambiguity like: "democracy yes, containing Russia yes, but, be careful, outside our institutions".
People of Luhansk celebrate recognition of the independence of the pro-Russian separatist region in Ukraine
From this European perspective, the bulk of the European Union's members are, at the same time, NATO allies and will be affected in their politics, economy and security by a conflict on their eastern border. For example, energy costs are at stake - and Germany has already suspended NordStream 2. Experts suggest that this situation could benefit gas imports from the United States and countries like Poland, which will play a role as a warehouse.
If the geography of energy plays a role here, then how can disunity be avoided within the European Union and in its relationship with the United States? After all, the ‚Äúelephant in the room‚Äù is being able to agree on a common package of sanctions?
This is the chronic problem of the European Union and the West at critical moments like this, the impact of which is felt differently in each country: this is the problem of energy geopolitics.
It is true that this crisis could give advantages to the United States and other alternative producers in supplying energy to Western Europe. But these advantages cannot be achieved immediately. They usually take their time. It is necessary to put alternative supply circuits into practice and see them work. We will always be talking about an extended period of time that does not correspond to the short-term resolution of energy problems.
Secondly, this NordStream2 was still not working. What Germany is saying is that it freezes it, suspends its activation, but the practical effect on the gas supply is null.
The development and duration of the crisis will be very important in this energy issue, but in the short term it does not affect Russia much. The most immediate practical result in the West, visible for weeks now, is the rise in the prices of natural gas and oil. Now, Russia is one of the world's largest exporters of natural gas and oil, so all this geopolitical instability - in the immediate future, I emphasize, because it can change even due to the effect of sanctions - is giving a huge return to Moscow. If we are to see the financial gains of Rosneft and Gazprom have reached record numbers. These are calculations and revenues that enter Russia.
The Europeans' dilemma is always to find a range of sanctions that are not perceived by different states as contrary to their interests in relationships and the functioning of sensitive economic sectors. This is what will happen as the crisis evolves, if it is necessary to move forward with tougher sanctions. It will be more difficult to reach these understandings about sanctions.
It would perhaps be time to rethink Western strategy. There is already an exaggeration. Perhaps it is still time to invest in diplomacy that marks the ground, because in reality we have never seen Western diplomacy that led the agenda in this crisis. What we saw was the French and Germans trying to talk to Putin to understand what the Russian leader wanted to do.
On the United States side, by multiplying warnings against Russia and reactions is Biden softening the bad image left in Afghanistan? What options does Washington have in terms of sanctions at a time when, for many, with this crisis Russia, in terms of perceptions of trying to artificially rise to the level where the United States and China meet?
This is an important question, because it plays a lot at the level of perceptions and the symbolic.
The United States (and the British) had a strategy that was to try, as much as possible, to denounce in advance the Russian force concentration maneuvers, invasion plans, or at least, the likelihood of these plans, the so-called 'false flag operations', all of this has been in the last few weeks almost permanently in our news, images, in the public media space.
If we can see some virtues in the strategy in terms of cutting room for maneuver for an invasion - if that is the Russian idea - it is an option that is not without very negative collateral by-products that can reduce an initial gain or even nullify it. We can also say that the strategy will be compensation for Biden for the widespread perception that he underestimated the warnings of the security services in the case of Afghanistan and, in this case, he will be at the other extreme. It is plausible and not an unfair comment for Joe Biden to make this claim.
In the British case, Boris Johnson, a few days ago, was fighting for his own political survival because of Covid19, and the internal discussion changed completely. I'm not saying that the strategy derives from this alone, but it is obviously a convenient factor to take into account in political calculation operations. However, these options have the effect of making the Russian threat credible, because the Russians try, as much as possible, to place themselves on the same level as the United States and China - increasingly recognized as being on par or very close - but if we have a strategy to accentuate these angles, or even eventually to inflate the threat, we are falling into Russia's game.
We are still, unintentionally, certainly, causing a problem for the Ukrainian economy by driving away investors and commercial partners, increasing the cost of their financing. President Zelensky himself has complained several times and asked to give up this rhetoric.
There is the feeling that the United States is more interested in playing a game of direct gains with Russia than actually thinking about Kiev's interests.
The President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelenskiy. Photo: Johanna Geron/EPA
I think it will be necessary for Joe Biden to correct this strategy, which seems excessive to me. The need to have contingency plans for military plans or eventual invasion is not in question - it would even be irresponsible not to have them - but I think that the United States and the West have perhaps invested too much here in disseminating images and information that even appear in the media because there are always 'stories' to make openings and even exaggerated comments, but time will confirm or show certain things.
My point is that the West perhaps should have invested more in withdrawing the diplomatic initiative from Russia. In this battle of public opinion, the West, instead of focusing on images, should have, particularly in Europe, taken more diplomatic initiatives which, in practice, never were.
Does the White House's own strategy contrast with that of the 2008 Russian-Georgian war or 2014 Crimea?
There is no doubt that the conviction of those who designed it is of the type: 'last time we were caught by surprise and now we are not'. The open question is whether Russia's intention is truly invasion - time will tell - and to what extent the Russians, or because they do not have that intention, have adapted the strategy and are reversing it in their favor in the sense that the mass dissemination of these images feeds their self-perception as the most powerful power reached certain levels and contributed to bringing the Ukrainian economy to its knees, a clear objective of Russia.
It would perhaps be time to rethink this Western strategy. There is already an exaggeration. Perhaps it is still time to invest in diplomacy that marks the ground, because in reality we have never seen Western diplomacy that led the agenda in this crisis. What we saw was the French and Germans trying to talk to Putin to understand what the Russian leader wanted to do.
The way for the West to cut corners, something it has not done in terms of diplomacy and public opinion, is to have a plan on its own terms, again, on its own terms, a grand plan to rethink Europe's security.
Such a plan to rethink Europe's security would cut through many arguments and, at the very least, define the terms of public discussion and force Russia to take a different course of action. The absence of this plan is one of the great flaws of Western strategy. I hope that the West and the United States, in particular, still have time to rectify.

Portugal "well aligned" with the EU and NATO
Former ambassador Martins da Cruz recalls the large Ukrainian community in Portugal and praises the position of the national authorities.
Ant√≥nio Martins da Cruz, ambassador
¬©¬†(Jorge Amaral/Global Imagens
Paula Sa

Portugal is "well aligned with the European Union and NATO, as expected", Ant√≥nio Martins da Cruz tells DN about the growing tension between Russia and Ukraine. In other words, the repudiation of the "violation" of the Minsk agreements, after the Russian authorities recognized two regions controlled by separatists in Ukrainian territory, Donetsk and Lugansk, and the support for sanctions on the country led by Vladimir Putin.
The former Portuguese ambassador to NATO recalls that the EU was always "very fragmented regarding Russia's positions and in the face of Ukraine's requests", but now, he emphasizes in a complimentary tone, "it has reached a minimum common denominator to impose sanctions on Russia and with which Portugal is in agreement".
"The European Union reached a minimum common denominator to impose sanctions on Russia and with which Portugal is in agreement."
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
Regarding the impact of this position on economic relations, Martins da Cruz recalls that Ukraine is not one of Portugal's partners, but there is a strong connection between the two countries as we have a "large Ukrainian community and around two hundred Portuguese with dual nationality".
As he emphasizes, we will not be affected by any Russian retaliation with regard to natural gas. Unlike Spain, which still imports 9% of gas from Ukraine, Portugal is a customer of other markets, in this case Nigeria, the United States and Algeria.
The Portuguese President of the Republic also reacted yesterday and considered that "the situation speaks for itself, the step that was taken [by Russia] speaks for itself, and the reaction also spoke for itself, by pointing out, on the one hand, what was a clear violation of the Minsk agreements and, on the other hand, questioning the territorial integrity of Ukraine".
"Russian recognition of the two breakaway regions of Ukraine clearly violates the Minsk agreements and calls into question the territorial integrity of Ukraine. We strongly condemn this action and express full solidarity with Ukraine."
Martins da Cruz recalls that foreign policy is "the exclusive responsibility of the government", but "it is good for the President to recall Portuguese positions.
The prime minister wrote on Twitter that "Russian recognition of the two separatist regions of Ukraine clearly violates the Minsk agreements and calls into question the territorial integrity of Ukraine. We strongly condemn this action and express full solidarity with Ukraine."
The president of the PSD yesterday reiterated his condemnation of Russia for its actions in Ukraine and argued that the country "has to decide whether it wants to return to the nightmare" of the Cold War "or embrace peace".
Also on the social network Twitter, Rui Rio stressed that "Russia must be condemned. I am part of a generation that lived through the Cold War and the nightmare of Mutual Assured Destruction; a generation that dreamed of the day the Berlin Wall fell. This is the time when Russia has to decide whether it wants to return to the nightmare or embrace peace."
The PCP came out in defense of Russia, as expected, but asking for dialogue for a peaceful solution to the conflict. In a statement, the communists considered that "the current situation and its recent developments are inseparable from decades of policy of tension and growing confrontation" by the United States of America (USA) and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) against Russia.
The PCP criticized the "continuous enlargement of NATO and the systematic advance in the installation of military assets and contingents from this political-military bloc ever closer to the borders" of Russian territory. There is a "need to develop initiatives that contribute to de-escalation and that prioritize a process of dialogue with a view to a peaceful solution to the conflict", they argue. Regarding the "concern with the Minsk agreements", the PCP considered that "it is important to bear in mind that the Ukrainian regime not only never complied with them, even openly, but also prevented the achievement of a peaceful solution to the conflict".
For the Liberal Initiative this is a moment when there can be no hesitation: "Russia seeks large-scale imperialist territorial aggression with ethnic/racist justifications. Russian rulers are afraid that their people will realize that liberal democracy is the only political system that can bring them more prosperity and a better life and will demand it, deposing the current autocratic regime."

translated_text:
N
During a United Nations (UN) General Assembly debate on the situation of the "temporarily occupied Ukrainian territories", Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield declared that one of the biggest refugee crises of our time could be at stake.
"If Russia continues on this path, it could - according to our estimates - create a new refugee crisis, one of the biggest crises facing the world today, with up to five million people displaced by Russia's chosen war and putting pressure on Ukraine's neighbors," said Linda Thomas-Greenfield.
Furthermore, according to the American diplomat, Russia's actions could cause an increase in food prices in developing countries and further intensify hunger in places such as Libya, Yemen and Lebanon, since Ukraine is one of the largest wheat suppliers in the world.
"The giant waves of suffering that this war will cause are unimaginable", stressed the American.
"To date, Russia's war in eastern Ukraine has killed more than 14,000 people. Nearly three million Ukrainians -- half of whom are elderly and children -- need food, shelter and other life-saving aid. And, of course, ordinary Russians should be asking how many Russian lives [Vladimir] Putin [President of Russia] is willing to sacrifice to fuel his ambitions," the ambassador added.
Today's UN General Assembly was an almost uninterrupted succession of condemnations of Russia's latest actions in eastern Ukraine. However, once again, China did not join the chorus of criticism, not distancing itself from its traditional diplomatic ally.
Faced with the condemnations, the Russian ambassador to the UN, Vassily Nebenzia, justified the Russian intervention (and deployment of troops) in Donbass: "Faced with the blatant genocide and the trampling of the most important human rights, the right to life, our country could not remain indifferent to the fate of the four million inhabitants of Donbass", he said.
According to the Russian version, the world shows "complete indifference to the fate of the people of Donbass", who suffer "a systematic deprivation of their basic rights for ethnic reasons".
The UN Secretary-General, Ant√≥nio Guterres, insisted today that the world faces "a moment of danger" and denounced Russia's "violations" in Ukraine, speaking at the opening of a meeting of the United Nations General Assembly.
"Russia's decision to recognize the so-called 'independence' of the Donetsk and Lugansk regions - and what followed - are violations of Ukraine's territorial integrity and sovereignty and are incompatible with the principles of the United Nations Charter," he said.
The secretary-general's participation was not initially planned for this meeting, which takes place annually, but Guterres decided to participate after canceling a trip to Africa and returning to New York early.

This Wednesday, the United States announced the application of sanctions to companies that participated in the construction of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, which connects Russia to Germany, and their executives, due to Russian actions in eastern Ukraine.
In a statement, US President Joe Biden thanked German Chancellor Olaf Scholz for the coordinated effort between the two countries and made it clear that he "will not hesitate" to adopt new measures against Russia if Moscow continues to move against Ukraine. "Yesterday [Tuesday], after close consultations between our two Governments, Germany announced that it would suspend certification of the gas pipeline. Today, I directed my administration to impose sanctions on Nord Stream 2 AG and its corporate directors," Biden announced.

"These measures are another part of our initial tranche of sanctions in response to Russia's actions in Ukraine. As I have made clear, we will not hesitate to take further action if Russia continues to escalate," the US head of state added.

The German leader, who until now had avoided commenting on the future of the gas pipeline, despite pressure for its suspension, ended up taking the decision after Russia recognized the pro-Russian separatist regions in eastern Ukraine.

The 1,235-kilometer Nord Stream 2 was built to transport Russian gas directly to Germany without passing through Ukraine, like its predecessor, Nord Stream 1, in operation since 2011.

translated_text:
World
Conflict in Ukraine. US and EU trigger sanctions against Russia
by Mariana Ribeiro Soares - RTP
Want to share this article?
cancel
Reuters
The US announced a set of sweeping economic sanctions on Russia on Tuesday night for what President Joe Biden called ‚Äúthe start of a Russian invasion of Ukraine‚Äù. The European Union also approved a package of sanctions to ‚Äúaffect Russia‚Äù and is expected to announce a new set of retaliatory measures this Wednesday, targeting important figures in the Russian regime.
SEE MORE
‚ÄúTo put it simply, Russia just announced that it is withdrawing a large chunk of Ukraine,‚Äù
said US President Joe Biden when announcing his ‚Äúfirst tranche‚Äù of sanctions aimed at the Russian regime.
The measures include sanctions on Russia's foreign debt, isolating Moscow from Western financing.
"We have cut off the Russian Government's ability to access financing from the West. It will also not be able to sell its new debt on European or American markets," Biden announced.
The US also applied sanctions to Russian banks:
‚ÄúWe have four blocking sanctions on two large financial institutions: VEB [one of the largest investment and development banks] and Banco Militar.‚Äù
In the crosshairs of US sanctions are still high-ranking ‚Äúelites‚Äù in Russia.
‚ÄúStarting tomorrow or the next day, we will impose sanctions on family members of the Russian elite, who will suffer too‚Äù, declared Biden, stating that ‚Äúthey [Russian oligarchs] share the corrupt profits of the Kremlin‚Äôs policies and must share the suffering too‚Äù.
The American president stressed that this is only the ‚Äúfirst phase of sanctions against Russia‚Äù, and these sanctions will be worsened depending on Moscow's behavior.
Joe Biden also announced the deployment of US troops to NATO member states, such as Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.
The president of the United States also says he has authorized more US forces for the Ukrainian region that are already stationed in Europe. ‚ÄúLet it be clear: these are defensive movements on our part, we do not intend to fight with Russia‚Äù, he stressed.
UK and EU also approve sanctions packages
The United Kingdom and the European Union also announced a wave of sanctions against Russian banks and individuals on Tuesday.
The 27 member states of the European Union reached an agreement on Tuesday on a package of sanctions, unanimously approved, to ‚Äúaffect Russia‚Äù.
The sanctions package will apply to the 351 members of the Duma [lower house of the Russian Federal Assembly] who voted in favor of recognizing two separatist regions of Ukraine as independent states.
The EU's response also targets 27 individuals and entities with a ‚Äúthreatening role for Ukraine's independence‚Äù, announced Josep Borrell, the EU's senior official for Foreign Policy and Security.
Regarding financial sanctions, restrictions are expected on the EU's economic relations with the two separatist regions, Donetsk and Lugansk, as well as the freezing of assets of two private Russian banks.
Later this Wednesday, the EU is expected to announce a package of additional sanctions on Russia that will target important figures of the Russian regime, namely the Minister of Defense, Sergei Shoigu, commanders-in-chief of the Russian Air Force and the Black Sea Fleet, according to the newspaper.
The Guardian
.
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson also announced on Tuesday that the United Kingdom will sanction five Russian banks and three high-net-worth individuals.
, including billionaire businessman Gennady Timchenko, after Russian President Vladimir Putin recognized two breakaway regions in eastern Ukraine.
"Today, the United Kingdom will sanction the following five Russian banks: Rossiya, IS Bank, General Bank, Promsvyazbank and Black Sea Bank, and we are also sanctioning three very high net worth individuals," Johnson announced in the British Parliament.
Germany also suspended authorization for the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, which connects Russia to Germany and was built to take Russian gas to the European country.
"In light of the latest developments, we must re-evaluate the situation in particular regarding Nord Stream 2," said German Chancellor Olaf Scholz.
None of the sanctions went as far as had been threatened in the event of a full-scale invasion of Ukraine, although U.S. and European officials have stressed that more retaliatory measures will be applied if the conflict to the east deteriorates.
Putin says he is ‚Äúopen to dialogue‚Äù
The widespread sanctions were announced after Russia recognized the independence of the breakaway republics of Donetsk and Lugansk in eastern Ukraine.
Western nations view this Russian action as a pretext for a full-scale invasion of Ukraine, something Moscow has always denied.
On Tuesday, the Russian Parliament also authorized the deployment of Russian troops in Donbass, less than 24 hours after Putin decreed their mobilization for ‚Äúpeacekeeping‚Äù operations ‚Äì a description that Washington classified as ‚Äúabsurd‚Äù.
The President of the United States considers that Vladimir Putin ‚Äútried to rewrite History‚Äù, directly attacking ‚ÄúUkraine‚Äôs right to exist‚Äù and threatening war if ‚Äúhis extreme demands are not met‚Äù.
"There is no doubt that Russia is the aggressor. The challenges we face are very clear," he said. Biden reiterated, however, that "there is still time to avoid the worst-case scenario" and that "the US is open to diplomacy, if it is serious. We are prepared and will judge Russia by its actions, not its words."
Russian President Vladimir Putin also declared himself, this Wednesday, ‚Äúopen to dialogue to find diplomatic solutions to the most difficult problems‚Äù, but stressed that ‚ÄúRussia's interests are not negotiable‚Äù.
Satellite images from the past 24 hours showed several new troops and equipment in western Russia and more than 100 vehicles parked at an airfield in Belarus, near the border with Ukraine, according to US space technology company Maxar.

US applies sanctions to companies involved in the construction of Nord Stream 2
The announcement comes after Germany announced the suspension of the controversial oil pipeline.
Construction work on the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline in Lubmin, Germany., March 2019
¬©¬†Tobias SCHWARZ / AFP
Dinheiro Vivo/Lusa
23¬†February,¬†2022¬†‚Ä¢¬†20:58
Share
this article

Email

Comment
The United States (USA) announced this Wednesday the application of sanctions to companies that participated in the construction of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, which connects Russia to Germany, and their executives, due to Russian actions in eastern Ukraine.
Related
Germany promises to compensate its population for rising gas prices
Marcelo convenes the Superior Council for National Defense for this Thursday
Ukraine: EU leaders discuss worsening emergency conflict in Brussels today
In a statement, US President Joe Biden thanked German Chancellor Olaf Scholz for the coordinated effort between the two countries and made it clear that he "will not hesitate" to adopt new measures against Russia if Moscow continues to move against Ukraine.
"Yesterday [Tuesday], after close consultations between our two Governments, Germany announced that it would suspend certification of the gas pipeline. Today, I directed my administration to impose sanctions on Nord Stream 2 AG and its corporate directors," Biden announced.
"These measures are another part of our initial tranche of sanctions in response to Russia's actions in Ukraine. As I have made clear, we will not hesitate to take further action if Russia continues to escalate," the US head of state added.

Thank you very much for your registration.
Biden also blamed his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin, for "providing the world with an overwhelming incentive" to move away from Russian gas.
"I want to thank Chancellor Scholz for his close partnership and continued dedication to holding Russia accountable for its actions," concluded the US leader.
Biden's announcement, aimed at one of the biggest geostrategic initiatives in energy-rich Russia, comes after Germany announced the suspension of the controversial oil pipeline.
Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced on Tuesday the suspension of the certification process for the gas pipeline, whose construction ended last year, without having received a license to start operating.
The German leader, who until now had avoided commenting on the future of the gas pipeline, despite pressure for its suspension, ended up taking the decision after Russia recognized the pro-Russian separatist regions in eastern Ukraine.
The 1,235-kilometer Nord Stream 2 was built to transport Russian gas directly to Germany without passing through Ukraine, like its predecessor, Nord Stream 1, in operation since 2011.
The initial major energy project was signed by then German Chancellor Gerhard Schr√∂der (1998-2005) and Russian President Vladimir Putin in April 2005, months before Angela Merkel came to power.

The United States (USA) today announced the application of sanctions to companies that participated in the construction of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, which connects Russia to Germany, and their executives, due to Russian actions in eastern Ukraine.
In a statement, US President Joe Biden thanked German Chancellor Olaf Scholz for the coordinated effort between the two countries and made it clear that he "will not hesitate" to adopt new measures against Russia if Moscow continues to move against Ukraine.
"Yesterday [Tuesday], after close consultations between our two Governments, Germany announced that it would suspend certification of the gas pipeline. Today, I directed my administration to impose sanctions on Nord Stream 2 AG and its corporate directors," Biden announced.
"These measures are another part of our initial tranche of sanctions in response to Russia's actions in Ukraine. As I have made clear, we will not hesitate to take further action if Russia continues to escalate," the US head of state added.
Biden also blamed his Russian counterpart, Vladimir Putin, for "providing the world with an overwhelming incentive" to move away from Russian gas.
"I want to thank Chancellor Scholz for his close partnership and continued dedication to holding Russia accountable for its actions," concluded the US leader.
Biden's announcement, aimed at one of the biggest geostrategic initiatives in energy-rich Russia, comes after Germany announced the suspension of the controversial oil pipeline.
Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced on Tuesday the suspension of the certification process for the gas pipeline, whose construction ended last year, without having received a license to start operating.
The German leader, who until now had avoided commenting on the future of the gas pipeline, despite pressure for its suspension, ended up taking the decision after Russia recognized the pro-Russian separatist regions in eastern Ukraine.
The 1,235-kilometer Nord Stream 2 was built to transport Russian gas directly to Germany without passing through Ukraine, like its predecessor, Nord Stream 1, in operation since 2011.
The initial major energy project was signed by then German Chancellor Gerhard Schr√∂der (1998-2005) and Russian President Vladimir Putin in April 2005, months before Angela Merkel came to power.

Separatist attack in Luhansk killed a Ukrainian soldier and injured six others
Feb 22, 2022 - 9:33 pm ‚Ä¢
Lusa
Since the beginning of the year, eight Ukrainian Armed Forces soldiers and one civilian have died in clashes with separatist forces, most of them from artillery fire.
A+
/
A-
Photo: Reuters
A Ukrainian soldier died and six others were injured following attacks by pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine, an Army source revealed this Tuesday, at a time when tensions in that region are increasing.
"A soldier died" in the Lugansk region, the military spokesman for the Ukrainian Army, Pavlo Kovalchuk, told France Presse (AFP), without specifying where the other soldiers were injured.
After several days of escalating conflict between Ukrainian forces and pro-Russian separatists, Ukrainian authorities said that this Tuesday was a day of relative calm.
The AFP reporting team witnessed continuous missile fire in several areas of Luhansk.
Since the beginning of the year, with the escalation of the conflict in eastern Ukraine, eight soldiers from the Ukrainian Armed Forces and one civilian have died in clashes with separatist forces, most of them by artillery fire.
In 2021, according to the Armed Forces of Ukraine, 66 soldiers died in the two self-proclaimed republics of Donetsk and Lugansk.
Ukraine/Russia tension
Putin makes sending troops to Donbas dependent on the situation on the ground
Russian president justifies recognition of independence(...)
See more
Russia on Monday recognized the two separatist Ukrainian territories in the Donbass region as independent and Moscow clarified that the recognition refers to the territory occupied when the self-proclaimed republics proclaimed this status in 2014, which includes space currently held by Ukrainian forces.
Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
The Russian head of state stated that the deployment of Russian troops to the Donbass region will depend on the situation on the ground, where clashes "continue" and tend to worsen.
The decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.
The EU approved a "sanctions package" against Russia "unanimously", revealed the head of European diplomacy, Josep Borrell.
The United Kingdom also announced sanctions against three oligarchs known to be close to Russian President Vladimir Putin and against five Russian banks.
German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said that Berlin took measures to interrupt the certification process for the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, for the distribution of Russian natural gas to Germany.

Ukraine: Putin says Russian interests are "non-negotiable" but is "open to dialogue"
President of Russia praised Russian military capabilities, but said he was ready to find "diplomatic solutions" to the Ukraine crisis.
¬©¬†EPA/ALEKSEY NIKOLSKYI/SPUTNIK/KREMLIN POOL / POOL
DN/Lusa
23¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†08:14
Facebook
Twitter
Comment
Share

Ukraine
International
Russia
Vladimir Putin
Related
international
"Putin will go as far as he is allowed to reconstitute the borders of the empire"
pentagon
US will deploy 800 more troops to the Baltic countries
ukraine
UK considers total invasion of Ukraine "highly likely"
The President of Russia insisted this Wednesday that the country's interests and security are "non-negotiable", praised Russian military capabilities, but said he was ready to find "diplomatic solutions" to the Ukraine crisis.
"Our country is always open to direct and honest dialogue to find diplomatic solutions to the most complex problems"
, said Vladimir Putin, in a television speech broadcast on the occasion of Defender of the Fatherland Day.
"However, the interests and security of our citizens are not negotiable for us"
, Putin added.
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
Russia has demanded guarantees from Western countries that Ukraine will never become a member of NATO.
When citing threats to Russia
"the loosening of the arms control system"
and
"NATO's military activities"
, Putin defended, once again, that Russian concerns remain "unanswered".
The Russian President also promised to continue developing the capabilities of the army and navy, "advanced digital technologies" and artificial intelligence, as well as so-called hypersonic weapons.
In recent years, Russia has developed hypersonic missiles, allegedly capable of overcoming any existing shield.
The country is also regularly accused of large-scale cyberattacks and disinformation campaigns against adversaries.
Russia on Monday recognized the two breakaway Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Luhansk as independent.
On Tuesday, Russian authorities clarified that the recognition refers to territory occupied when the self-proclaimed republics announced this status in 2014, which includes space currently held by Ukrainian forces.
Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
Japan, Australia and Canada announce sanctions against Russia and separatist territories
Japan, Australia and Canada announced sanctions against Russia and the pro-Russian separatist territories of Luhansk and Donetsk in the last few hours, which Russian President Vladimir Putin recognized on Monday as independent.
Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said the government will ban new issuance and distribution of Russian sovereign debt securities in Japan in response to "Russia's actions in Ukraine."
Kishida said the country will also ban trade with Luhansk and Donetsk, suspend the issuance of visas to people linked to the two eastern areas of Ukraine and freeze the assets of these individuals in Japan.
The Japanese Prime Minister said that the sanctions will come into force "as soon as possible".
Kishida indicated that Japan is prepared to adopt additional measures, if the situation worsens, in coordination with the remaining G7 member countries, and assured that Japan will do everything to protect the Japanese who are still in Ukraine, despite Tokyo having ten days ago advised its citizens to leave the country.
Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced sanctions against banking institutions such as VEB, one of Russia's largest investment and development banks, and the Russian military bank, among others.
Australia will also impose sanctions against industries in various sectors, such as energy, mining and hydrocarbons, in the regions of Donestsk and Luhansk, which are now covered by sanctions imposed in 2011 on Crimea and Sevastopol, then occupied by Russia.
Morrison said Australia will also ban entry and apply financial sanctions to eight members of Russia's security council, a body that brings together key Russian decision-makers, in particular the leaders of the Army and secret services.
The official said that there are still around 1,400 Australians living in Ukraine and added that he had ordered the urgent processing of visa applications submitted by 1,400 Ukrainians, including students.
Canberra has already contacted a number of companies to prevent a possible cyber attack on Australian critical infrastructure in retaliation for sanctions imposed against Russia, Morrison said.
Canada will now prohibit its citizens "from carrying out any foreign transactions" with the pre-Russian separatist territories of Luhansk and Donetsk.  Canadians are also prohibited from "participating in the purchase of Russian debt."
Prime Minister Justin Trudeau also revealed, at a press conference, sanctions on Russian parliamentarians who voted in favor of the "illegal decision to recognize these territories".
The head of government also explained that up to 460 soldiers from the Canadian Armed Forces will be deployed to Latvia, to reinforce NATO in the face of the threat of a Russian invasion of Ukraine.
The measures revealed by Australia, Japan and Canada follow announcements by other countries and Western bodies, such as the EU, which approved this Tuesday a "sanctions package" against Russia "unanimously".
The United Kingdom announced sanctions against three oligarchs known to be close to Russian President Vladimir Putin and against five Russian banks.
German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said Berlin had taken steps to stop the certification process for the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, for distributing Russian natural gas to Germany.
US President Joe Biden announced a set of economic sanctions on Russian individuals, entities and banks.
Joe Biden stated that the United States of America (USA) is immediately imposing a "total blockade" on two large Russian financial institutions and "comprehensive sanctions" on Russian debt.
Russia on Monday recognized the two separatist Ukrainian territories in the Donbass region as independent and Moscow clarified this Tuesday that the recognition refers to the territory occupied when the self-proclaimed republics proclaimed this status in 2014, which includes space currently held by Ukrainian forces.
Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.

translated_text:
In a note from the BE Political Committee, entitled "No to Russia's imperialist aggression. For an integral and neutral Ukraine", the party led by Catarina Martins states that "in the face of the annexation of Donbass, the Bloc condemns Putin's military adventure, accompanied by an imperialist speech that denies Ukraine's right to exist as an independent State".
"This is a rejection of the Minsk Agreements, violated by both parties over the years. This annexation constitutes, without a doubt, a rupture with the previous process, the partition of the territory of Ukraine, whose borders are recognized by the United Nations, completely in violation of international law. Putin's actions only find significant acceptance in well-known personalities of the European extreme right", he criticizes.
Thus, for BE, "Portugal must condemn Putin's military adventure and distance itself from positions of support for the USA and the expansion of NATO".
Portugal can, in the blocists' analysis, "support the application of sanctions to Russian leaders, their oligarch supporters and their respective international companies, offering its political and diplomatic solidarity to Ukraine for the preservation of its territory".
"The Portuguese government must, within the framework of the European Union, insist on the diplomatic route to define terms for a ceasefire in the Donbass and for coexistence in the region", they argue.
From the blocists' perspective, "the American imposition of NATO weapons and bases along the borders of the Russian Federation results in a worsening of tensions and an escalation of the conflict in the style of the Cold War".
"The Portuguese Government must act so that Ukraine can have a de facto status similar to that of Finland - one of respected neutrality. It is to such a solution, acceptable to all parties, that European diplomacies should commit their efforts", they propose.
BE also recalls a resolution from the party's National Bureau, dated February 5th, in which it warned that "the strengthening of NATO's war machine, under the pretext of military maneuvers by Russian imperialism", endangered "peace in Europe" and that Russia must "unconditionally respect the territorial integrity of Ukraine".
Russian President Vladimir Putin recognized, on Monday, the self-proclaimed people's republics of Donetsk and Luhansk, in Donbass, and authorized the Russian army to send a "peacekeeping" force to those territories in eastern Ukraine.
The decision was taken after months of high tension between Russia and the West, after Moscow concentrated tens of thousands of troops on the borders with neighboring Ukraine, but is part of a dispute that began three decades ago.

National banks have 132 million euros in¬†Russia
Larger banks, questioned by the Observer, say they have little or no exposure to Russia (and Ukraine). But BIS data points to 132 million euros connecting Portuguese banking to Moscow.
Edgar Caetano
Text
23 Feb 2022, 18:23
i
Sergei Fadeichev/TASS
Sergei Fadeichev/TASS
You have free access to all Observador articles by being our subscriber.
The main national banks say, when questioned by the Observer, that they have
little or no exposure to Russia and also Ukraine
‚Äì the two countries that are at the center of a conflict that is creating severe disruption in economies and financial markets. However, according to BIS data,
the Portuguese financial system has an exposure equivalent to 149 million dollars
(or 132 million euros) to Russia.
The Observer questioned the main banks in Portugal about the degree of exposure to Russia (and Ukraine). O
BPI
responded that ‚Äúthe bank does not have any direct or indirect exposure to Russian and/or Ukrainian assets‚Äù, in the same vein as what the
Caixa Geral de Dep√≥sitos
: ‚ÄúWe have no exposure to any of these countries,‚Äù said an official source from the public bank.
Already the
MillenniumBCP
, which has an important presence in Poland, indicated that ‚Äú
no relevant exposure
to the aforementioned geographies‚Äù, that is, Russia and Ukraine. O
Novo Banco did not respond
, until the publication of this work.
However, according to the same BIS data, Portuguese banks have a
149 million dollar exhibition
‚Äì a number that concerns the entire Portuguese financial system since, as an official BIS source explained, the entity does not have disaggregated data.
PUB
‚Ä¢ CONTINUE READING BELOW
The 149 million (dollars) relate to the responsibilities they have
Russian entities as immediate counterparty
, i.e. include all loans or debt securities related to any entity physically located in Russia. These could be exposures to banks but also to Russian companies (or even the public sector).
This value can increase to 157 million if exposures on a guarantee basis are also included, that is, investments or credits to companies guaranteed by an entity (such as a bank) based in Russia.
According to data from the Bank for International Settlements (better known by the Anglo-Saxon acronym BIS), the banks of Italy, France and Austria are those that have the greatest exposure to Russia, with the banks of the first two having an exposure equivalent to 25 billion dollars (each) and the Austrian banks 17.5 billion.
All of these countries have banks with a presence in Russia (including UniCredit and Soci√©t√© G√©n√©rale), which explains why they concentrate a large part of the country's global exposure ‚Äì which, according to BIS, is equivalent to
121.5 billion dollars.

Russian troops also threaten Belarus' independence, says opponent

Belarusian opponent Svetlana Tikhanovskaya warned this Wednesday that the tens of thousands of Russian troops in joint maneuvers in Belarus, which Westerners fear could be used in an attack on Ukraine, also threaten her country's independence.
Belarus must fight for "its independence" and against the "dictatorship", argued Tikhanovskaya,
who is in exile, in an interview today with the AFP agency.
Considered by the West to be the true winner of the August 2020 presidential election,
the Belarusian opponent said she was horrified by the referendum taking place on Sunday on constitutional changes in Belarus, to allow President Alexander Lukashenko to authorize the installation of Russian nuclear weapons in the former Soviet republic.
Close

Subscribe
The Belarusian opposition party urged the United States and Europe to denounce the February 27 referendum.
The Belarusian president, who suppressed the popular protest movement against his re-election in 2020, wants to be "grateful" to the Kremlin, which largely supported him, says Tikhanovskaya.
Military exercises with no end date
"Lukashenko was supported by the Kremlin and now he wants to show him his loyalty (...) it gives ground for military maneuvers", added the Belarusian human rights activist, who estimates the strength of the Russian army in her country at around 30,000 soldiers.
The military exercises were supposed to end on February 20, but Belarus announced that they would continue, without giving an end date.
The Ukrainian capital, Kiev, is just 150 kilometers from the border with Belarus.
Alexander Lukashenko won the 2020 presidential elections with 80.23% of the votes, a vote marked by violence and accusations of fraud, and whose result is not recognized by the European Union, which it considers to have been neither free nor fair.

The Ukrainian Armed Forces announced this Wednesday the mobilization of reservists aged 18 to 60, in light of the worsening military situation caused by Russia.
"The mobilization concerns reservists aged between 18 and 60"
, says a message from the Ukrainian land forces published this Wednesday on the social network Facebook.
"Mobilization begins today (Wednesday). The maximum period of service is one year"
, advance.
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
Ukraine has more than 200,000 reservists, in addition to around 250,000 members of the regular armed forces.
Refusal to attend this recruitment without a plausible reason may be subject to "administrative and criminal sanctions", the armed forces also say.
On Tuesday, the President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky had already determined the partial mobilization of military personnel in reserve to reinforce the Army, but ruled out the total mobilization of the armed forces.
Zelensky explained, in a communication to the country on Tuesday, that the decree applied only to Ukrainians in the operational reserve, mobilized to reinforce the Army that fights pro-Russian militias in the Donbass region and faces the Russian military threat on the border.
The National Police of Ukraine also announced this Wednesday that it will send additional forces to the conflict zone in the east of the country to ensure public order.
The "number two" of the National Police, Oleksandr Fatsevich, also told the press that the additional agents will be sent before the end of the week.
Meanwhile, the Ukrainian Ministry of Foreign Affairs called on national citizens this Wednesday to leave Russia as quickly as possible in the face of the worsening military situation.
"The ministry recommends Ukrainian citizens to refrain from all travel to Russia and those already there should leave (Russian) territory immediately."
, Kiev diplomacy indicated in a statement.
Russia, which invaded Ukraine in 2014 and annexed the Crimean peninsula, recognized on Monday as independent the two separatist Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Luhansk, in the Donbass region, worsening the military situation in the region.
Moscow also approved the sending of Russian military personnel to the area.

translated_text:
A
Ukraine suffered a new cyber attack this Wednesday, the third in the space of a few weeks, against state and banking sector websites, the Minister of Digital Transformation, Mykhailo Fedorov, reported today.
"At approximately 4pm local time (minus two hours in Lisbon), another massive DDOS (or Distributed Denial of Service, in English) attack began in our state," said Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Digital Transformation, Mikhail Fyodorov, on his official account on the social network Telegram, adding that the Parliament's website was also affected.
According to Reuters, several state websites and services from Ukrainian institutions, including the Ministries of Health, Security and Foreign Affairs, were disabled.
Several banks were also affected, although the minister did not clarify which ones.
The Ukrainian authorities announced, on Tuesday of last week, the 15th, that a computer attack was affecting the official websites of the Ministry of Defense and the Armed Forces of Ukraine, as well as the online activities of the banks Privatbank and Ochtchbank.
The government center for strategic communications and information security pointed the finger at the "aggressor", without explicitly mentioning Russia, in a statement published on its page on the social network Facebook.
Russia today denied any involvement in these computer attacks.
In January, Ukraine had already been the target of a major cyber attack against several government websites.
Authorities then claimed to have proof of Russia's involvement.

Russian Defense Minister on European sanctions list
The sanctions list also includes two banks and "some countries are calling for Russian oligarchs to be included in the upcoming sanctions."
¬©¬†EPA/JASON SZENES
Jo√£o Francisco Guerreiro, in Brussels
23¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†15:45

Ukraine is the target of a "massive" cyber attack
The 27 decided to include Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu on the list of targets for European sanctions. According to information collected by DN, the political decision of the Foreign Affairs ministers was confirmed by the permanent representatives, who were meeting since 10:00, in Brussels.
The list also includes "two Russian banks". According to a European source, "some countries are calling for Russian oligarchs to be included in the upcoming sanctions."
"The Russian Ambassador in Brussels will now be formally informed of the decision," added the same source.
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
On Tuesday, the head of European diplomacy admitted that this list could be expanded if the situation deteriorated. This was also the emphasis of the president of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen.
"Our action is a response to Russia's aggressive behavior. If Russia continues to ride out this crisis that it has created, we are ready to take further action in response", von der Leyen had stated, stressing that "the European Union is united and acting quickly".
The inclusion of the Minister of Defense follows from the list of criteria approved by the Ministers of Foreign Affairs.
"Firstly, the decision-makers responsible for threatening Ukraine and those who are financially and materially supporting or benefiting from them, those in the defense sector who have played a role in the invasion and destabilization actions and those waging a disinformation war against Ukraine, and the banks that provide financing to Russian decision-makers and other operations in those territories", clarified Josep Borrell.
The list also includes "351 members of the Russian parliament, the Duma, who voted to violate international law, territorial integrity, and the sovereignty of Ukraine will be included in our sanctions list," he added.
Charles Michel calls heads of state or government to Brussels
European Council President Charles Michel called European leaders to a last-minute summit to assess "the latest developments" and decide "how to deal with Russia."
Charles Michel has already issued 27 invitation letters, which he sent to European capitals, calling on governments for a "special European Council on Thursday, February 24th, which will take place in person in Brussels and begin at 8 pm".
In the letter, the president of the European Council begins by noting that "the use of force and coercion to change borders has no place in the 21st century".
"I would like to thank you for the unity demonstrated in recent days, particularly through the rapid adoption of the sanctions package by the Council today", he continues.
Charles Michel criticizes "the aggressive actions of the Russian Federation", which "violate international law and the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine. They also undermine the European security order".
"It is important that we remain united and determined and jointly define our approach and collective actions", he highlighted in the letter.
At the emergency meeting, Charles Michel "would like the latest developments to be discussed".
The debate will also discuss "how we protect the rules-based international order", and "how we deal with Russia, including holding Russia accountable for its actions"
Finally, Michel understands that ways should be discussed on how to "continue to support Ukraine and its people".

Home

Zelensky mobilizes military reserves to reinforce the Army
Military exercises will take place "soon" for Ukrainians in reserve status who will make up territorial defense units, President Volodymyr Zelensky announced. He assured that, for now, "there is no need for general mobilization".
President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelensky
¬©¬†EPA/JOHANNA GERON
DN/Lusa
22¬†February¬†2022¬†‚Äî¬†23:06
Facebook
Twitter
Comment
Share

Ukraine
Volodymyr Zelensky
International
Related
ukraine
Putin denies imperial ambition but US says "invasion" has already begun
USA
US cancels meeting with Russian Foreign Minister. "It doesn't make sense"
pentagon
US will deploy 800 more troops to the Baltic countries
The President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, ordered this Tuesday the partial mobilization of military personnel in reserve to reinforce the Army, but ruled out for now a total mobilization of the armed forces, given the increase in the Russian threat.
Zelensky explained, in a communication to the country, that this new decree applies only to Ukrainians in the operational reserve, mobilized to reinforce the Army that fights pro-Russian militias in the Donbass region and faces the Russian military threat on the border.
The Ukrainian head of state added that, normally, this reserve is activated during periods of hostilities and that it covers "a special period of time", without specifying.
Close
Subscribe to newsletters
News Diary
and receive information first hand.
Subscribe
"We need to quickly add additional personnel to the Ukrainian Army and other military formations," he stressed.
The Armed Forces of Ukraine comprise around 250,000 soldiers and have a reserve of around 140,000, reports the Associated Press (AP).
Zelensky also announced that military exercises will take place "soon" for the Ukrainians in reserve status who will make up the territorial defense units.
The president of Ukraine ordered an increase in the number of members in these units to two million, which includes hunters and forest guards.
But he assured that, for now, "there is no need for general mobilization" among the population, something that pro-Russian separatists did on Saturday with all men of legal age.
Zelensky rules out a full-scale war with Russia
In his address to the nation, Zelensky also ruled out a large-scale war with Russia and, in this way, rejected the imposition of martial law in the Donbas region, despite Moscow's recognition of the independence of the two self-proclaimed separatist republics, Donetsk and Lugansk.
The President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, announced that the Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
Zelensky, who considered Moscow's recognition a violation of his country's territorial integrity, did not go ahead with breaking diplomatic relations with Russia, despite having already admitted this scenario and being pressured to do so.
The Ukrainian head of state also regretted that the West did not adopt preventive sanctions against Russia before Moscow recognized the separatist republics.
But he welcomed the decisions already imposed, such as Germany's suspension of the certification of the controversial Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, which was supposed to transport Russian gas directly to Germany, without passing through Ukrainian territory.
Also today, the EU approved a "sanctions package" against Russia "unanimously", revealed the head of European diplomacy, Josep Borrell.
The United Kingdom also announced sanctions against three oligarchs known to be close to Russian President Vladimir Putin and against five Russian banks.
US President Joe Biden announced this Tuesday a set of economic sanctions on Russian individuals, entities and banks.
Joe Biden stated that the United States of America (USA) is immediately imposing a "total blockade" on two large Russian financial institutions and "comprehensive sanctions" on Russian debt.

During a seminar in The Hague on the future of NATO, Stoltenberg explained that "strong political, practical and financial support will continue to be provided to help Ukraine build its defense capabilities (...) and defend its right to self-defense".
"Today we face the most dangerous moment for European security. Our highly valued partner, Ukraine, remains under imminent threat from Russia. NATO allies stand united in full support of Ukraine's territorial integrity and sovereignty within its internationally recognized borders," Stoltenberg said.
The Secretary General of the Alliance also warned that "the risk of conflict is real" and explained that "Moscow is challenging fundamental security principles, such as NATO's right to protect and defend its allies and the right of each nation to choose its path".
"(Russia) is using force and resorting to ultimatums. Not just to redraw borders in Europe, but to try to rewrite the entire global security architecture," Stoltenberg added.
For the leader of the Alliance, NATO and the European Union (EU) are "two sides of the same coin, with different roles, limits and members, but which complement each other".
Stoltenberg stressed that, "while the EU is making the most of its entire toolbox in relation to the current crisis", NATO "has significantly increased its presence in the eastern region and is ready to do even more".
Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte, who also participated in the seminar in The Hague, highlighted that, "in an unprecedented move, Russia threatens war on Europe's eastern border", classifying this gesture as a "serious escalation and a flagrant violation of Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity", referring to Moscow's recognition of the self-proclaimed separatist republics of Donetsk and Luhansk.
"It is undoubtedly a threat to Ukraine, but it is also a threat to European and international security (...). We must be clear: there are no old or new members, Western or Eastern, first or second class. We are all NATO allies", concluded the head of Government of the Netherlands.

Belarusian opponent Svetlana Tikhanovskaya warned today that the tens of thousands of Russian troops in joint maneuvers in Belarus, which Westerners fear could be used in an attack on Ukraine, also threaten her country's independence.
Belarus must fight for "its independence" and against the "dictatorship", argued Tikhanovskaya, who is in exile, in an interview today with the French agency France-Presse.
Considered by the West to be the true winner of the August 2020 presidential election, the Belarusian opponent said she was horrified by the referendum taking place on Sunday on constitutional changes in Belarus, to allow President Alexander Lukashenko to authorize the installation of Russian nuclear weapons in the former Soviet republic.
The Belarusian opposition party urged the United States and Europe to denounce the February 27 referendum.
The Belarusian President, who repressed the popular protest movement against his re-election in 2020, wants to be "grateful" to the Kremlin, which largely supported him, says Tikhanovskaya.
"Lukashenko was supported by the Kremlin and now he wants to show him his loyalty (...) it gives ground for military maneuvers", added the Belarusian human rights activist, who estimates the strength of the Russian army in her country at around 30,000 soldiers.
The military exercises were supposed to end on February 20, but Belarus announced that they would continue, without giving an end date.
The Ukrainian capital, Kiev, is just 150 kilometers from the border with Belarus.
Alexander Lukashenko won the 2020 presidential elections with 80.23% of the votes, a vote marked by violence and accusations of fraud, and whose result is not recognized by the European Union, which it considers to have been neither free nor fair.

Zelensky mobilizes reserve soldiers to reinforce Ukrainian army
Zelensky explained that this new decree applies only to Ukrainians in the operational reserve, mobilized to reinforce the army fighting pro-Russian militias in the Donbass region.
Lusa Agency
Text
23 Feb 2022, 00:04
i
‚ñ≤
Zelensky also announced that military exercises will take place "soon" for the Ukrainians in reserve status who will make up the territorial defense units
SERGEY DOLZHENKO/EPA
‚ñ≤
Zelensky also announced that military exercises will take place "soon" for the Ukrainians in reserve status who will make up the territorial defense units
SERGEY DOLZHENKO/EPA
The President of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelensky, ordered this Tuesday the partial mobilization of military personnel in reserve to reinforce the Army, but ruled out for now a total mobilization of the armed forces, given the increase in the Russian threat.
Zelensky explained, in a communication to the country, that this new decree applies only to Ukrainians in the operational reserve, mobilized to reinforce the Army that fights pro-Russian militias in the Donbass region and faces the Russian military threat on the border.
The Ukrainian head of state added that, normally, and
This reserve is activated during a period of hostilities and covers ‚Äúa special period of time‚Äù
, without specifying.
‚ÄúWe need to quickly add additional personnel to the Ukrainian Army and other military formations,‚Äù he stressed.
PUB
‚Ä¢ CONTINUE READING BELOW
The
Ukraine's Armed Forces comprise around 250,000 personnel
and has a reserve of around 140,000, reports the Associated Press (AP).
Zelensky also announced that military exercises will take place ‚Äúsoon‚Äù for the Ukrainians in reserve status who will make up the territorial defense units.
The President of Ukraine determined the
increase in the number of members in these units
to two million, including hunters and rangers.
But he assured that, for now, ‚Äúthere is no need for general mobilization‚Äù among the population, something that pro-Russian separatists did on Saturday with all men of legal age.
In his address to the nation,
Zelensky also ruled out a full-scale war with Russia
and, in this way, rejected the imposition of martial law in the Donbass region, despite Moscow's recognition of the independence of the two self-proclaimed separatist republics, of Donetsk and Lugansk.
The President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, announced that the Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a ‚Äúpeacekeeping‚Äù mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
Zelensky, who considered Moscow's recognition a violation of his country's territorial integrity, did not go ahead with breaking diplomatic relations with Russia, despite having already admitted this scenario and being pressured to do so.
The Ukrainian head of state also regretted that the West did not adopt preventive sanctions against Russia before Moscow recognized the separatist republics.
But he welcomed the decisions already imposed, such as Germany's suspension of the certification of the controversial Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, which was supposed to transport Russian gas directly to Germany, without passing through Ukrainian territory.
Also this Tuesday, the EU approved a ‚Äúsanctions package‚Äù against Russia ‚Äúunanimously‚Äù, revealed the head of European diplomacy, Josep Borrell.
The United Kingdom also announced sanctions against three oligarchs known to be close to Russian President Vladimir Putin and against five Russian banks.
US President Joe Biden announced a set of economic sanctions on Russian individuals, entities and banks.
Joe Biden stated that the United States of America (USA) is immediately imposing a ‚Äútotal blockade‚Äù on two large Russian financial institutions and ‚Äúcomprehensive sanctions‚Äù on Russian debt.

translated_text:
Country
BE argues that Portugal "must condemn Putin's military adventure"
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
15:41
0
Comments
BE argued today that Portugal should condemn "the military adventure" of Russian President Vladimir Putin in relation to Ukraine, but distance itself from "positions in support of the USA and the expansion of NATO".
In a note from the BE Political Committee, entitled "No to Russia's imperialist aggression. For an integral and neutral Ukraine", the party led by Catarina Martins states that "in the face of the annexation of Donbass, the Bloc condemns Putin's military adventure, accompanied by an imperialist speech that denies Ukraine's right to exist as an independent State".
"This is a rejection of the Minsk Agreements, violated by both parties over the years. This annexation constitutes, without a doubt, a rupture with the previous process, the partition of the territory of Ukraine, whose borders are recognized by the United Nations, completely in violation of international law. Putin's actions only find significant acceptance in well-known personalities of the European extreme right", he criticizes.
Thus, for BE, "Portugal must condemn Putin's military adventure and distance itself from positions of support for the USA and the expansion of NATO".
Portugal can, in the blocists' analysis, "support the application of sanctions to Russian leaders, their oligarch supporters and their respective international companies, offering its political and diplomatic solidarity to Ukraine for the preservation of its territory".
"The Portuguese government must, within the framework of the European Union, insist on the diplomatic route to define terms for a ceasefire in the Donbass and for coexistence in the region", they argue.
From the blocists' perspective, "the American imposition of NATO weapons and bases along the borders of the Russian Federation results in a worsening of tensions and an escalation of the conflict in the style of the Cold War".
"The Portuguese Government must act so that Ukraine can have a de facto status similar to that of Finland - one of respected neutrality. It is to such a solution, acceptable to all parties, that European diplomacies should commit their efforts", they propose.
BE also recalls a resolution from the party's National Bureau, dated February 5th, in which it warned that "the strengthening of NATO's war machine, under the pretext of military maneuvers by Russian imperialism", endangered "peace in Europe" and that Russia must "unconditionally respect the territorial integrity of Ukraine".
Russian President Vladimir Putin recognized, on Monday, the self-proclaimed people's republics of Donetsk and Luhansk, in Donbass, and authorized the Russian army to send a "peacekeeping" force to those territories in eastern Ukraine.
The decision was taken after months of high tension between Russia and the West, after Moscow concentrated tens of thousands of troops on the borders with neighboring Ukraine, but is part of a dispute that began three decades ago.

original_text:
