No s√°bado, durante a visita oficial a Havana do vice-primeiro-ministro russo, Yuri Borissov, Cuba j√° havia criticado fortemente a "histeria da propaganda" de Washington contra a R√∫ssia e a "expans√£o" da NATO nas suas fronteiras.
O documento hoje divulgado surge horas antes da visita √† ilha caribenha do presidente da Duma, Vyacheslav Volodin, e ap√≥s a valida√ß√£o de um projeto de reestrutura√ß√£o da d√≠vida cubana de 2,3 mil milh√µes de d√≥lares (cerca de dois mil milh√µes de euros), pelos deputados russos, de acordo com ag√™ncia de not√≠cias Prensa Latina (Cuba).
Volodin inicia hoje uma visita oficial a Cuba, numa altura em que aumentam as tens√µes entre Moscovo e o Ocidente, devido √† crise na Ucr√¢nia.
Num comunicado publicado no seu 'site' na Internet, o parlamento cubano (unicameral) informou que o presidente da Duma ser√° recebido pelo presidente o organismo legislativo, Esteban Lazo, e "abordar√° o fortalecimento da coopera√ß√£o bilateral e dos la√ßos interparlamentares".
A delega√ß√£o russa seguir√° depois para a Nicar√°gua, outro pa√≠s aliado de Havana.
Cuba enfrenta a pior crise econ√≥mica em 27 anos devido ao aperto do embargo dos Estados Unidos e ao impacto da pandemia no turismo, 'motor' da economia.
Havana "deixou de pagar desde o in√≠cio de 2020 [...] os reembolsos de quatro acordo de empr√©stimos intergovernamentais" concedidos entre 2006 e 2019, acrescentou a Prensa Latina.
As visitas dos altos funcion√°rios russos a Cuba acontecem depois de uma conversa telef√≥nica em janeiro entre o Presidente da R√∫ssia, Vladimir Putin, e o seu hom√≥logo cubano Miguel D√≠az-Canel, onde discutiram o refor√ßo da "parceria estrat√©gica" entre Moscovo e Havana.
Na ter√ßa-feira, o Presidente da Venezuela, Nicol√°s Maduro, outro aliado do Kremlin na Am√©rica Latina, garantiu a Vladimir Putin o seu apoio na crise com a Ucr√¢nia: "A Venezuela est√° com Putin, ela est√° com a R√∫ssia. Ela [Venezuela] est√° com os corajosos e as causas justas no mundo".

translated_text:
The "determination of the United States to impose the progressive expansion of NATO to the borders of the Russian Federation constitutes a threat to its national security and regional and international peace", considered the Cuban Ministry of Foreign Affairs, cited in a statement, advocating "a diplomatic solution through a constructive and respectful dialogue".
In the text, the ministry states that the United States "has been threatening Russia for weeks and manipulating the international community about the dangers of an imminent mass invasion of Ukraine", supplying weapons and deploying troops in neighboring countries.
On Saturday, during the official visit to Havana by Russian Deputy Prime Minister Yuri Borissov, Cuba had already strongly criticized Washington's "propaganda hysteria" against Russia and the "expansion" of NATO on its borders.
The document released today comes hours before the visit to the Caribbean island by the President of the Duma, Vyacheslav Volodin, and after the validation of a project to restructure Cuban debt worth 2.3 billion dollars (around two billion euros), by Russian deputies, according to the news agency Prensa Latina (Cuba).
Volodin begins an official visit to Cuba today, at a time when tensions between Moscow and the West are increasing due to the crisis in Ukraine.
In a statement published on its website, the Cuban parliament (unicameral) said that the president of the Duma will be received by the president of the legislative body, Esteban Lazo, and "will address the strengthening of bilateral cooperation and interparliamentary ties."
The Russian delegation will then head to Nicaragua, another country allied with Havana.
Cuba is facing the worst economic crisis in 27 years due to the tightening of the United States embargo and the impact of the pandemic on tourism, the 'engine' of the economy.
Havana "has stopped paying since the beginning of 2020 [...] the repayments of four intergovernmental loan agreements" granted between 2006 and 2019, Prensa Latina added.
The visits of senior Russian officials to Cuba follow a telephone conversation in January between the President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, and his Cuban counterpart Miguel D√≠az-Canel, where they discussed strengthening the "strategic partnership" between Moscow and Havana.
On Tuesday, the President of Venezuela, Nicol√°s Maduro, another Kremlin ally in Latin America, assured Vladimir Putin of his support in the crisis with Ukraine: "Venezuela is with Putin, she is with Russia. She [Venezuela] is with the brave and the just causes in the world".

decision was condemned by most Western countries, which

EU sanctions target defense minister and two Russian banks
Feb 23, 2022 - 16:11 ‚Ä¢
Lusa
Some countries are calling for Russian oligarchs to be included in the next sanctions, a position that was expressed at the meeting of the committee of representatives.
A+
/
A-
Photo: EPA
See also:
By the minute. Ukraine target of cyber attack, sanctions on Russia could reach ‚Äúunprecedented scale‚Äù
Europe can apply sanctions "on a scale never seen before" to Russia, guarantees Santos Silva
Putin. ‚ÄúRussia‚Äôs interests and the security of its citizens are non-negotiable‚Äù
Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu and two private Russian banks are among those targeted by European Union (EU) sanctions on Moscow following President Vladimir Putin's recognition of separatist territories in eastern Ukraine.
The information was provided to the Lusa agency today by European sources after the final confirmation by the Committee of Permanent Representatives of the Governments of the Member States of the European Union to the sanctions approved by the 27 Foreign Ministers, on Tuesday.
According to the same sources, the "approval of the sanctions is confirmed", covering "two Russian banks", as well as the "Russian Minister of Defense".
"The Russian ambassador in Brussels will be informed," they added.
Also according to these European sources, "some countries are asking for Russian oligarchs to be included in the next sanctions", a position that was expressed at the meeting of the committee of representatives.
On Tuesday night, member states' ambassadors to the EU gave final approval to the list of European sanctions on Russia, following Russian recognition of separatist territories in eastern Ukraine.
Confirmation followed today.
Also on Tuesday night, the head of EU diplomacy, Josep Borrell, announced the approval, unanimously among the 27 member states of the community bloc, of a package of sanctions against Russia, aiming to "hit hard" the Russian authorities.
Specifically, the sanctions cover 27 individuals and entities from the political, military, business and media sectors, in addition to around 350 members of the lower house of the Russian parliament (Duma), as Lusa had already advanced.
Also as Lusa has advanced, with regard to financial sanctions, restrictions are expected on the EU's economic relations with the two separatist regions, Donetsk and Luhansk, as well as the freezing of assets of two Russian private banks and limits on the Russian State's ability to access the EU's capital and financial markets.
Today, the President of the European Council, Charles Michel, called an extraordinary summit of EU heads of state and government for Thursday, in Brussels, to discuss the escalation of tension between Ukraine and Russia.
The EU's position comes after Russian President Vladimir Putin signed, on Monday night, a decree recognizing the self-proclaimed republics of Luhansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and ordered the mobilization of the Russian army to "maintain peace" in these pro-Russian separatist territories.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.

A Russian invasion of Ukraine could generate a "new refugee crisis" with five million people displaced, the United States ambassador to the UN General Assembly in New York warned this Wednesday.
"If Russia continues on this path, it could - according to our estimates - create a new refugee crisis, one of the biggest today," said Linda Thomas-Greenfield.
The Ukrainian Armed Forces announced today the mobilization of soldiers aged between 18 and 60 in reserve, to face the worsening military situation caused by Russia.
"The mobilization concerns reservists aged between 18 and 60", says a message from the Ukrainian land forces posted on Facebook. "The mobilization starts today (Wednesday). The maximum period of service is one year", he adds.

translated_text:
World
Cuba believes Russia "has the right to defend itself" from threats
Lusa Agency
Feb 23, 2022
21:19
0
Comments
Photo: EPA/ZURAB KURTSIKIDZE
The Cuban Government maintained today that Russia "has the right to defend itself", asking the United States and NATO to respond to Moscow's "legitimate requests for security guarantees" in the Ukrainian crisis.
The "determination of the United States to impose the progressive expansion of NATO to the borders of the Russian Federation constitutes a threat to its national security and regional and international peace", considered the Cuban Ministry of Foreign Affairs, cited in a statement, advocating "a diplomatic solution through a constructive and respectful dialogue".
In the text, the ministry states that the United States "has been threatening Russia for weeks and manipulating the international community about the dangers of an imminent mass invasion of Ukraine", supplying weapons and deploying troops in neighboring countries.
On Saturday, during the official visit to Havana by Russian Deputy Prime Minister Yuri Borissov, Cuba had already strongly criticized Washington's "propaganda hysteria" against Russia and the "expansion" of NATO on its borders.
The document released today comes hours before the visit to the Caribbean island by the President of the Duma, Vyacheslav Volodin, and after the validation of a project to restructure Cuban debt worth 2.3 billion dollars (around two billion euros), by Russian deputies, according to the news agency Prensa Latina (Cuba).
Volodin begins an official visit to Cuba today, at a time when tensions between Moscow and the West are increasing due to the crisis in Ukraine.
In a statement published on its website, the Cuban parliament (unicameral) said that the president of the Duma will be received by the president of the legislative body, Esteban Lazo, and "will address the strengthening of bilateral cooperation and interparliamentary ties."
The Russian delegation will then head to Nicaragua, another country allied with Havana.
Cuba is facing the worst economic crisis in 27 years due to the tightening of the United States embargo and the impact of the pandemic on tourism, the 'engine' of the economy.
Havana "has stopped paying since the beginning of 2020 [...] the repayments of four intergovernmental loan agreements" granted between 2006 and 2019, Prensa Latina added.
The visits of senior Russian officials to Cuba follow a telephone conversation in January between the President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, and his Cuban counterpart Miguel D√≠az-Canel, where they discussed strengthening the "strategic partnership" between Moscow and Havana.
On Tuesday, the President of Venezuela, Nicol√°s Maduro, another Kremlin ally in Latin America, assured Vladimir Putin of his support in the crisis with Ukraine: "Venezuela is with Putin, she is with Russia. She [Venezuela] is with the brave and the just causes in the world".

The President of Russia insisted today that the country's interests and security are "non-negotiable", praised Russian military capabilities, but said he was ready to find "diplomatic solutions" to the Ukraine crisis.
"Our country is always open to direct and honest dialogue to find diplomatic solutions to the most complex problems", said Vladimir Putin, in a televised speech broadcast on the occasion of Defender of the Fatherland Day.
"However, the interests and security of our citizens are non-negotiable for us," Putin added.
Russia has demanded guarantees from Western countries that Ukraine will never become a member of NATO.
Citing as threats to Russia "the loosening of the arms control system" and "NATO's military activities", Putin argued, once again, that Russian concerns remain "unanswered".
The Russian President also promised to continue developing the capabilities of the army and navy, "advanced digital technologies" and artificial intelligence, as well as so-called hypersonic weapons.
In recent years, Russia has developed hypersonic missiles, allegedly capable of overcoming any existing shield.
The country is also regularly accused of large-scale cyberattacks and disinformation campaigns against adversaries.
Russia on Monday recognized the two breakaway Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Luhansk as independent.
On Tuesday, Russian authorities clarified that the recognition refers to territory occupied when the self-proclaimed republics announced this status in 2014, which includes space currently held by Ukrainian forces.
Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.

translated_text:
World
Russia's "warlike" intentions in Venezuela condemned by the opposition
Lusa Agency
Feb 22, 2022
22:31
0
Comments
Photo AFP/File
The Venezuelan opposition today condemned Russia's alleged intentions to use Venezuela for military purposes to pressure the United States, and expressed support for Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky.
"We condemn Russia's intentions to use Venezuelan territory for military purposes, as we have already denounced," said opposition leader Juan Guaid√≥.
The politician was speaking during a meeting with opposition deputies elected in 2015, during which he stressed that "the role of the opposition in the conflict continues to be to recover democracy in Venezuela, distancing ourselves from Russia's intentions of invading Ukraine."
Guaid√≥ also highlighted that the Venezuelan opposition also "condemns that Cuba and Nicaragua use Venezuelan territory to promote their regimes."
This was the second time that the Venezuelan opposition expressed solidarity with Ukraine, after Russian President Vladimir Putin recognized the independence of the self-proclaimed separatist republics of Donetsk and Lugansk and ordered the mobilization of military personnel for "peacekeeping" operations in these Ukrainian territories.
"We reject and ignore these supposed 'republics' controlled by Russia and demand respect for the right of each people to choose their destiny autonomously," the opposition said in a press release, calling for this recognition to be "unconditionally repudiated" by all democrats, who "stand up to global authoritarianism" in all its forms.
On February 17, President Nicol√°s Maduro expressed support for Russia in the face of Western threats.
"Russia has the full support of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela in the fight it is waging to dispel the threats from NATO [North Atlantic Treaty Organization] and the Western world. Russia has the full support to dispel all threats and so that it continues to be a territory of peace," said President Nicol√°s Maduro in Caracas, during a visit by Russia's Deputy Prime Minister, Yuri Ivanovich Borisov.
"Relations between Russia and Venezuela are increasingly acquiring a greater strategic level, greater quality and depth in their results and greater historical strength", he added.
On Monday, the United Socialist Party of Venezuela (in power) argued that "Russia has every right to defend its position and its territory".
"Russia carries out maneuvers with Belarus and gives them (the USA and Europe) tachycardia. It's understandable because these people are used to doing what they want in the world", the vice-president of the PSUV, Diosdado Cabello, told journalists.
On January 13, Russia's Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs, Serguei Riabkov, told RTVI TV that he "neither confirms nor excludes" the possibility of Russia sending military equipment to Cuba and Venezuela, in the event of a failure in talks and an increase in US pressure on Russia, according to the Associated Press (AP) news agency.
Riabkov, who led the Russian delegation in recent talks with the USA in Geneva, noted that "everything depends on American action", pointing out that President Putin has already warned that Moscow may adopt technical-military measures if Washington provokes the Kremlin and increases its military pressure.

No discurso √† na√ß√£o, Zelensky descartou ainda uma guerra em larga escala com a R√∫ssia e, desta forma, rejeitou a imposi√ß√£o de uma lei marcial na regi√£o do Donbass, apesar do reconhecimento por Moscovo da independ√™ncia das duas autoproclamadas rep√∫blicas separatistas, de Donetsk e Lugansk.
O Presidente da R√∫ssia, Vladimir Putin, anunciou que as for√ßas armadas russas poder√£o deslocar-se para aqueles territ√≥rios ucranianos em miss√£o de "manuten√ß√£o da paz", decis√£o que j√° foi autorizada pelo Senado russo.

translated_text:
Zelensky explained, in a communication to the country, that this new decree applies only to Ukrainians in the operational reserve, mobilized to reinforce the Army that fights pro-Russian militias in the Donbass region and faces the Russian military threat on the border.
The Ukrainian head of state added that, normally, this reserve is activated during periods of hostilities and that it covers "a special period of time", without specifying.
"We need to quickly add additional personnel to the Ukrainian Army and other military formations," he stressed.
The Armed Forces of Ukraine comprise around 250,000 soldiers and have a reserve of around 140,000, reports the Associated Press (AP).
Zelensky also announced that military exercises will take place "soon" for the Ukrainians in reserve status who will make up the territorial defense units.
The President of Ukraine ordered an increase in the number of members in these units to two million, which includes hunters and forest guards.
But he assured that, for now, "there is no need for general mobilization" among the population, something that pro-Russian separatists did on Saturday with all men of legal age.
In his address to the nation, Zelensky also ruled out a large-scale war with Russia and, in this way, rejected the imposition of martial law in the Donbas region, despite Moscow's recognition of the independence of the two self-proclaimed separatist republics, Donetsk and Lugansk.
The President of Russia, Vladimir Putin, announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
Zelensky, who considered Moscow's recognition a violation of his country's territorial integrity, did not go ahead with breaking diplomatic relations with Russia, despite having already admitted this scenario and being pressured to do so.
The Ukrainian head of state also regretted that the West did not adopt preventive sanctions against Russia before Moscow recognized the separatist republics.
But he welcomed the decisions already imposed, such as Germany's suspension of the certification of the controversial Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, which was supposed to transport Russian gas directly to Germany, without passing through Ukrainian territory.
Also today, the EU approved a "sanctions package" against Russia "unanimously", revealed the head of European diplomacy, Josep Borrell.
The United Kingdom also announced sanctions against three oligarchs known to be close to Russian President Vladimir Putin and against five Russian banks.
US President Joe Biden today announced a set of economic sanctions on Russian individuals, entities and banks.
Joe Biden stated that the United States of America (USA) is immediately imposing a "total blockade" on two large Russian financial institutions and "comprehensive sanctions" on Russian debt.

US will deploy 800 more troops to the Baltic countries
The Pentagon will send eight F-35 fighters to several locations on NATO's eastern flank, which are in Germany, and has given the green light for the transfer of 12 AH-64 helicopters from Greece to Poland.
The US Department of Defense recalled that the US has more than 90,000 soldiers deployed in Europe

The United States will send another 800 troops to the Baltic countries by the end of the week, to reinforce NATO's eastern flank in the face of Russia's growing threat to Ukraine.
A source from the US Department of Defense clarified the number
s Tuesday's announcement, made by US President Joe Biden, that he authorized the transfer of additional troops to the Baltic countries - Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.
These 800 soldiers are part of an infantry battalion that is currently in Italy and will be deployed to the Baltic region.

The United States will also move 20 AH-64 combat helicopters from Germany to those Eastern European countries.
At the same time, the Pentagon will send eight F-35 fighters to several locations on NATO's eastern flank, which are in Germany, and also gave the green light for the transfer of 12 AH-64 helicopters, from Greece to Poland.
The same source added that this transfer of military personnel and equipment will allow "to reassure NATO allies, deter any potential aggression against member states of the Atlantic Alliance and train the forces of the host nation."
US has more than 90,000 soldiers deployed in Europe
The US Department of Defense indicated that these movements of troops and equipment are "temporary" and recalled that the US has more than 90,000 soldiers deployed in Europe under rotational and permanent mandates.
On February 11, the Pentagon had ordered the sending of 3,000 additional soldiers to Poland, due to the increase in tensions in Ukraine, which increased the number of soldiers deployed by Washington in Europe due to this crisis to 6,000.
US President Joe Biden announced this Tuesday a set of economic sanctions on Russian individuals, entities and banks,
following Russia's recognition of the self-proclaimed republics of Donbass, in eastern Ukraine.
Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.
The decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.

translated_text:
O
Ukrainian parliament approved on Wednesday night President Volodymyr Zelenskiy's proposal to introduce a national state of emergency.
The country awaits a possible invasion by Russia, which has been prepared by the Russians and warned throughout today by Western intelligence services.
Russia has more than 150,000 troops along the border with Ukraine and this week the Russian parliament authorized the use of military action abroad.
On Tuesday, Russian President Vladimir Putin warned that he would send troops to the separatist republics of Donetsk and Lugansk, to "keep the peace", but Western allies, namely the United States, warned that the decision represented "the beginning of an invasion".
It should be noted that this new state of emergency does not apply to the separatist republics, which are technically part of Ukrainian sovereign territory - in these, the state of emergency has been in force since 2014, even though they are controlled by pro-Russian separatists.
The declaration comes into force this Thursday and was approved by 335 of the 339 deputies in the Ukrainian parliament.
The state of emergency now established in Ukraine allows authorities to impose restrictions on movement, prevent rallies and ban political and party activities in the "interests of national security and public order".
The document also prohibits the dissemination of "information material that could destabilize the situation in the country." This state also includes the possibility of evacuation from dangerous locations, control of citizens' documentation and regulation of civil radio and television stations.
If necessary, the state of emergency makes it possible to restrict freedom of movement, the registration of citizens' means of transport and belongings and the application of a mandatory curfew, a decision that is delegated to regional authorities.
[News updated at 9:42 pm]

translated_text:
"The
The use of force and coercion to change borders has no place in the 21st century. I call for a special European Council for tomorrow [Thursday] in Brussels to discuss the latest developments related to Ukraine and Russia", announced the President of the Council, Charles Michel, on his official account on the social network Twitter.
The summit will be held in person and is scheduled for 20:00 Brussels, 19:00 Lisbon.
In the letter of invitation addressed to the leaders, including Prime Minister Ant√≥nio Costa, the President of the European Council begins by thanking the 27 "for the unity demonstrated in recent days, particularly through the rapid adoption of the sanctions package" against Russia, in light of Moscow's recognition of the self-proclaimed republics of Luhansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and the decision of Russian President Vladimir Putin to mobilize military forces in the region.
Reiterating that "aggressive actions by the Russian Federation violate international law and the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine" and "also undermine the European security order", Charles Michel says it is important that the 27 remain "united and determined, to jointly define the approach and collective actions" in the face of the current situation.
The President of the European Council specifies that the objective of this extraordinary summit is to discuss "the latest developments", how the EU can "protect the rules-based international order", "how to deal with Russia, including holding it accountable for its actions", and "how to continue supporting Ukraine and its population".
The convening of this extraordinary European Council occurs on the same day that the Committee of Permanent Representatives of the Governments of the Member States of the European Union definitively adopted the sanctions against Russia approved by the 27 Foreign Ministers, on Tuesday.
On Tuesday night, the member states' ambassadors to the EU had already given final approval to the list of European sanctions on Russia, which, according to the head of European diplomacy, Josep Borrell, aim to "harm hard" on the Russian authorities, with the package being formally adopted today.
Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu and two private banks in Russia are among those targeted by the sanctions, which cover 27 individuals and entities from the political, military, business and media sectors, as well as around 350 members of the lower house of the Russian parliament (Duma).
Regarding financial sanctions, restrictions are expected on the EU's economic relations with the two separatist regions, Donetsk and Lugansk, as well as the freezing of assets of two Russian private banks and limits on the Russian State's ability to access the EU's capital and financial markets.
The EU's positions come after Russian President Vladimir Putin signed, on Monday night, a decree recognizing the self-proclaimed republics of Lugansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and ordered the mobilization of the Russian army to "maintain peace" in these pro-Russian separatist territories.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, who had feared for months that Russia would invade Ukraine again, after having annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea in 2014.
EU leaders already discussed the crisis in Brussels in person last week, in Brussels, in an informal meeting held immediately before the EU-Africa summit, with the president of the European Council deciding to schedule this summit as a matter of urgency in light of this week's developments, which have increased fears of a large-scale military conflict.

"Our country is always open to direct and honest dialogue to find diplomatic solutions to the most complex problems", said Vladimir Putin, in a televised speech broadcast on the occasion of Defender of the Fatherland Day.

Russia has demanded guarantees from Western countries that Ukraine will never become a member of NATO.

Russia on Monday recognized the two breakaway Ukrainian territories of Donetsk and Luhansk as independent.
On Tuesday, Russian authorities clarified that the recognition refers to territory occupied when the self-proclaimed republics announced this status in 2014, which includes space currently held by Ukrainian forces.
Putin announced that Russian armed forces will be able to move to those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission, a decision that has already been authorized by the Russian Senate.

translated_text:
T
Aip√© condemned Russia's decision to prepare to send troops to disputed territories in Ukraine and ordered the Taiwanese military to prepare its own defense against Beijing.
Without naming names, Tsai said that "external forces are trying to manipulate the situation in Ukraine and affect the morale of society" in Taiwan.
"The fact that the Taiwanese authorities are escalating the Ukrainian issue" and pretending to be alarmed by the situation is "insane", reacted Hua Chunying, spokesperson for China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
"Taiwan is definitely not Ukraine. Taiwan has always been an inalienable part of Chinese territory. This is an irrefutable historical and legal fact," he pointed out.
Beijing has intensified military, diplomatic and economic pressure on Taiwan since Tsai Ing-wen came to power in 2016. Unlike her predecessor, Tsai believes the island is a sovereign nation and not part of China.
Not recognized as an independent state by the UN, Taiwan has 23 million inhabitants and a democratic political system.
China has adopted a cautious stance toward Ukraine, but has also offered increasing support to Russian President Vladimir Putin.
Earlier this month, Moscow and Beijing signed a joint declaration in which they agreed on several foreign policy objectives, including rejecting NATO expansion and the return of Taiwan to China.
China and Taiwan have lived as two autonomous territories since 1949, when the former Chinese nationalist government took refuge on the island, following its defeat in the civil war against the communists.

This Wednesday, Ukraine was the target of a large-scale cyber attack.
According to the Russian news agency Interfax, the services of several institutions in the country, including the Ministries of Health, Security and Foreign Affairs, were disabled following a distributed denial of service attack (also known by the acronym DDoS in English). According to a Government source, several banks in the country were also affected.
Distributed denial of service attacks (also called distributed network attacks) take advantage of capacity limits that apply to all network resources, such as the infrastructure that powers a company's website, by sending multiple requests to the hacked web resource with the aim of exceeding the website's capacity and preventing its normal functioning.
The Ukrainian authorities, faced with an escalation of tensions with Russia, had already realized, during the week, that hacker plans were underway to launch major attacks on several institutions.

"Speak clearly." Putin reprimands head of the Secret Service on live television
Feb 22, 2022 - 22:26 ‚Ä¢
Writing
The moment was televised live last Monday.
A+
/
A-
"Speak clearly." Putin reprimands head of the Secret Service on live television
The head of Russia's Secret Service held a tense conversation with Vladimir Putin during the National Security Council meeting that led to the decision to recognize the people's republics of Donetsk and Luhansk as independent territories.
Sergei Naryshkin was repeatedly interrupted by the Russian President who, in a clear tone of reprimand, instructed him to "speak bluntly" about what he thought for the territories of eastern Ukraine.
"We could give our, let's say, Western partners, one last chance, presenting them with the choice, in the shortest possible time, to force Kiev to choose peace and implement the Minsk agreements," Naryshin told Putin, adding that, "in the worst case scenario, we must make the decision we are discussing today."
"What does 'in the worst case' mean? Are you suggesting that we start negotiations or that we recognize sovereignty?" Putin asked.
To the assertiveness of the question, the head of the Secret Service responded with a long stammer that led Putin to increase the pressure: "Speak, speak, speak bluntly!"
"I support the proposal on the entry of the Donetsk and Luhansk People's Republics into the Russian Federation," replied Naryshkin, but was quickly corrected by Putin.
"We're not talking about that", replied the President in a tone of clear disapproval. "We are talking about recognizing its independence or not.", to which Sergei Naryshin finally responded that he supported this proposal.

translated_text:
"The
The Russian Ministry of Finance, together with the Central Bank of Russia, will continue to closely monitor the situation on the financial markets and, if necessary, will take additional measures to strengthen financial stability," the ministry said in a statement cited by EFE.
In this way, "to help strengthen stability in the Russian debt market, decisions on bond placement in the coming weeks will be made taking into account market conditions," he added.
In the same note, the ministry noted that the Russian Treasury has "a significant amount of funds temporarily available": 4.5 billion rubles (56,557 million dollars or 49,799 million euros), compared to 2.2 billion rubles (27,634 million dollars or 24,343 million euros) that it intends to collect on the market in 2022.
"This allows for a flexible approach to the placement schedule" of bonds, the Finance Ministry said.
Furthermore, the ministry stated that, to address the risks of forced sales of public bonds by some foreign investors, the placement of bonds after February 22 will be carried out through the issuance of new bonds registered before that date.
The President of the United States of America (USA), Joe Biden, announced, on Tuesday, the first direct economic sanctions against two large Russian financial institutions, VEB (one of Russia's main investment and development banks) and the military bank (PSB).
Furthermore, he announced "comprehensive" sanctions against Russia's sovereign debt to block the Moscow Government's access to Western financing.
"[Russia] will no longer be able to obtain money from the West and will also not be able to negotiate new debts in our markets or in European markets", stressed the North American President.
The sanctions came after Russia recognized the self-proclaimed separatist republics of Donetsk and Luhansk in eastern Ukraine and announced the deployment of Russian troops to those territories, which Moscow described as a peacekeeping mission.
